Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>storehouse</kanji> <kanji>storage</kanji> is a place you put things (like food) to keep them cool. This is a <vocabulary>refrigerator</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why did you get a tattoo that says refrigerator?
Context 1-JP: <jp>なんでタトゥーで冷蔵庫なんて彫ったの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: From the <kanji>backside</kanji> you <kanji>cut</kanji> someone. Wow. What a jerk. What a <vocabulary>backstab</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is <jp>裏</jp> and <jp>切る</jp>'s readings, put together.
Context 1-EN: They use this facility to kill traitors.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奴らは裏切り者を殺すのにこの施設を利用している。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: "<reading>Yo, so, oh</reading>, you gonna wear that <vocabulary>attire</vocabulary> today or what?"
Context 1-EN: You’re already in a spring dress.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もうすっかり春の装いだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Change</kanji> your <kanji>attire</kanji> to look like someone else. This is a <vocabulary>disguise</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I made it to the disguise class at the last minute.
Context 1-JP: <jp>変装教室にギリギリ間に合いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This <kanji>attire</kanji> is <kanji>put</kanji> inside this <vocabulary>equipment</vocabulary>, where it's changed into something else. This attire <vocabulary>device</vocabulary> is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I learned how to use an electrical control unit today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は電気制御装置の使い方を学びました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>backside</kanji> <kanji>street</kanji> (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an <vocabulary>alley</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>裏</jp> and <jp>通り</jp> put together into one word.
Context 1-EN: The race car sped, weaving through the side streets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>レーシングカーは、裏通りを縫うようにして走っていった。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Scared,To Be Afraid Of,To Fear
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>怖い</jp> is "scary." This is a verb version, making it <vocabulary>to be scared</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be afraid of</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>怖い</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My husband was very scared of getting surgery for his ingrown eyelashes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の主人は逆さ睫毛の手術を受けるのをとても怖がっていたんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Rent</kanji> it and I will <kanji>lend</kanji> it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a <vocabulary>rental</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that <jp>貸</jp> is read as <jp>たい</jp> for this one. What is your rental? It is a <reading>tie</reading> (<jp>たい</jp>) fighter. Sweet.
Context 1-EN: My friend is looking for an apartment to rent, don’t you know any good places?
Context 1-JP: <jp>友人が賃貸のアパートを探してるんですが、どこかいい物件を知りませんかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>主催</jp> is <kanji>sponsorship</kanji>, the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to sponsor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <jp>主催</jp> already as well.
Context 1-EN: Our school is hosting a karaoke party this Saturday. Would you like to join us?
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの学校で土曜日にカラオケパーティーを主催するんだけど、よかったら来ない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fear</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to fear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is shared with <jp>恐ろしい</jp>, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.
Context 1-EN: I’m not afraid of anything except for going blind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>目が見えなくなること以外は、何も恐れることはないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The word <jp>迷う</jp> means "to go astray" but this word is <vocabulary>to lead astray</vocabulary>. You are doing the astraying to someone or something else. You know this because the other person <reading>was</reading> (<jp>わす</jp>) just fine until you came along to lead them astray.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>迷う</jp>, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.
Context 1-EN: If you lead my daughter astray, I’ll never forgive you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし俺の娘を路頭に迷わすようなことがあったら、一生許さないぞ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>催促</jp> is <kanji>urge</kanji>, then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know <jp>催促</jp> first.
Context 1-EN: I’m sorry to be so demanding, but can you take some pictures of Tokyo Tower and send them to me by Monday, please? Thanks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>催促するようで申し訳ありませんが、東京タワーの写真を何枚か撮って月曜日までに送ってもらえませんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I don't know why a <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>pole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>robber</vocabulary>, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>泥</jp> plus the reading for <jp>棒</jp> put together.
Context 1-EN: The training to become a burglar is as hard as boot camp.
Context 1-JP: <jp>泥棒になるためのトレーニングは、ブートキャンプ並にハードです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>掃除</jp> is <kanji>cleaning</kanji>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to clean</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word <jp>掃除</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: "I’ve been awake since four this morning." "No way! What have you been doing?" "Well, just cleaning around the house."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「今朝は4時から起きてるよ。」「嘘でしょ？いったい何してるの？」「えっと…家を大掃除してるの。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>乾く</jp> is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>乾く</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I love you so much. I need you. Could you please dry my wet shirts right now, Mr. Sun? Please!!!!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたを愛しています。僕にはあなたが必要なんです。太陽さん、どうか僕の濡れたシャツを今すぐ乾かしてくれませんか？お願いします！！！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>散る</jp> is "to be scattered." This is when you're doing the scattering. You know that because you're causing a <reading>ruckus</reading> (<jp>らかす</jp>) from all the scattering of money you're doing, down on the people below.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading of the <jp>散</jp> comes from <jp>散る</jp>. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.
Context 1-EN: There are dirty clothes scattered all over the floor in my room. Even if I cleaned them up, it would just get messy again the next day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の部屋には脱ぎっぱなしの服が床に散らかっています。掃除しても、次の日にはまたすぐ散らかしちゃうんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>複数</jp> is <kanji>multiple</kanji>, and <jp>形</jp> is <kanji>shape</kanji>, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the <vocabulary>plural</vocabulary>, or the <vocabulary>plural form</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word <jp>複数</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: The plural of sheep is sheep.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Sheepの複数形はsheepです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My friend said, "You don't even know the plural of this word?" and laughed at me, and I was very hurt.
Context 2-JP: <jp>「この単語の複数形も知らないの？」って友達に笑われて、とても傷つきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In Japanese you don’t need to change things to the plural form as often as in English.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本語では英語に比べて単語を複数形にすることは少ないです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Not to be confused with <jp>会社</jp>, which is a company, this is <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. When a <kanji>company</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>s together, it's like a bunch of people, who are in groups, who come together to live in one world. That is a <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Even if I leave home right now, I think I’ll probably be late for social studies.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今家を出ても、社会のじゅぎょうに間にあわないと思います。</jp>
Context 2-EN: As a member of the international society, I will not yield to food porn.
Context 2-JP: <jp>国さい社会の一員として、めしテロにはだんじてくっしません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As a society, we need to be concerned about youths taking ’selfies’ at funerals.
Context 3-JP: <jp>社会問題として、若者がお葬式で自分撮りをすることについて考える必要がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>lung</kanji> <kanji>internal organ</kanji> is the <vocabulary>lung</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My grandfather died of inflammation of the lungs.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の祖父は肺臓炎で亡くなりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>internal organs</kanji> is the <vocabulary>heart</vocabulary>, of course.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have a kind of telephone phobia and my heart starts beating very fast whenever I talk on the phone.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電話恐怖症みたいなのがあって、電話で話をする時に心臓がバクバクするんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>越す</jp> means "to go beyond." <jp>追</jp> is <kanji>follow</kanji>. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means <vocabulary>to overtake</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>追う</jp> and <jp>越す</jp> put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.
Context 1-EN: I always wave my hand to say hi whenever I pass other bikers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>他の自転車走者を追い越す時、いつも挨拶代わりに手を振ります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that to <jp>飼う</jp> is "to keep a pet." If you're the <kanji>master</kanji> that is <kanji>keeping a pet</kanji> (<jp>飼う</jp>), then you are the <vocabulary>pet owner</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words <jp>飼う</jp> and <jp>主</jp> to be able to remember the reading of this word.
Context 1-EN: If a dog’s owner had chickenpox, could the dog get it too?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし犬の飼い主が水疱瘡になったら、その犬も水疱瘡になる可能性はあるんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>祖父</jp> is grandfather and <jp>祖母</jp> is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your <vocabulary>grandparents</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>祖父</jp> and <jp>祖母</jp>, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: My grandparents still see their pediatrician.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の祖父母はまだ小児科医にかかっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>傷</jp> is "wound"? Now a wound is <jp>つく</jp>ing to you, or in other words, is getting attached to you. If you get a wound attached to your body, you are probably going <vocabulary>to get hurt</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <jp>傷</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Aren’t I too young to be called a middle-aged woman? I’m hurt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おばちゃんって呼ばれる年齢かなあ。傷つくなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>fly</kanji> into something <kanji>crowded</kanji> (say a moving train full of people) to die by <kanji>suicide</kanji> (<jp>自殺</jp>), that is going to be <vocabulary>suicide by train</vocabulary>. Unfortunately, this is a term you should probably be familiar with because it comes up from time to time on the news and around train stations. (Hopefully someday it will no longer be a term you need to know and we can remove it forever.)
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>飛ぶ</jp>, <jp>込む</jp>, and <jp>自殺</jp>. Combine them together to read this entire word.
Context 1-EN: He hooked up my PlayStation to his TV before leaving our house to commit suicide by jumping in front of a train. Do you think it means something?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつ、飛び込み自殺をするために家を出る前、俺のプレイステーションをあいつのテレビに繋いだんだよな。何か意味があったのかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>say</kanji> a <kanji>reason</kanji> for your actions, but really it's just an <vocabulary>excuse</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>言う</jp> and <jp>訳</jp> combined.
Context 1-EN: I sent her an explanation email and I hope she can understand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>分かってもらえることを願って、言い訳を書いたEメールを送りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>valuable</kanji> <kanji>formal name title</kanji>. It's like saying something like "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means <vocabulary>you</vocabulary>, but it isn't as nice as it sounds. Probably a lot of irony and sarcasm going into this word, because if you use <jp>きさま</jp> to say "you" to someone, you're probably not pleased with that person, or you're just trying to be rude.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the reading you learned with <jp>貴</jp> plus the vocab reading for <jp>様</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I couldn’t sleep well because YOU were very noisy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>貴様がうるさかったせいで、昨日全然寝れなかったじゃねぇか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>descend</kanji>, but this word means something closer to <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to come down</vocabulary>. Usually used with things like rain or snow.
Reading Mnemonic: The rain is <vocabulary>to fall</vocabulary> and you're outside anyway with your mouth open so you'll get a mouth <reading>full</reading> (<jp>ふる</jp>) of rainwater! All the ponds, wells, and your yard will be full of water too!
Context 1-EN: I was walking my dog in the afternoon while the rain fell.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お昼過ぎ、にわか雨が降る中、私は愛犬の散歩をしていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cow</kanji> <kanji>rice bowl</kanji> is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a <vocabulary>beef bowl</vocabulary>. Go get some Yoshinoya.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the same readings that you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "This beef bowl is my treat." "Oh, thank you. I’ll take you up on that."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「この牛丼は、私のおごりね。」「わあ、ありがとう。じゃあ、お言葉に甘えます。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shrink</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to shrink</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Jesus couldn't cause the monster <vocabulary>to shrink</vocabulary>. He had to transform into <reading>cheese jesus</reading> (<jp>ちぢ</jp>), a more powerful version of himself, in order to shrink the monster down to size.
Context 1-EN: My puppy was shrinking in fear while the thunder was rumbling.
Context 1-JP: <jp>雷がゴロゴロ鳴っている間、うちの犬は怖がって縮まっていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Shrink</kanji> what you have into something <kanji>small</kanji>. It was big, now it's small. This is a <vocabulary>reduction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Our company is thinking of reducing our profit margin to be competitive with another company.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの会社、他社との競争に勝つために、利鞘を縮小することを検討しているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You are <vocabulary>stylish</vocabulary>. If you're stylish, you always <reading><jp>いき</jp></reading> (<jp>いき</jp>) to the clothing stores to buy more stylish clothes.
Context 1-EN: He believes that he carries on refined conversations, but they’re actually irritating.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分で粋な会話をしてるって思ってるところがムカツクんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>holy</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is a <vocabulary>holy day</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Today is a Jewish holy day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日はユダヤ教の聖日にあたります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
Context 1-EN: I’m looking for nice curtains that will suit our 100 centimeter by 160 centimeter window.
Context 1-JP: <jp>縦100cm横160cmの窓に合う良いカーテンを探しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>holy</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bible</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m halfway through the bible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>聖書を半分ぐらい読み終わりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Magnet</kanji>ic <kanji>energy</kanji> is when <vocabulary>magnetism</vocabulary> occurs.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You shouldn’t put magnetic cards and magnets together.
Context 1-JP: <jp>磁気カードと磁石を一緒にしない方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>deep red</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> isn't a deep red tea... it's a <vocabulary>black tea</vocabulary>. If you think about it, a lot of black tea is really deep red, which is why a deep red tea is a black tea instead.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How do you like your black tea?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お紅茶はどのようにおいれ致しましょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>shoot</kanji> something into someone that you actually have to <kanji>pour</kanji> (aka a liquid), you're shooting them up with a needle, giving them a <vocabulary>shot</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>injection</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My lower back was sore so the doctor gave me a shot of painkillers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>腰が痛かったんですが、お医者さんが痛み止めの注射を打ってくれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It <kanji>release</kanji>s and <kanji>shoot</kanji>s out of the bomb. It's not fire. It's <vocabulary>radiation</vocabulary>, and it sticks around a long time once it has been released.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It was very cold when I got up this morning because of radiational cooling.
Context 1-JP: <jp>放射冷却のせいで今朝起きた時はものすごい冷え込みだったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Departure</kanji> and <kanji>shoot</kanji> something off. If you do that to something, you are going <vocabulary>to launch</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The missile was launched as planned.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ミサイルは予定通り発射された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.
Context 1-EN: In the play, the curtain came down when the heroine passed away.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その劇では、女主人公が死んで幕が下りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Just imagine a <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>curtain</kanji> off in the background. You don't know what's behind it, but you know what's in front of it. Thing is, the thing in front of the curtain is controlled by whoever is behind the black curtain. This person is the <vocabulary>wirepuller</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mastermind</vocabulary> of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings for <jp>黒</jp> and <jp>幕</jp>, though the vocab reading for <jp>幕</jp> is the same as the on'yomi reading, making things easy for you.
Context 1-EN: So, you are the mastermind, huh? No wonder you seemed so professional when you killed her.
Context 1-JP: <jp>結局、あんたが黒幕だったんだな。どうりであの女を殺した時手慣れていたと思ったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>infer</kanji> <kanji>reason</kanji> is to have <vocabulary>reasoning</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I inferred that the intimidating letter was written by an American due to the way the date was written.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日付の書き方から、その脅迫状はアメリカ人によって書かれたものだと推理しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>worship</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to worship</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You have <vocabulary>to worship</vocabulary> the <reading>ogre</reading> (<jp>おが</jp>), because if you don't it'll eat your face off.
Context 1-EN: My family gathers in front of our family Buddhist altar to pray to Buddha every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の家族は、毎朝仏壇の前に集まって仏様に拝みます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: As for my<kanji>self</kanji>? I <kanji>recommend</kanji> this product. It is a <vocabulary>self recommendation</vocabulary>. You make it of yourself!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We accept both self recommendations and direct applications for this modeling position.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今回のモデルへの応募について、自薦・他薦は問いません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>infer</kanji> and <kanji>recommend</kanji> something is to give a <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary>. What do you recommend?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I recommended you as a good farter for the fart competition.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたを、優秀な屁こき野郎として、屁こき大会に推薦しておきましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Departure</kanji> and <kanji>brandish</kanji> this thing. This means you're sending something out to show to everyone. That's why this is <vocabulary>to exhibit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to demonstrate</vocabulary> (because when you brandish, and send it out to show, you're demonstrating it!).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>はつ</jp> becomes <jp>はっ</jp>, though.
Context 1-EN: Who demonstrated the most leadership in solving the problem?
Context 1-JP: <jp>問題解決にリーダーシップを一番発揮していたのは誰ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>family name</kanji> is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of <kanji>Genji</kanji>. These kanji represent <vocabulary>Genji</vocabulary>, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why is the fake name for prostitutes, hostesses, and geisha called a "Genji name?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして娼婦やホステス、キャバ嬢、芸者さんなどが使う偽名を「源氏名」って言うんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It can <kanji>carry</kanji> a <kanji>river</kanji>. It's a <vocabulary>canal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>か</jp> goes to <jp>が</jp>, probably while floating down said <vocabulary>canal</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: You can skate on the canal during the winter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>冬には運河の上でスケートができますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>run alongside</kanji> <kanji>coast</kanji> basically just describes the <vocabulary>coast</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He asked me to sail along the coast in his yacht with him this Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今度の日曜日にヨットで沿岸を一緒に帆走しないかって彼に誘われたんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> is where the electricity comes from. It is the <vocabulary>power source</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When I go out, I turn off all the power by unplugging everything from the electrical sockets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>出かける時は、完全に電源を切るために全部のコンセントを抜きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> is the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, but it also refers to the <vocabulary>ground spring</vocabulary>s, where the origin of water comes from.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Think of how this <vocabulary>ground spring</vocabulary> is everyone's (<jp>皆</jp>) origin (<jp>元</jp>). Everyone can use it, it's the <jp>皆元</jp>!
Context 1-EN: Music is a source of power in my daily life.
Context 1-JP: <jp>音楽が私の日々の生活のパワーの源です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>brandish</kanji> it to <vocabulary>command</vocabulary> the troops.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings, so if you know those you may take command of this vocab word.
Context 1-EN: I’d like to meet the commanding officer of the American army.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アメリカ軍を指揮している司令官に一度会ってみたいな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (<vocabulary>drama</vocabulary>). Can also mean <vocabulary>play</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>show</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. No more drama from you, okay?
Context 1-EN: I saw off the emperor, who was going to see the opera.
Context 1-JP: <jp>オペラ劇を観劇しに行く天皇へい下をお見送りしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The person who plays the role of the horse in Act II Scene III of this play is my older brother.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この劇の第2幕第3場で馬の役をしているのがオレの兄貴なんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The person next to me was constantly cracking their knuckles during the show and it was so annoying.
Context 3-JP: <jp>隣の席の人が劇の最中にずっと指をポキポキ鳴らしてて、すっごく苛々しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>earthquake</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is where the earthquake started from. It is the <vocabulary>epicenter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried about my friends who live close to the epicenter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>震源地に近いところに住んでる友達が心配だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone keeps saying <kanji>furthermore</kanji> and <kanji>also</kanji> over and over again. Just when you think they've stopped, they turn around and say "<vocabulary>and yet</vocabulary>," before going back to repeating <vocabulary>furthermore</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>besides</vocabulary> again and again. It's driving you crazy.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She’s beautiful, and furthermore, she's smart, but she has a terrible personality.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は、美しく、尚且つ頭も良いが、性格は悪い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Rejoice</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji> isn't so much drama as it is <vocabulary>comedy</vocabulary>, since it makes you rejoice.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The movie is too sad. It should be called a tragedy, not a comedy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その映画は悲しすぎて、喜劇というよりは悲劇だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After watching a documentary about Chaplin, the king of comedy, I decided to pursue a career in comedy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>喜劇王チャップリンのドキュメンタリーを観て自分もお笑いの道を目指そうと思いました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It was so hot that I kept fanning myself while watching the comedy show.
Context 3-JP: <jp>すごく暑かったので、喜劇を観ながらずっと自分をうちわで扇いでいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Describe</kanji> your surroundings by <kanji>mention</kanji>ing everything you see. What you just said was a <vocabulary>description</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In this lesson we’re going to learn to link together illustrations, photographs, and descriptions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この授業では、挿し絵や写真と叙述を結び付けることを学びます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is where people do drama. This is a <vocabulary>theater</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Let's meet up in the theater's lobby.
Context 1-JP: <jp>劇場のロビーで待ち合わせしましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I’ll see you at a bathroom in the theater then.
Context 2-JP: <jp>それでは劇場のトイレで会いましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My daily commute to the theater is over two hours each way.
Context 3-JP: <jp>劇場までの毎日の通勤に、片道二時間以上かかります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>work</kanji> is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is <vocabulary>full time employment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>full time</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I won’t be able to work full-time for now until my child gets a little older.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもがもうちょっと大きくなるまでは、常勤でのお仕事はちょっと無理かな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>consent</kanji> and <kanji>know</kanji> everything that's going on. You <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>know</vocabulary> about all this.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I can’t consent to your marrying my daughter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わしの娘がお前と結婚することは承知できん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This tree consists of many <vocabulary>branch</vocabulary>es. This particular branch, the one you're looking at, is <reading>E</reading>. Those others are other letters, but this is E...<jp>だ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The branches were bent by blood red apples.
Context 1-JP: <jp>枝は真っ赤な林檎でたわんでいた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pig</kanji>'s <kanji>meat</kanji> is called <vocabulary>pork</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I might have gotten food poisoning from the pork I had for lunch. I feel so sick. Is it okay if I’m out of the office for the rest of the day?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ランチに食べた豚肉に当たったかもしれません。すごく気持ち悪いんですが、早退させてもらえませんかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>loss</kanji> is a <vocabulary>heavy loss</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>おお</jp> reading of <jp>大</jp> coupled with the on'yomi reading for <jp>損</jp>. Just keep in mind that the <jp>そん</jp> changes to <jp>ぞん</jp> and you'll be good here.
Context 1-EN: I went to a pachinko parlor in the hopes of making a lot of money, but I ended up with a heavy loss instead.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大儲けするつもりでパチンコに行ったが、結局大損してしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>loss</kanji> will give you a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>handicap</vocabulary>. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a <vocabulary>disadvantage</vocabulary>... this time.
Context 1-EN: I had a loss of $500 in poker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ポーカーで五百ドル損をした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Rot</kanji> and <kanji>failure</kanji> lead to <vocabulary>decomposition</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rotting</vocabulary>. This word also has the related meaning of  <vocabulary>corruption</vocabulary>, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: There was a smell of something decomposing in the air.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そこには、何かが腐敗したような臭いがただよっていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This additive prevents food from rotting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この添加物により、食品の腐敗が防げます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Many people are tired of the corrupt political ring.
Context 3-JP: <jp>多くの人々が腐敗した政治組織にうんざりしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something <kanji>rot</kanji>s and <kanji>eat</kanji>s away at something, that is <vocabulary>corrosion</vocabulary>. Not a good thing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Stainless steel is supposed to withstand corrosion, isn’t it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ステンレスは腐食作用への耐久性があるんじゃなかったっけ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rot</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rot</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember the word <jp>臭い</jp>, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all <reading><jp>くさ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: Don’t leave milk out of the fridge because it goes bad easily.
Context 1-JP: <jp>牛乳は腐りやすいんだから冷蔵庫の外に出しっ放しにしないでね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Small</kanji> <kanji>bean</kanji>s refer to a type of bean known as <vocabulary>azuki bean</vocabulary>s. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are <vocabulary>azuki beans</vocabulary>, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as <reading>azuki</reading> (<jp>あずき</jp>). Other than that, there's not much else to do.
Context 1-EN: Azuki bean paste is made of azuki beans, but it’s pretty high in sugar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>餡こは小豆から作られているが、けっこう糖分が高い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>to carve</vocabulary> up the steak, you wish you could use a knife, but you don't have one. Instead, you'll have to use your <reading>keys</reading> (<jp>きざ</jp>) to cut it. Imagine trying to cut up the steak with these keys. It's very difficult.
Context 1-EN: I can’t be bothered to cut up the green onion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>葱を刻むのは面倒くさいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that <kanji>carve</kanji>s out all the <kanji>time</kanji>s for something (say, on a big sign) and then <kanji>express</kanji>es them to the world, is a <vocabulary>timetable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>schedule</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The train schedule is a must-have for commuters.
Context 1-JP: <jp>通勤・通学者にとって、電車の時刻表は絶対に必要なものです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>庶民</jp> means "common people?" Well when all the common people <kanji>like</kanji> something it becomes <vocabulary>popular</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The humble taste of the udon here is good.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここの饂飩はこの庶民的な味がいいんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>編む</jp> is "to knit." When you knit in <kanji>three</kanji>s, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this <vocabulary>braided hair</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>み</jp> from <jp>三つ</jp> and <jp>つ</jp> and <jp>編む</jp> combined into one (or should I say three?) braids. Just watch out because this isn't <jp>みっつあみ</jp>, it's just <jp>みつあみ</jp>. Listen to the audio a few times to make sure you remember how it's spelled and pronounced!
Context 1-EN: Oh come on, it was so obvious! There was no chemistry between you two! You definitely shouldn’t call that girl with the braided hair!
Context 1-JP: <jp>おいおい、頼むよ。明らかにお前たちの相性全然よくなかっただろ！絶対にあの三つ編みの女に電話なんてしない方がいいって！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>閉める</jp> is "to shut" or "to close" this is going to be the version where you don't do anything and something shuts on its own. This word is <vocabulary>to be shut</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be closed</vocabulary>. You know this because you put your hand in the door to open it, but then it shuts (on its own) on your hand, <reading>marring</reading> your hand forever.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>閉める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Suddenly, the door shut by itself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>突然、扉がひとりでに閉まりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I will <kanji>supply</kanji> and you will <kanji>acquire</kanji>. Does that sound good? Do I have your <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird for <jp>納</jp>. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "<reading>Nahh!</reading> (<jp>なっ</jp>), no consent!"
Context 1-EN: You made my daughter consent by using money, didn’t you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうせお前は娘を金ずくで納得させたんだろう？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>否定</jp> is "denial," then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to deny</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word <jp>否定</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: I deny the theory that natto goes well with rice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は納豆がご飯に合うって説は否定しますね。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Satisfied,To Be Settled,To Be Paid,To Be Supplied,To Be Delivered
Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>納める</jp> is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's <vocabulary>to be satisfied</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be settled</vocabulary>. You aren't doing the supplying, and you know this because if you were to be caught supplying your reputation would be <reading>marr</reading>ed (<jp>まる</jp> for life).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>納める</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I don't think they will be satisfied with just money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>金を払うだけで、彼らが納まるとは思えないけどな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I was too <kanji>slow</kanji>, so we'll have to <kanji>prolong</kanji> the time in which this product will come out. This is a <vocabulary>delay</vocabulary> :(
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The bus was delayed for a long time and I was late to the meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バスの大幅な遅延により会議に遅れてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> with a <vocabulary>different meaning</vocabulary> (<jp>異義</jp>), and it's a part of <kanji>language</kanji>. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a <vocabulary>homonym</vocabulary>, you know?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.
Context 1-EN: I made a youtube video about homonyms, so please take a look.
Context 1-JP: <jp>同音異義語に関するYoutubeビデオを作ったので、よかったら見てみてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>著作</jp> is "writing" or "authorship." The <kanji>rights</kanji> that writing has is what's known as <vocabulary>copyright</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know <jp>著作</jp> first, too.
Context 1-EN: I don’t want you guys to use someone else’s work regardless of whether or not it is subject to copyright.
Context 1-JP: <jp>著作権の対象となるかどうかに関わらず、他人の作品は使用しないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>蒸れる</jp> is "to be humid." So, if you have a humid hot, you have weather that is <vocabulary>hot and humid</vocabulary> (or you can just say <vocabulary>humid</vocabulary>, because that implies hotness too, usually). This is a useful word for summers in Japan, since you'll complain about this all the time.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>蒸れる</jp> and <jp>暑い</jp>. Know those and you know this too.
Context 1-EN: This summer is definitely more humid than it was last year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の夏は絶対去年よりも蒸し暑いよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>beforehand</kanji> <kanji>measure</kanji> is when you make a <vocabulary>prediction</vocabulary> of something.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Scientists failed to predict the massive earthquake.
Context 1-JP: <jp>科学者たちは、大地震の予測に失敗した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>View</kanji> and <kanji>measure</kanji> what you are watching. This is <vocabulary>observation</vocabulary>. It is no mere viewing, it is more than that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How can I become a member of Antarctic exploration party?
Context 1-JP: <jp>南極観測隊のメンバーになるにはどうすればいいですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>cottage</kanji> is a place where the soldiers stay. This is the <vocabulary>barracks</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The barracks were filled with such an offensive stench that I could barely breathe.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その兵舎には異臭が漂っており、息をするのもやっとだった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>measure</kanji> so the verb vocab means <vocabulary>to measure</vocabulary>. This word generally has to do with scientific or medical measurements.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember another word that means "to measure?" It is <jp>量る</jp>, and has the same reading as this word. That should make things easier to remember.
Context 1-EN: The nurse is good at measuring people’s blood pressure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その看護婦さんは、血圧を測るのが上手です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tear</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary>.

Meaning: To Be Drunk,To Be Seasick,To Be Carsick
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drunk</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be drunk</vocabulary>. This drunk feeling also happens to some people in boats and cars. But we call that <vocabulary>to be seasick</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be carsick</vocabulary>. You aren't actually drunk, but you feel like you are (and you're probably gonna puke, yuck!).
Reading Mnemonic: I'm not drunk, <reading>yo</reading> (<jp>よ</jp>). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.
Context 1-EN: Everybody got seasick and puked all over the ship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>みんな船に酔ってしまい、そこら中に吐き散らかしていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Never drive when you are drunk.
Context 2-JP: <jp>酔ってる時に車を運転するのは絶対にダメだよ。</jp>

Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>奈</jp> is good, the reading for <jp>良</jp> is pretty off in terms of what you've learned. But, if you know that the meaning is Nara, you know the reading is <reading><jp>なら</jp></reading> as well.
Context 1-EN: I removed stubborn color stains on my teeth at the dental clinic in Nara.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は歯のしつこい着色汚れを奈良の歯医者さんで落としました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that will <kanji>exchange</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is something that pulls in air, takes out the bad stuff, and then outputs good air, exchanging it for the bad. That is <vocabulary>ventilation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why don’t we open the window and air out the room?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっと窓を開けて部屋の換気をしない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>change</kanji>, but this verb is <vocabulary>to change</vocabulary>. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going <vocabulary>to change</vocabulary> it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.
Reading Mnemonic: I don't like this car. I would like <vocabulary>to change</vocabulary> it for another <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>).
Context 1-EN: When you become an adult, it's difficult to change your way of thinking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大人になると、考え方を変えることはむずかしいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Oh, please do not change the shape of Fugu's lips. They were inspired by Koichi's favorite food, cod roe. If you change them, Koichi will be sad.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あっ、フグのくちびるの形は変えないでください。それはコウイチの好物のタラコをモチーフにしているんです。変えたらコウイチが悲しみます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you change the shape of your eyebrows, you look like a different person.
Context 3-JP: <jp>眉毛の形を変えると、まるで別人のようだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take your <kanji>finger</kanji> and <kanji>pluck</kanji> out the one thing out of all the things that needs <vocabulary>pointing out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>identification</vocabulary>. Yep, that's the one. Pluck that one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do you mind if I point out your mistakes?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっと間違いを指摘させてもらってもいいですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obsolete</kanji> and this word means <vocabulary>to become obsolete</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Everything has <vocabulary>to become obsolete</vocabulary>. Even the biggest most fiery things, like a <reading>sta</reading>r, for example, will go obsolete at some point.
Context 1-EN: Viet insists that the cupcake boom has already died out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトはカップケーキブームは既に廃れていると主張した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>憎む</jp> is "to hate" then the noun version would be <vocabulary>hatred</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>憎む</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I certainly thought they hated each other.
Context 1-JP: <jp>てっきり彼らはお互いに憎しみ合っているものだと思っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>haven</kanji> for <kanji>wave</kanji>s would be inside the greatest most deadly wave of them all... the <vocabulary>tsunami</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tidal wave</vocabulary>. Dun dun dunnnn!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the <jp>津</jp> and <jp>波</jp> kun'yomi readings, combined together.
Context 1-EN: Many people were swept away by the tsunami.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たくさんの人達が津波に流されてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'd like to <kanji>offer</kanji> <kanji>money</kanji>, no strings attached. It's free. It's a <vocabulary>donation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I wrapped some money up as a political donation and gave it to them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>政治献金としていくらかお金を包んだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I would like to <kanji>offer</kanji> my <kanji>blood</kanji> to someone else in the form of a <vocabulary>blood donation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I saw a car bump into the mobile blood bank van.
Context 1-JP: <jp>車が移動献血車に衝突するのを見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>nucleus</kanji> experiment (<jp>実験</jp>) is a <vocabulary>nuclear test</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Budget-wise, we are unable to increase our temporary staff for nuclear testing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>予算の都合上、核実験への臨時スタッフの採用は増やせない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Nucleus</kanji> arms (<jp>へいき</jp>), aka weapons, are <vocabulary>nuclear weapons</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Before using the nuclear weapon, please carefully review the instruction booklet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>核兵器を使用する前に、説明書に書かれている操作方法を必ずお読みください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dance</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to dance</vocabulary>, as well as <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Who is the greatest dancer of them all? China's previous ruler, <reading>Mao</reading> (<jp>まう</jp>).
Context 1-EN: In my boyfriend’s room a bunch of dust was fluttering about and it was disgusting, so I tried to imagine that they were beautiful petals fluttering about instead. It didn’t work.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼氏の部屋、埃がすっごい舞ってて最悪だったんだけど、綺麗な花びらが舞っているんだって思い込むように頑張ってみたさ。ま、無理だったけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dance</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> isn't really a machine... a <jp>台</jp> is a large machine thing counter, so in this case it's talking about a stage. A dancing stage is a <vocabulary>stage</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that <jp>台</jp> is read as <jp>たい</jp> here, not <jp>だい</jp>.
Context 1-EN: You have such a great voice. Have you ever thought about singing on stage?
Context 1-JP: <jp>すごくいい声持ってるね。舞台で歌を歌ってみようと思った事はないの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>father</kanji> you've <kanji>inherit</kanji>ed isn't your original father, he's your <vocabulary>stepfather</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My stepfather used to give me piggyback rides all the time when I was little.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小さい頃、継父にいつもおんぶをしてもらっていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Maintain</kanji> what we have and put it on <kanji>hold</kanji>. We need to keep it up to date and fixed, so we need <vocabulary>maintenance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The cost of car maintenance is really high and I can’t afford that yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>車は維持費が高いし、今はまだそんな余裕はないな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>step</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to step on</vocabulary>. So, not quite "to step" like you might expect, but at least you're stepping still, though it's on something.
Reading Mnemonic: You want <vocabulary>to step on</vocabulary> that bug? You <reading>foo</reading>l (<jp>ふ</jp>)! That's a killer shoe stabbing bug, it will cut right through your sole and poison you via your foot! <reading>Foo</reading>l!
Context 1-EN: Eww! Did you step in poop! Yuck!
Context 1-JP: <jp>うわぁ！うんこ踏んじゃったの？きもーい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>generally</kanji> does things... in <vocabulary>general</vocabulary>. It's more <vocabulary>common</vocabulary> this way.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the <jp>はん</jp> changes to <jp>ぱん</jp> for <jp>般</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Those pumps are a little too expensive for an ordinary person like me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私みたいな一般庶民には、そのパンプスはちょっと高すぎるかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>ultra</kanji> natural (<jp>自然的</jp>) is <vocabulary>supernatural</vocabulary>. Too natural! Super!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Have I ever told you about my supernatural power?
Context 1-JP: <jp>そういえば、私の超自然的な力についてお話したことってありましたっけ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>ultra</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ultrasonic wave</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the <jp>は</jp> changes to <jp>ぱ</jp> for <jp>波</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I was told that ultrasonic waves destroy fat cells permanently, so I bought this machine for $3,000.
Context 1-JP: <jp>超音波なら脂肪細胞を永久に破壊することができると言われたので、この3000ドルもする機械を買ったんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>super</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji> that's <kanji>fast</kanji> is <vocabulary>supersonic speed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My panda robot can fly at supersonic speeds.
Context 1-JP: <jp>僕のパンダロボットは、超音速で空を飛べるんだぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You're staring really closely at this <vocabulary>deer</vocabulary>, but something looks off. You get closer, slowly, and you realize it's a <reading>shee</reading>p in a <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>しか</jp>) shaped like a deer. The sheep car deer suddenly turns toward you rushing forward, legs raised. Ahh, get outta there! (The lesson here is to never get too close to a deer. You never know its true form until it's too late.)
Context 1-EN: I can’t distinguish between male and female deer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>牡鹿と牝鹿の区別がつきません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>believe</kanji> I can <kanji>trust</kanji> you. That's why I put so much <vocabulary>reliance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trust</vocabulary> on you to do well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don’t wanna jump to conclusions because he seems to be pretty trustworthy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は信頼できるような気がするし、早合点はしたくないね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>deer</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Kagoshima Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are part on'yomi, part kun'yomi, but you should know them all if you look at them one by one. Just remember that <jp>児</jp> is read as <jp>ご</jp> here. Go, Kagoshima Prefecture! Go!
Context 1-EN: I drove on the most bumpy road I’ve ever driven on in Kagoshima Prefecture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>鹿児島県で、今までで運転した中で一番デッコボコの道路をドライブしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>elephant</kanji> <kanji>tusk</kanji> is the material known as <vocabulary>ivory</vocabulary> (or just an <vocabulary>elephant tusk</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I switched out my name stamp for an expensive ivory one.
Context 1-JP: <jp>印鑑を高級な象牙の物に変えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I will <kanji>accept</kanji> and I have <kanji>agreement</kanji> in the matter. I have come to <vocabulary>acceptance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Koichi reluctantly agreed to become the president of the United States.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチはアメリカ合衆国の大統領になることを渋々受諾した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have my <kanji>consent</kanji> and <kanji>agreement</kanji>. This is my <vocabulary>consent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My father agreed to our marriage without hesitation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は、私達の結婚を二つ返事で承諾した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>降参</jp> is "surrender" so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to surrender</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the same as <jp>降参</jp> as well, of course.
Context 1-EN: Haven’t you ever thought about surrendering, even once?
Context 1-JP: <jp>降参しようと思ったことは今まで一度もないんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>暮らす</jp> is "to live" or "to live one's life," then to live one's life as <jp>一人</jp>, means you are <vocabulary>living alone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the vocab readings from <jp>一人</jp> and <jp>暮らす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m living alone and I forgot to set my clock back an hour when the winter time started.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一人暮らしをしているので、冬時間が始まった時に、時計を一時間遅らせることを忘れてしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>he</kanji> <kanji>woman</kanji> is <vocabulary>she</vocabulary>. Also could mean <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>, depending on how it's used.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is a bit weird, at least for the <jp>彼</jp> portion. Just think about how <vocabulary>she</vocabulary> (your <vocabulary>girlfriend</vocabulary>) is a <reading>canoe</reading> (<jp>かの</jp>), and you love that canoe girlfriend more than anything. She is your best friend and your lover, and everyone thinks you're weird. Imagine everyone thinking you're weird as you give kisses to your canoe girlfriend.
Context 1-EN: She has good taste in clothes, but she doesn’t have the best figure.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は服のセンスはいいが、体型がいまいちだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An "examination hell" is the nickname given to the exams you have to take in Japan all at once. That's why this is <vocabulary>exam hell</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that smooshes two previous vocabulary words together into a new one. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Studying on the train is common for Japanese students who suffer from exam hell.
Context 1-JP: <jp>試験地獄に苦しむ日本の学生にとっては、電車で勉強するのは当たり前のことです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sweet</kanji> <kanji>vinegar</kanji> is <vocabulary>sweet vinegar</vocabulary>. Them Japanese love their sweet things.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>甘い</jp> plus <jp>酢</jp>, combined together. It's the kun'yomi readings, but that's probably because we're combing two words into one. It also changes the <jp>す</jp> to <jp>ず</jp> so, remember that.
Context 1-EN: During lunch the other day for some reason one of the students pulled a bottle of sweet vinegar out of her desk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この間、給食の時に生徒が何故か机の中から甘酢の瓶を取り出したのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're <kanji>boat</kanji> <kanji>drunk</kanji> you have <vocabulary>sea sickness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>船</jp> goes to <jp>ふな</jp> (probably because you're sick and can't spell). The <jp>酔い</jp> comes from <jp>酔う</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I got over my seasickness with this medicine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この薬で船酔いを克服しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>exhausted</kanji> by all the <kanji>evil</kanji> things in your life you might die of <vocabulary>exhaustion</vocabulary>!

Context 1-EN: It seems that the local economy will not recover from impoverishment unless the population increases.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人口が増えない限り、地方経済の疲弊が回復することはないでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fueling</kanji> (<jp>給油</jp>) <kanji>place</kanji> is a place where you get things fueled. This can either be a <vocabulary>gas station</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>filling station</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>きゅうゆじょ</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>きゅうゆしょ</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: きゅうゆじょ,きゅうゆしょ
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning: To Compensate For,To Make Up For
Meaning Mnemonic: To make <kanji>reparation</kanji> is <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to make up for</vocabulary>. Take responsibility for your actions and make up for everything.
Reading Mnemonic: When you go <vocabulary>to compensate for</vocabulary> what you did, you become too good for your own britches. You are <reading>too good now</reading> (<jp>つぐなう</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Even if you atoned for your sins with your own death, it wouldn’t solve the problem.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たとえあなたが死をもって罪を償っても、問題は解決しないでしょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something begins to <kanji>crumble</kanji> and <kanji>break</kanji>, it will certainly <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary> at some point. It just can't hold up under the pressure.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My poop was so big this morning that the bathroom floor collapsed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝の俺のクソが大き過ぎて、トイレの床が崩壊したんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We are <kanji>versus</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji> (that side). We need to switch things around on that side, and we need <vocabulary>to counter</vocabulary> them now that it's our turn.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I completely failed to see the oncoming motorcycle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>対向するバイクの存在を完璧に見落としていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>anti</kanji> something and you <kanji>confront</kanji> the government about it, in some cases you are going <vocabulary>to rebel</vocabulary> against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The dog was hostile towards me, so I screamed at him, "You are a bad dog!"
Context 1-JP: <jp>犬が私に反抗したので、「お前は悪い犬だ！」って叱りつけてやりましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>evil</kanji> <kanji>damage</kanji> you do has an <vocabulary>evil effect</vocabulary> on people. All that negativity can have a really <vocabulary>harmful influence</vocabulary> on them. You should think before you do things.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You should also think about how evil it is to not let children play video games.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子供にゲームをさせないことによる弊害も考えておくべきです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>貨幣</jp> is "<kanji>currency</kanji>" and <jp>価値</jp> is "<kanji>value</kanji>." This shows the <vocabulary>currency value</vocabulary>. Hopefully it's good for you when you visit Japan!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Context 1-JP: <jp>その時からどれぐらい貨幣価値が変わったか、知っているかい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>war</kanji> <kanji>struggle</kanji> is the part in war where you have to struggle at each other. This is a <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Actually, ninjas try to avoid combat as much as possible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>実際のところ、忍者は直接戦闘することをできるだけ避けた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Create</kanji> a <kanji>garden</kanji>? You'll have to know a lot about <vocabulary>landscape gardening</vocabulary>.
