Meaning Mnemonic: You must <kanji>struggle</kanji> with <kanji>intention</kanji>. You know you're going to win this way. Show your <vocabulary>fighting spirit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The battle robot was full of fighting spirit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その戦闘ロボットは、メラメラと闘志を燃やしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of <jp>香</jp>, making it have the same meaning, <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary> you smell is somebody's <reading><jp>顔</jp></reading> (<jp>かお</jp>). Just imagine smelling the fragrance of a bunch of people's faces. Yum!
Context 1-EN: It is hard to choose which perfume to wear. It takes me at least an hour every morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どの香りを付けるかを決めるのは難しいですね。毎朝短くとも一時間はそれに時間を費やします。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fragrance</kanji> <kanji>harbor</kanji>, perhaps this is where the perfumes came from back in the day. This place is <vocabulary>Hong Kong</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you might expect. Try to use the meaning mnemonic to get the meaning, then know that it sounds something similar to the reading. "Hon(g) Kon(g)" goes to <reading><jp>ほんこん</jp></reading>. Almost the same, right?
Context 1-EN: I’ll be in Hong Kong at the start of the week for a business trip.
Context 1-JP: <jp>週の前半は出張で香港にいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>burial</kanji>, so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to bury</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to inter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: We're going <vocabulary>to bury</vocabulary> you, so this is your new <reading>home</reading> (<jp>ほうむ</jp>) now, friend.
Context 1-EN: I’m worried that the truth of the incident might be buried.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その事件の真相が闇に葬られるのではないかと心配しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A trade (<jp>貿易</jp>) company (<jp>会社</jp>) is a company that makes a lot of trades, because it's easy for them, making this word a <vocabulary>trading firm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for the <jp>易</jp> portion is a bit weird. Just think about how this one trade firm only trades in train <reading>station</reading>s (<jp>えき</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Over 300 people applied for the position at the trading firm, but it looks like none of them were hired.
Context 1-JP: <jp>三百人以上の人がその貿易会社の職に応募したが、誰も採用されなかったそうだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>burial</kanji> is when you burn the body. You call this <vocabulary>cremation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The cremation system doesn’t shut down automatically. The person in charge checks how the bones are doing from a small window once in a while and stops it when they think it’s done.
Context 1-JP: <jp>火葬のシステムは自動的に停止する訳ではありません。係の人が小窓から骨の様子を見ながら、終わったと思う時に止めるのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>burial</kanji> <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is a <vocabulary>funeral</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If anyone calls, say I’m at a funeral and will be back at three o’clock.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし誰かから電話があったら、葬式に出ていて三時に戻ると伝えてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>dance</kanji> of going to <kanji>see</kanji> someone. It's a <vocabulary>sympathy visit</vocabulary>. Because, you know, you gotta dance the dance of sympathy.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. <jp>舞い</jp> comes from <jp>舞う</jp>.
Context 1-EN: When I visited her in the hospital, her room was decorated with many flowers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>病院にお見舞いに行くと、彼女の部屋はたくさんの花で飾られていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>一般</jp> is "general"/"common" then something that has <jp>的</jp> attached to it is <vocabulary>ordinary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>normal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>common</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>一般</jp> plus <jp>的</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Continuing to live in your parents’ home after graduating from college is pretty common in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大学卒業後も実家に住み続けることは、日本ではそこそこ一般的です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>general</kanji>-<kanji>al</kanji>! It's super general. It's <vocabulary>general</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>overall</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>across the board</vocabulary>. Nothing specific going on here.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Dogs are generally scared of cats, aren’t they?
Context 1-JP: <jp>全般的に、犬は猫を怖がるものじゃないんですかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>open sea</kanji> <kanji>rope</kanji> is the rope that attaches <vocabulary>Okinawa</vocabulary> to the mainland.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, put together.
Context 1-EN: I am not sure when my daughter will be back from Okinawa because she likes it there so much.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの娘は沖縄が大好きで、一体いつ戻ってくるのかさっぱり分かりません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To "do maintenance (<jp>維持</jp>)" is keeping something in that maintained position, which is <vocabulary>to maintain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the reading from the vocabulary you learned earlier. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You should do some exercises to maintain your health.
Context 1-JP: <jp>健康を維持するために、何か運動をする方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Rely On,To Trust,To Depend On
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>頼む</jp> is "to ask for" or "to request." This word is <vocabulary>to rely on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to trust</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to depend on</vocabulary>. You know it is this word because it is <reading>ru</reading>de to rely on your friends, but you are anyways.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit different from <jp>頼む</jp>, however. It's <jp>たよ</jp>, because you go to rely on your friends so much they become <reading>tiyored</reading> (<jp>たよ</jp>). They say "tired" like that, for some reason.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been wondering if I should trust him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の事を頼っていいものか決めかねています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>demand</kanji> and <kanji>need</kanji> this thing, which is why you must make this <vocabulary>demand</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Tofugu t-shirts may be in high demand, but their cost performance isn’t great.
Context 1-JP: <jp>TofuguTシャツは需要は大きいかもしれないけど、コスパがあまり良くないんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>馬鹿</jp> is "stupid" so if you hear a rumor about something (<jp>らしい</jp>) that's stupid, you'll just respond by saying "that's <vocabulary>absurd</vocabulary>."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>馬鹿</jp>.
Context 1-EN: That’s completely absurd!!!
Context 1-JP: <jp>全く馬鹿らしいにもほどがある！！！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> of <kanji>tall</kanji> <kanji>age</kanji> is going to be an <vocabulary>elderly person</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>old person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Elderly people have difficult problems with employment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>高齢者たちは、雇用について難しい問題を抱えています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you are at an <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>age</kanji> you are at an <vocabulary>old age</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Could you please explain the structure of Japan’s old-age pension to me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本の老齢年金の仕組みについてご説明してもらえませんでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>age</kanji> is the number of <vocabulary>years old</vocabulary> you are.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: "How old are you?" "I’d rather not say." "Okay, then. Just let me know if you are older than 100."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「年齢はおいくつですか？」「あまり言いたくないです。」「じゃあ、別にいいよ。ただ、百歳を超えてるかどうかだけ教えてくれない？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To do <kanji>pregnant</kanji> <kanji>pregnant</kanji> is <vocabulary>to be pregnant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She got a urine pregnancy test done and the doctor told her that she is pregnant.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は尿で妊娠反応検査をして、お医者さんから妊娠していると言われました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I <kanji>dodge</kanji>d being <kanji>pregnant</kanji>. Whew. Good thing I was taking my <vocabulary>birth control</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: One of my New Year’s resolutions is to properly use contraception.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の新年の抱負の一つは、ちゃんと避妊をすること、です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You do <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>do</kanji> and I'll do another do. I'll do the same thing <vocabulary>to match</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The <jp>いち</jp> is shortened to <jp>いっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The fingerprints left on the fake bacon matched Mami’s.
Context 1-JP: <jp>偽のベーコンに残された指紋は、マミのものと一致しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pregnant</kanji> <kanji>wife</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pregnant woman</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I got a temporary job as a counselor for pregnant women.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妊婦さんのためのカウンセラーという、臨時の仕事が見つかりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>do</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary>. This is a polite way to say "to do."
Reading Mnemonic: What are you going <vocabulary>to do</vocabulary>? You're going to become a professional <reading>eater</reading> (<jp>いた</jp>), because you like to do eating a lot, and you are very polite about your eating despite how fast you eat in these competitions.
Context 1-EN: I’ll guide you around the city, if you’d like.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしよろしければ私が町をご案内致しますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>edition</kanji> will <kanji>go</kanji> out to the public if we were <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Mami asked Aya to publish a bacon magazine with her.
Context 1-JP: <jp>マミはアヤに、ベーコン雑誌を一緒に刊行しないかと尋ねた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accompany</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to accompany</vocabulary>. This can be used both literally and figuratively.
Reading Mnemonic: You need to accompany your friend, so to call out to them you yell "友!" (ともなう) to command them to come near you to accompany you to somewhere else.
Context 1-EN: As technology advanced, people grew less and less concerned about the environment.
Context 1-JP: <jp>技術の進歩に伴って人々は自然環境にだんだん関心がなくなってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>evening</kanji> <kanji>edition</kanji> is the <vocabulary>evening edition</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The evening edition of every newspaper reported the stock market crash as their front page story.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どの新聞の夕刊でも、株式市場の大暴落が一面記事で報じられた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Play music</kanji> that will give me <kanji>comfort</kanji>, why then I should go see a <vocabulary>musical performance</vocabulary> to keep me nice and calm.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you have a musical handbell for around 1000 yen?
Context 1-JP: <jp>千円くらいの、奏楽用のハンドベルはありますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>contrary</kanji>... this is the te-form version of contrary, meaning you're starting to say something, making this <vocabulary>on the contrary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is like <jp>変える</jp>, which is to change. So, if you change what the other person is saying to another way, then you're saying you're changing things. It has the same reading, so remember it that way.
Context 1-EN: I just wanted to do the right thing but instead it backfired and I just stressed my friend out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>善かれと思ってしたことが、却って仇となって友人のストレスになってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It is <kanji>contrary</kanji> to what I think is good. It is <kanji>below</kanji> my standards. Thus, <vocabulary>rejection</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My idea for all of the Tofugu members to bungee jump was quickly rejected.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguメンバー全員がバンジージャンプに挑戦するというアイディアは、速攻で却下されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'll <kanji>think</kanji> and <kanji>consider</kanji> this. I'll give it <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Please consider your own family instead of mine.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の家族ではなく自分の家族のことを考慮してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>distribute</kanji> your <kanji>consider</kanji>s, you will be giving <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>care</vocabulary> to whatever you're distributing these cares to.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Mom, don’t you think that adults lack consideration for kids?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お母さん、大人って子供への配慮が欠けていると思わない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>interior</kanji> person (the honorific <jp>さん</jp> shows it's a person) is the person who stands in the interior of the house and doesn't leave, making that person your <vocabulary>wife</vocabulary>. Ouch. Sexist kanji strikes again.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji.
Context 1-EN: "What kind of person is your wife?" "She’s the type that does everything energetically."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「おまえの奥さんって、どんな人？」「彼女は何でもバリバリやるタイプだよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>suspend</kanji>, but in this case, you're going to suspend your win or loss and try <vocabulary>to stake</vocabulary> it all on one, big bet. You're going <vocabulary>to risk</vocabulary> it all!
Reading Mnemonic: You decide <vocabulary>to risk</vocabulary> it all and bet everything on your <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>). If you lose, you lose the car, but if you win, then you were right to stake it all on this.
Context 1-EN: Do you have something to put your life on the line for?
Context 1-JP: <jp>何か命を懸けるほどのものはありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: "How many things are in this <vocabulary>cluster</vocabulary>?" asks your boss. "Just a <reading>few sah</reading>," (<jp>ふさ</jp>) you reply.
Context 1-EN: I bought three bunches of grape for 298 yen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この葡萄、三房で298円だったんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>draw</kanji> a <kanji>drawing</kanji> or <kanji>painting</kanji>, you will end up with a <vocabulary>drawing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>painting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Claude Monet was very good at stippling, which is a bit different from pointillism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クロード・モネは、点画法という、点描画法とは少し違った技法を得意としていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Draw</kanji> a <kanji>copy</kanji> of the world and you are making a <vocabulary>depiction</vocabulary> of the world.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Aya drew a detailed depiction of the Tofugu murder case.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アヤは、Tofugu殺人事件を細部に渡って描写した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>cluster</kanji> is something that has a cluster of cool-creating coolant. This device is <vocabulary>air conditioning</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It's too hot. Could you turn on the air conditioning please?
Context 1-JP: <jp>暑すぎだよ〜。ちょっと冷房付けてもらえないかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>handle</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to handle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually! Can you handle that?
Context 1-EN: My step child treats me like I’m a stranger and it really stresses me out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夫の連れ子にまるで他人の用に扱われて、すごくストレスが溜まります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I want to <kanji>suppress</kanji> and <kanji>pressure</kanji> you! Muahaha! This is <vocabulary>oppression</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It took the police a while to suppress the riot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察は、その暴動を抑圧するのにしばらく時間がかかりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>versus</kanji> (compare) the <kanji>title</kanji> of these two things, you'll notice that they're the same as each other. They have <vocabulary>symmetry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m thinking of getting a short asymmetrical haircut called "ashime."
Context 1-JP: <jp>アシメっていう左右非対称のショートカットにしてみようかなって思ってるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>loose</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>loose</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so feel nice and loose and move on to the next item.
Context 1-EN: The neck of this shirt is pretty loose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このシャツは首回りが緩いんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>title</kanji> is the title one person gives themselves. They are speaking in the <vocabulary>first person</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This horror movie was shot from the first-person perspective.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このホラー映画は、一人称の視点から撮影されています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>consign</kanji> something to someone, you are going <vocabulary>to entrust</vocabulary> them with that item. Here you go, I entrust you.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is unusual, but I will entrust you with the knowledge of why to help you remember it! This uses the the on'yomi reading and not the kun'yomi, as you might expect, because the <jp>す</jp> here is the old-fashioned version of the verb <jp>する</jp>. Luckily, you learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so it's unusual but hopefully not too hard!
Context 1-EN: It was a mistake to entrust all the pictures to that detective.
Context 1-JP: <jp>探偵を託して写真を全部渡したのが間違いでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>loose</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to loosen</vocabulary>. This is when something loosens on its own, and not via your actions. You know this because a cow is loosening things, <reading>moo</reading> (<jp>む</jp>)...
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
Context 1-EN: Some of the bolts in the tunnel are coming loose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのトンネルのボルトは、何本か緩んできています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To the <kanji>committee</kanji> I would like to <kanji>consign</kanji> these things. This is what I <vocabulary>consign</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He says that he did blindfold the guy, but entrusted the rest of the murder to the other assassin.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そいつがさ、男の目隠しまではしたけど、残りの殺人業務は他の暗殺者に委託したって言うんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the na-adjective version of <kanji>loose</kanji>, so that means this word means <vocabulary>loose</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from what you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The stream curves gently towards the east and is a good fishing spot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その小川が緩やかに東にカーブしているところがあるんだけど、そこが釣りの穴場なんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>presents</kanji> you <kanji>acquire</kanji> are a <kanji>bribe</kanji>. What? That is <vocabulary>bribery</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When I was three my father taught me to say, "I have nothing to do with the bribery case," to my mother.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父は、私が三歳の時に、「その贈収賄事件には私は関与していない」と母に言うように教えた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>accept</kanji> and <kanji>consign</kanji> the job. You are going to <vocabulary>be entrusted with</vocabulary> this property for the winter. Don't go into room 237.

Meaning: To Repeat,To Repeat Over And Over
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>繰る</jp> is "to spin" (so spinning) and <jp>返す</jp> is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this <vocabulary>to repeat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to repeat over and over</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>繰る</jp> and <jp>返す</jp>. Combine them together to get the reading.

It's a word you'll see a lot to varying degrees of kanji and length.

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>chant</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to chant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Really, when you are going <vocabulary>to chant</vocabulary>, the most important thing to do is to figure out your <reading>tone</reading> (<jp>とな</jp>). If you get the tone down, the rest  comes naturally.

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>concurrently</kanji>, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "<vocabulary>to combine</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>to double as</vocabulary>." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.
Reading Mnemonic: For example, a <reading>ca</reading>r (<jp>か</jp>) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.
Context 1-EN: I prefer to have a kitchen-cum-living room if possible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>できれば台所と居間を兼ねるような部屋がある方がいいなぁ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>楽</jp> was used in <jp>音楽</jp> and meant "music?" Well this is that <jp>楽</jp> again. <kanji>Music</kanji> made with a <kanji>bowstring</kanji> is <vocabulary>string music</vocabulary>.

To remember it, just think about how much <vocabulary>consideration</vocabulary> you're always showing. You're always like "<reading>Yah</reading> (<jp>や</jp>), yah, no, I totally understand. SOOO sad." /end sympathy/

Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

Context 1-JP: <jp>私の一番好きな日本の諺は、「身を殺して仁を成す」です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>again</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> <kanji>room</kanji> is a <vocabulary>changing room</vocabulary>. You get to change again, even after changing in the morning for the first time to leave your house. This can also be a <vocabulary>locker room</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>dressing room</vocabulary>, so really anywhere you can change that's not your home, usually.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m in the dressing room looking for her locker now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今更衣室であの女のロッカーを探しているところよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mineral</kanji> <kanji>stone</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ore</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>mineral</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of the kanji, you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Every mineral he touches turns to gold.
Context 1-JP: <jp>どんな鉱石でも、彼が触ると金に変わってしまうのさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mineral</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mineral</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is the best mineral I’ve ever seen. Nothing can match it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは今までで最高の鉱物さ。これに敵うものはないね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Charcoal</kanji> <kanji>mineral</kanji> has been found! Time to dig a <vocabulary>coal mine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>coal pit</vocabulary> to retrieve it!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Well, it is really disappointing that this coal mine is going to be closed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うーん。この炭鉱が閉山するってのは、本当に残念ですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji it should use the kun'yomi reading (which is the reading you learned with the kanji).
Context 1-EN: Coil the thread here, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>糸は、ここにまいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you believe in the red string of fate?
Context 2-JP: <jp>うんめいの赤い糸をしんじますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I used a needle and thread to stitch up the gash in my leg.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は足の傷口を縫うのに針と糸を使った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji. This is probably because this word gets attached to numbers usually, which makes it behave more like jukugo. So, you can have <jp>１回</jp>, <jp>２回</jp>, <jp>３回</jp>, or even <jp>１００回</jp> if you're into that sort of thing.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been to Japan once.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本に一回行ったことがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've made plans to swim from America to Japan, but they've been put on hold eight different times now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカから日本までおよいでわたるけいかくを立てたが、もう八回ほどと中で中止になっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t count the number of times I’ve eaten sand.
Context 3-JP: <jp>何回砂を食べたか自分でも数えきれないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look outside, it's totally frozen. You throw <reading>salt</reading> (<jp>そと</jp>) outside to melt the ice.
Context 1-EN: Let’s wait outside.
Context 1-JP: <jp>外でまちましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The cats are staring at the bird outside of the window.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ねこたちは、まどの外にいるとりをジーッとみています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I kept yawning outside all day today.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日は一日中外であくびをしていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If it's <kanji>certain</kanji> that you will <kanji>attain</kanji> it, then it is <vocabulary>inevitable</vocabulary>. It is a <vocabulary>foregone</vocabulary> conclusion.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think it’s necessary to teach kids sex education at some point, but how do people usually teach those things in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもへの性教育はある時期では必至になると思うんですが、日本はそうした教育については通常どのように行われるんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The "things" (<jp>こと</jp>) I do with my "ma" (<jp>ま</jp>) are always supported by <vocabulary>sincerity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary>. I am always sincere with my mom. That's why the things I do with ma are always sincere. I have a name for this, it is <reading>ma </reading> (<jp>まこと</jp>), because with ma, sincerity is the most important thing to do.
Context 1-EN: I’m sincerely upset that the judge accepted his plea of not guilty by reason of insanity.
Context 1-JP: <jp>裁判官が彼の心神喪失による刑事責任能力の回避の申し立てを受け入れたことは、誠に遺憾です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>pleasure</kanji>? Well, you could say it's "pleasurable," but I'm afraid that's not what we're going for here. In this case, this word is a little more innocent. It just means <vocabulary>fun</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How much <vocabulary>fun</vocabulary> did you have? You just had a <reading>ton o'</reading> (<jp>たの</jp>) fun!
Context 1-EN: This game is really fun and interesting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このゲームは、とても楽しくて、おも白いです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's more fun to eat while watching TV than it is to eat while chatting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>テレビを見ながら食べる方が、しゃべりながら食べるより楽しいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Jumping out of an airplane is so much fun!
Context 3-JP: <jp>飛行機から飛び降りるって、物凄く楽しいよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>moon</kanji> <kanji>see</kanji> something, you're doing a <vocabulary>moon viewing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. For <jp>見</jp> you already learned the kun'yomi reading when you learned the kanji. For <jp>月</jp> you'll have to think back to the vocab word <jp>月</jp> which uses the <jp>つき</jp> reading. Combine these two together and you have <reading><jp>つきみ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I’m making rice dumplings for moon viewing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>月見のおだん子をつくっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am planning to have a moon viewing party with my friends tonight.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日のよる、友人たちと、お月見をするよていです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My grandpa passed away from choking on a mochi cake on a moon viewing day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>そ父は、月見の日に餅でのどを詰まらせて死にました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>hometown</kanji> <kanji>home village</kanji> is the one that's your <vocabulary>hometown</vocabulary>. It's also your <vocabulary>birthplace</vocabulary>, where you were born.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>郷</jp> is the one you learned, but the reading for <jp>里</jp> isn't the one you learned. To remember this reading, just think about how your <vocabulary>birthplace</vocabulary> is the place you were <reading>rea</reading>red (<jp>り</jp>), and you <reading>rea</reading>lly (<jp>り</jp>) miss the place.
Context 1-EN: Visiting my hometown is a waste of time and money.
Context 1-JP: <jp>郷里を訪れるのはお金と時間の無駄です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a noun version of <kanji>think</kanji>. What is "a think"? It's a <vocabulary>thought</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading with <jp>考える</jp>, just cut off the <jp>る</jp>!
Context 1-EN: I can never explain my own thoughts well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつも自分の考えを上手くせつめいできません。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたの考えはあますぎます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Can I buy your thoughts for 100 yen?
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの考えを百円で買わせてもらえませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have really <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>guts</kanji> you're a super <vocabulary>bold</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>daring</vocabulary> person. In fact, you might even be superman. That's how big your guts are. Don't worry, I don't tell anyone I know who you are. It'll be our little secret.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The group is bold to commit crimes in broad daylight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>グループは、大胆にも真っ昼間から犯行に及んだのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>older sister</kanji> and your <kanji>younger sister</kanji>. These are your <vocabulary>sisters</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Those two sisters look so alike.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二人の姉妹はとてもよくにています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hey, you two kinda look like sisters.
Context 2-JP: <jp>何か、二人って姉妹みたいだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There is a bond between sisters that isn’t shared between girls who are just friends.
Context 3-JP: <jp>単なる女友達には無い絆が、姉妹の間にはある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have your <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>. Part of your self is you. This is <vocabulary>oneself</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>myself</vocabulary>. Wait, who is this part of me? You're not sure... wait, no, it's myself. Is it? Be a little psychotic for a moment as you try to remember this vocab word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I finished the homework perfectly all by myself.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちゃんと自分でしゅくだいをしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That's the color you can only choose if you are confident with yourself, isn't it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>自分に自しんがないとえらべない色だよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Of course I talk to myself. Sometimes I need expert advice.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もちろん私は自分と話しますよ。だって、時には専門家の意見が必要ですもの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the reading for the vocab.
Context 1-EN: This summer is hotter than last year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の夏は、さく年よりもあついです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to go buy some summer dresses sometime soon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>近いうちに夏ワンピをかいに行きたいんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Summer is only good for three things. Movies, video games, and duck carving.
Context 3-JP: <jp>夏にして楽しいことは三つだけだ。映画、ビデオゲーム、それから木彫の鴨を作ること。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It turns out she is a <vocabulary>fake</vocabulary>. Your <reading>niece</reading> (<jp>にせ</jp>) was a robot this whole time, just pretending to be your niece. What is wrong with this world, where your niece can be an <vocabulary>imitation</vocabulary> niece. A <jp>偽</jp>niece, if you will.
Context 1-EN: What benefit is there to telling everyone this forged document isn’t a forged document?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして俺が偽札を偽札じゃないということが皆の為になるのさ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>two hundred</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please preheat the oven to two hundred degrees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>オーブンを、二百どによねつしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got two hundred likes on Facebook.
Context 2-JP: <jp>フェイスブックで二百もいいねをもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I gave the cashier two hundred dollars and told her to buy some deodorant.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕は、レジの人に二百ドルをあげて、これで制汗剤を買うように言いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji> is someone else's hands (or just someone else, if you remembered that <jp>手</jp> can also refer to a person as well). Whose hands are these? These are your <vocabulary>partner</vocabulary>'s hands. That's why everything is mutual.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For <jp>手</jp>, that's no problem for you. For <jp>相</jp>, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way: Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: <reading>I</reading> (<jp>あい</jp>) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."
Context 1-EN: First, you will listen closely to what your partner has to say.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まずは、相手の話をちゃんときいてあげようよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: According to my fortune, my future partner is a prince in some country. I wonder if it's true.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うらないによると、わたしのけっこん相手はどこかの国の王子さまだそうです。本当かな？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t want a stupid talking companion.
Context 3-JP: <jp>馬鹿な話し相手は欲しくない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some <kanji>fake</kanji> <kanji>attire</kanji> doesn't make you look fake, it makes you disappear. This fake attire is fake surroundings. So, if you're in a shrub, it's shrub attire. If you're in the darkness, it's dark attire. This is <vocabulary>camouflage</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My uncle was arrested for disguising his products with false labels and is currently in prison.
Context 1-JP: <jp>伯父は、自社製品の表示を偽装して逮捕され、現在は刑務所にいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is the <kanji>neck</kanji> of your <kanji>leg</kanji>? Think about it. It's your <vocabulary>ankle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from both kanji, probably because it includes body parts. You know the kun'yomi reading of <jp>足</jp> from previous vocab and you know the kun'yomi reading of <jp>首</jp> from learning that kanji. So, you should be able to read this kanji so long as you remember that it's all kun'yomi.
Context 1-EN: I twisted my ankle.
Context 1-JP: <jp>足首をひねってしまいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My right ankle hurts a lot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>右の足首がすごくいたいんです！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I sprained my ankle while running away from a feather floating in the air.
Context 3-JP: <jp>宙に舞う羽から逃げる途中で、足首を捻挫した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Let's <kanji>create</kanji> a <kanji>fake</kanji>. This fake we've created? It's a <vocabulary>forgery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Two kinds of fake bills started floating around in Tokyo on the very same day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全く同じ日に、二種類の偽造紙幣が東京で出回り出しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>buy</kanji> so the verb form is <vocabulary>to buy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be just fine.
Context 1-EN: I want to buy toilet paper, meat, vegetables, and soy sauce on the same day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トイレットペーパーと肉とやさいとしょうゆを同じ日に買いたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why did you end up buying the smartphone?
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうしてそのスマホを買うことにしたんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: There was a long line of people waiting to buy the Koichi bobblehead.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチのボブルヘッド人形を買うために、長い行列ができていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: Please take the red shoes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その赤のくつをとってください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I’m thinking of dyeing my bangs red next time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>つぎは、まえがみのいろを赤にしようとおもっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My cheeks still go red when I hear the name Orlando Bloom.
Context 3-JP: <jp>オーランド・ブルームという名前を聞くだけで、今でも頬が赤くなる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>駆ける</jp> is "to gallop" and <jp>出す</jp> is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going <vocabulary>to rush out</vocabulary> a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>駆ける</jp> and <jp>出す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: When I asked him a question he just ran off.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼に質問を尋ねた時、駆け出しただけだ。 </jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>school</kanji> is obviously a place where people study and learn. In English, that's simply a <vocabulary>school</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This jukugo word consists of on'yomi readings, except <jp>学</jp> (<jp>がく</jp>) is shortened with a small <jp>っ</jp> to make it <reading><jp>がっこう</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I go to school on foot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは歩いて学校に行っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have to submit an absentee notice to my school, so can I have one, please?
Context 2-JP: <jp>学校にてい出するので、ちえんしょう明しょを下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why are we barbecuing hot dogs at school during class today?
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日はどうして学校で授業中にホットドッグをバーベキューするの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>location</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is either a <vocabulary>place</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>location</vocabulary>, just like the kanji it's made from.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for the first kanji and the on'yomi reading for the second. You haven't learned this reading for <jp>場</jp> yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is this <vocabulary>place</vocabulary> you're in? You look around and listen. You hear, "<reading>Baa</reading> (<jp>ば</jp>) baa baa!" You must be in a <reading>ba</reading>rn!
Context 1-EN: Usually we gather in the classroom, but the location is different tomorrow, so make sure you don’t go to the wrong place.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いつもは教室にあつまりますが、明日は場所がちがうので、まちがえないでくださいね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You should know your own battlefield.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自分がたたかうべき場所をきちんと知っておくべきだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This is the place where I first met Rose. But, I forget why I took my shoes off that day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この場所は私が初めてローズに会った場所です。でも、あの日どうして靴を脱いだのかは思い出せません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>遮断</jp> means "isolation?" Well the <kanji>machine</kanji> that isolates you from a train is a <vocabulary>crossing gate</vocabulary>. That way you won't walk, bike, or drive your car into an oncoming train.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When the railroad crossing gate comes down, do not cross the tracks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>遮断機が降りている時に、線路を渡ってはいけません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <jp>駆ける</jp> is "to gallop." <jp>回る</jp> is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going <vocabulary>to run around</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>駆ける</jp> and <jp>回る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The recipe said to put in saffron, so I ran around searching for it everywhere, but I couldn’t find any, so I didn’t add saffron this time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>レシピにサフランがいるって書いてあったから、あちこち駆け回って探したんだけど見つからなくて、結局今回はサフランは使わなかったの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's been <kanji>decide</kanji>d and <kanji>determine</kanji>d. The <vocabulary>decision</vocabulary> has been made.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to take note of the shortened <jp>けつ</jp> in <jp>決</jp>. It goes to <jp>けっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: They’ve decided to turn the Kumaman manga into an anime!
Context 1-JP: <jp>クママンまんがの、アニメ化が決定しました！</jp>
Context 2-EN: This will be your final decision and it can't be changed later. Is that okay?
Context 2-JP: <jp>これはさいしゅう決定になりますので、その後の変更はできませんが、よろしいでしょうか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll leave the decision of whether we’re going to attend your little sister’s wedding or my mother’s funeral to you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君の妹の結婚式と俺の母さんの葬式、どちらに出席するかの決定は君に任せるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>不孝</jp> is "disobedience to parents"? Well, <kanji>someone</kanji> who shows <kanji>disobedience to parents</kanji> is a <vocabulary>disobedient child</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>unfilial child</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <jp>不孝</jp> is a reading you should know already. Add the <jp>もの</jp> reading for <jp>者</jp> and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.
Context 1-EN: My mother called me a "disobedient child."
Context 1-JP: <jp>母に「不孝者」と呼ばれた。 </jp>

Meaning: Lack Of Filial Piety,Disobedience To Parents
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>不孝</jp> means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add <kanji>parent</kanji>s to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means <vocabulary>lack of filial piety</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>disobedience to parents</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>不孝</jp> is the one you learned. Then, add <jp>親</jp>'s reading (vocab) to it.
Context 1-EN: It’s already too late, but I was a really disobedient son.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もう手遅れですが、私は本当に親不孝な息子でしたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>write down</kanji> your <kanji>day</kanji> (and do it every day) that's your <vocabulary>diary</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This jukugo word uses the on'yomi readings, except the <jp>日</jp> (<jp>にち</jp>) is shortened with a small <jp>っ</jp>, making the reading <jp>にっき</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to leave your diary with this book here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたの日記も、この本と一しょにここにおいておきます。 </jp>
Context 2-EN: We don't have a culture of diary exchange in North America.
Context 2-JP: <jp>北米には、こうかん日記みたいな文化はないんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I read Fugu’s journal last night and, to be honest, it was really sad.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日の夜、フグの日記を読んだんだけどさ、実はとても悲しい日記だったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji> there's a lot of people together. Why would you have a bunch of people gather together? Probably for a <vocabulary>convention</vocabulary> or some kind of competition or <vocabulary>tournament</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I am participating in the soccer tournament on Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日よう日は、サッカーの大会に出じょうします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: At fireworks events, ice cream sells well.
Context 2-JP: <jp>花火大会では、アイスクリームがよく売れます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I won the marathon because I couldn’t stop farting and all the other runners slowed down whenever they smelled them.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私がマラソン大会で優勝したのは、オナラを止めることができず、他のランナーがその臭いを嗅ぐたびにペースを落としていったからだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>What</kanji> <kanji>thousand</kanji>? Could be five thousand, two thousand, or ten thousand, since you're asking. Let's generalize. How do you say all of those amounts at the same time? You say "<vocabulary>thousands</vocabulary>."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just take note that <jp>千</jp> is read as <jp>ぜん</jp> and not <jp>せん</jp> because of rendaku.
Context 1-EN: I’ve practiced thousands of times.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何千回も、れんしゅうしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Suddenly, thousands of bacon strips dropped from sky.
Context 2-JP: <jp>とつぜん、何千ものベーコンがそらからふってきた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Victims of the titan attack numbered in the thousands.
Context 3-JP: <jp>巨人攻撃の被害者は、何千人にものぼった。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Utterly Amazed,To Be Stunned,To Be Amazed
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a combination of the word <jp>呆れる</jp> meaning "to be amazed" and <jp>返る</jp> meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means <vocabulary>to be utterly amazed</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a combination of the words <jp>呆れる</jp> and <jp>返る</jp>. <jp>呆れる</jp> becomes <jp>呆れ</jp> and you just add <jp>返る</jp> to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.
Context 1-EN: I was utterly amazed because the room was horribly dirty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>部屋があまりに汚かったので、呆れ返ってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who does <kanji>study</kanji> for a living. That is a <vocabulary>scholar</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: His father is a splendid scholar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれのお父さんは、立ぱな学者です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That scholar is a resume faker.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの学者はけいれきさしょうをしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am a world renowned scholar of Hello Kitty.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は世界でも有名なハロー・キティ学者です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>generations</kanji> (and society!) that make up the <kanji>world</kanji> create our world. So this is <vocabulary>the World</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>the Universe</vocabulary>. This word is used more like "the biggest dog in the world" or "the fattest cat in the world." For example, you'll hear words like <jp>世界一番</jp> (number one in the world) thrown around a lot.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: However, neither of them exist in this world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しかし、この世界にはどちらもありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mt. Fuji is registered as a World Heritage Site.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ふじ山は世界いさんにとうろくされています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He lives in his own world and doesn’t want to leave it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あいつは自分の世界に閉じこもっていて、そこから出てこようとしないんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Even though it gets <kanji>mix</kanji>ed up as it <kanji>passes through</kanji> itself, modern <vocabulary>traffic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>transport</vocabulary> systems are pretty amazing. This word refers to traffic and transport for pedestrians, bikes, cars, buses, trains, planes... anything that gets us from A to B.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Traffic accidents happen a lot here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ここでは、交通じこがよくおきるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please wear your seatbelt for traffic safety.
Context 2-JP: <jp>交通安全のためにシートベルトをしてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you take the public transit system, you should wear a mask.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こうきょう交通きかんに乗れる時はマスクをした方がいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If a <kanji>person</kanji> has a lot of <kanji>energy</kanji> then they're very charismatic and fun! What's another feature of charismatic / fun people? They are most likely <vocabulary>popular</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This beer is very popular.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このビールはとても人気があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am probing into why that doujinshi is so popular.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのどう人しの人気のひみつをさぐっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I am the most popular berry collector around here," said the bear.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私がこの辺りで一番人気の高いベリー採集者であります。」と熊が言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have <kanji>four</kanji> <kanji>hundred</kanji>s, you have <vocabulary>four hundred</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word has number four in it, and uses the kun'yomi reading for that kanji (<jp>よん</jp>). The reading for <jp>百</jp> though, is the on'yomi reading (<jp>ひゃく</jp>). This is pretty normal when it comes to words containing four in Japanese. You know both of these readings already. Hooray!
Context 1-EN: Please make four hundred copies of this document.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このしりょうを四百枚コピーしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There was an incident where 400 people went missing overnight in the city of Seattle in the US.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカのシアトル市で、一やにして四百人がしっそうするというじけんがあった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How did you spend four hundred dollars on a toothpick?
Context 3-JP: <jp>いったいどうして四百ドルも一本の爪楊枝を買うのに使ったんだい？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A company <kanji>request</kanji>s <kanji>consign</kanji>ment work and you take it to become a <vocabulary>part time employee</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That person is a part-time employee who used the reemployment system.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの人は、再雇用制度を利用した嘱託社員なんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>central</kanji>... that is really, really in the <vocabulary>center</vocabulary> if you ask me (and is very <vocabulary>central</vocabulary> as well). This is one of those "overdid it on the meaning" words.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That’s Tanaka’s older sister standing in the center.
Context 1-JP: <jp>中央に立っているのが、田中さんのおねえさんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I’m waiting for you at the central ticket gate of Osaka station.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大さかえきの、中央かいさつ口でまっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a little dent in the center of my head.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の頭の中央部分には小さな凹みがある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a <vocabulary>pair</vocabulary>, you know?
Context 1-EN: My sister and I are fraternal twins, but we look very similar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>妹と私は二卵性双生児ですが、外見がすごく似ています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>携帯</jp> means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then <jp>電話</jp> means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying <jp>携帯</jp>, making this a <vocabulary>portable phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cell phone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mobile phone</vocabulary>. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of <jp>携帯</jp> and <jp>電話</jp> for this one.
Context 1-EN: "May I use your cell phone?" "Sure, go ahead."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「あなたの携帯電話をお借りしてもいいですか？」「ええ、どうぞ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a word that's attached to the end of various other words. Think of a "road" as a <vocabulary>way</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>method of</vocabulary> something. For example, the <jp>どう</jp> in Judo is the soft "way." There are many words that end with <jp>道</jp>, and you'll see them later on. For now, know that this means <vocabulary>method of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>way</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is added to the end of many different words, meaning it's treated like most jukugo (and uses an on'yomi reading). You know the on'yomi reading, so you should be able to read this word. Be sure to drop the <jp>〜</jp> when writing in the reading in the test, though. It's only there to show that it's added onto things and not part of the correct answer.
Context 1-EN: The teacher is going to teach the rules and the methods of Judo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生が、じゅう道のルールややり方を教えます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm gonna master the way of sword in Hokkaido.
Context 2-JP: <jp>北海道で、けん道をきわめるつもりです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you please explain the difference between bushido and chivalry?
Context 3-JP: <jp>武士道と騎士道の違いについて説明してください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're part of a special <vocabulary>group</vocabulary>. It is the <reading>cumi</reading>n group, and they deal with all things cumin (the spice / seed). Smell the cumin. Touch it. Taste it. You live and breathe the stuff, because you are the president of this cumin group. P.S. This can also be spelled <jp>組み</jp> (same overall reading: <jp>くみ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: After this, we’ll be splitting into two teams.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これから、みなさんを二組に分けます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our group is famous around here.
Context 2-JP: <jp>オレたちの組はこの辺じゃ有名なんだぜ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I heard Koichi in grade 3 class 2 was asked out again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>三年二組のコウイチくん、またこく白されたらしいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>solid</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tough</vocabulary>. This "solid" and "tough" is a figurative version of the word.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The recipe calls them delicious, moist cookies, but they turned out to be really hard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>レシピには、美味しくてしっとりしたクッキーって書いてあったのに、出来上がったクッキーはすっごく堅かったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are <kanji>mourning</kanji> your <kanji>fault</kanji>. Because of your fault, you have gotten a <vocabulary>loss</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>forfeit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: In the nursing home there is an old woman who seems to have lost her memory, but she is really funny.
Context 1-JP: <jp>介護施設に、どうやら記憶喪失らしいお婆さんがいるんだけど、その人がすっごく面白いのよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You look at the floor. It's disgusting. Dirtiest and nastiest floor you've ever seen. You say <reading>yucka</reading> (<jp>ゆか</jp>) because it's covered in <reading>yucca</reading> (<jp>ゆか</jp>). Plus, it's all rotten.
Context 1-EN: I'll have to clean floor today.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は床掃除をしなければならないの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A cockroach was crawling on the floor.
Context 2-JP: <jp>床に一匹のゴキブリがはっていた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I watch TV, I usually lay on the floor with my legs crossed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>テレビを見てる時は、大抵足を組みながら床に寝転がっています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Wake up</kanji> from your <kanji>bed</kanji> and get up. You are <vocabulary>rising</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>getting out of bed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the on'yomi readings for both of these. For <jp>起</jp>, just remember how in order to get up out of bed, you have to be let out of your chains, which requires a <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>). Otherwise, you stay laying down forever.
Context 1-EN: He is still snoring even though it’s time to get out of bed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は起床時間になっても、まだいびきをかいています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What do you do in your <vocabulary>home</vocabulary>? You <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>e</reading>ggs (<jp>いえ</jp>), that's what. You eat eggs three times a day, every day. You really love eating eggs in your <vocabulary>house</vocabulary>!
Context 1-EN: Everyone, please stop by my house.
Context 1-JP: <jp>みなさん、家にあそびに来てください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You really need to clean your house.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いいかげん、家をかた付けた方がいいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Home is where the heart is. And the food.
Context 3-JP: <jp>家とは、みんなの心と食べ物がある場所です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>week</kanji> is <vocabulary>this week</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There is a lot of work to do this week.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今週は仕ごとがたくさんあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's meet up in front of the Hachiko statue at 11 a.m. this Tuesday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今週の火よう日の午前十一じに、しぶ谷のハチ公前でまち合わせをしましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This week is going to be really busy because I just bought four new video games.
Context 3-JP: <jp>新しいゲームを４つ買ったので、今週はかなり忙しくなる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>substitute</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is a <vocabulary>substitution</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I substituted sour cream with yogurt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サワークリームをヨーグルトで代用しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You can use stockings as a substitute for the cord you wear under your kimono.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きもののこしひもは、ストッキングでも代用かのうです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We didn’t have glue so we substituted grains of boiled rice for it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>糊がないので飯粒で代用した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>hand</kanji> that <kanji>sell</kanji>s the items is connected to a person who is known as the <vocabulary>seller</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>vendor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too! One hint that this is a kun'yomi reading word is the hiragana in the center. It's like two separate words combined together, and when a word is a single kanji / a single kanji with hiragana attached it is usually kun'yomi. This is like two of those, combined.
Context 1-EN: I was cheated by that vendor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの売り手にだまされました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This's the hottest seller's market ever.
Context 2-JP: <jp>空ぜんの売り手市場ですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The guy selling that house told me he’s selling it because his neighbor is a real jerk.
Context 3-JP: <jp>その家の売り手は、「近所の人が本当にひどいやつなので、家を手放すことにしたんだ」と、私に話してくれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well!
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which is also the reading you associated with the kanji, earlier.
Context 1-EN: These chopsticks are made of bamboo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このおはしは竹でできています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you cut a bamboo to about a meter high, it dies and even its roots wither.
Context 2-JP: <jp>竹は、一メートルぐらいのたかさまで切ってしまうと、ねまでかれてしまいます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I love working with bamboo! I made my television out of bamboo. It doesn’t work, but it sure looks nice.
Context 3-JP: <jp>竹細工が本当に好きなんだ！うちのテレビも俺が竹から作ったんだよ。まあ、動かないけどね。でも、見た目がいいんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fasten</kanji> everything into <kanji>one</kanji>. <vocabulary>All together</vocabulary> in one <vocabulary>batch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>lump</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened <jp>いち</jp>.
Context 1-EN: In Japan they use a different method of measurement for baking sweets and cooking. I think it would be better to have one way of measuring throughout the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本では焼き菓子作りとか料理の計量方法が違うんだよね。いっそ世界中の計量方法が一括で同じだったらいいのにね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fasten</kanji> <kanji>arc</kanji>s are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (<vocabulary>parentheses</vocabulary>) and [<vocabulary>brackets</vocabulary>].
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.
Context 1-EN: When people read the left bracket, they just say "kakko," but when they read the right bracket, they say "kakko-tojiru," which means "close bracket."
Context 1-JP: <jp>左の括弧を読む時は単に「括弧」と言いますが、右の括弧を読む時は「括弧閉じる」と言います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Doing something both <kanji>fast</kanji> and <kanji>early</kanji> probably requires you to do it <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immediately</vocabulary>. Whatever it is, be sure to do it <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is strange. The reading for <jp>速</jp> (<jp>そく</jp>) is what you'd expect (on'yomi), but <jp>早</jp> gets a reading you haven't seen before, meaning you should treat this as an exception. Just think about how you're learning this word <vocabulary>at once</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>without delay</vocabulary> so there's no time for any <reading>sa</reading>ss (<jp>さっ</jp>), just kanji learning.
Context 1-EN: I used it immediately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>早速使わせていただきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Thank you for your immediate response.
Context 2-JP: <jp>早速のごへんしん、ありがとうございます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I will send the eggplants to him at once.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はその茄子を早速彼に送ります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>round</kanji> <kanji>arc</kanji> is, well, the shape of an <vocabulary>arc</vocabulary>. It has that round shape to it, you know?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The father ordered his son to paint an arc.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父親は息子に円弧を描くように命令しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> of something is its <vocabulary>electric power</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you tell me everything you know about the Electricity Liberalization that started in Japan in April of 2016.
Context 1-JP: <jp>2016年4月から日本でスタートした、電力自由化についてくわしく教えてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't want to pay the bill to that electric company.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの電力会社には電気代をはらいたくないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Power was restored in roughly three hours and I was able to fix my hair with my electric hair clippers before the interview.
Context 3-JP: <jp>電力が約三時間で復旧したので、私は面接の前に電動バリカンで頭を刈って整えることができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>think</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is really the way someone thinks. That's why this word means <vocabulary>way of thinking</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: People have their own way of thinking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>考え方は、人それぞれです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mom and dad's thought processes are totally different to begin with.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そもそも、父と母は考え方がまったくちがうんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Even if you really are an awful woman, thinking badly about yourself still isn’t a healthy way to think.
Context 3-JP: <jp>自分のことを悪い人間だと思うのは、もし自分が実際に悪女だったとしても、良くない考え方です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wait</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to wait</vocabulary> for your <reading>ma</reading>ma (<jp>ま</jp>) all the time. You want to go out? You have to wait for mama to drive you. Want to eat dinner? You have to wait for mama to make you food. Hmm. Maybe all this waiting is really a you problem.
Context 1-EN: I was waiting for five hours at the cafe, but he didn’t come.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きっ茶店で、五時間待っていましたが、かれは来ませんでした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll be waiting for you at Starbucks.
Context 3-EN: Wait! I might have forgotten my wallet at home.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと待って！財布を家に忘れたかも。</jp>

Meaning: To Challenge Someone,To Challenge Something,To Challenge
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>challenge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to challenge someone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>I do</reading>n't (<jp>いど</jp>) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my <reading>Id</reading> (<jp>いど</jp>), after all.
Context 1-EN: I’m going to challenge the famous bacon connoisseur this Sunday.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私はこの日曜日、有名なベーコン鑑定家に挑みます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have your <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>state</kanji>. For Japan (since this is a Japanese word), that would be the main island, the big one in the middle: <vocabulary>Honshu</vocabulary>. You'll have to know some minor Japanese geography for this. Go look at a map of Japan and study it over real quick to see where I'm talking about if you don't know already.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: After this I plan on going to Honshu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この後、本州に行くつもりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Where the heck in Japan is Honshu?
Context 2-JP: <jp>本州とは、いったいぜんたい日本のどこにあるんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you don't know where Honshu is, why don't you look it up on your computer?
Context 3-JP: <jp>本州がどこか分からなければ、パソコンでしらべたらどうですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: My <kanji>challenge</kanji> has made a <kanji>departure</kanji> and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a <vocabulary>provocation</vocabulary> to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A protester threw a Molotov cocktail toward the police during a riot to provoke them.
Context 1-JP: <jp>抗議者の一人が、警察を挑発するために火炎瓶を投げつけました。</jp>

Meaning: To Hoist,To Fly,To Raise,To Deep Fry
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hoist</kanji>. This strange word means <vocabulary>to hoist</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to raise</vocabulary>, and (most importantly) <vocabulary>to deep fry</vocabulary>. The hoisting part usually has to do with hoisting or raising a flag, or something similar.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all <jp>あげる</jp> as well. For example, <jp>上げる</jp> is <jp>あげる</jp> and <jp>挙げる</jp> is <jp>あげる</jp> as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m just about to deep fry pork cutlets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょうど今からトンカツを揚げるところです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. What? Yeah, that's what.
Context 1-EN: What would you say?
Context 1-JP: <jp>何と言いますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who do you think you are?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなた、何さまのつもりですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What was the name of that drink we had at the hotel in Thailand?
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕達がタイのホテルで飲んだ飲み物の名前は何？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>early</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>early</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading, which you did not learn when you learned the kanji. You have to remember the <jp>はや</jp> portion to be able read this word. In order to do that, here's a mnemonic: You're <kanji>fast</kanji>! You're <kanji>early</kanji>! Your chop comes down onto your opponent's neck so quickly! As you chop him, you yell "<reading><jp>はや</jp></reading>!"
Context 1-EN: We arrived 15 minutes earlier than scheduled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>よていより、十五分早くつきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think it's too early to ask her out.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かの女にこく白するのはまだ早いとおもうんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A tofu maker always wakes up early in the morning.
Context 3-JP: <jp>豆腐屋さんの朝はいつも早い。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a <kanji>flat</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>. What kind of energy would be a flat one? Probably a <vocabulary>cool</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>calm</vocabulary> one. You'd also tell people about this flat energy by saying you are <vocabulary>all right</vocabulary> or just <vocabulary>okay</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How come you’re always so calm?
Context 1-JP: <jp>よく平気でいられますね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The princess is a type of person who wouldn't get upset even if she lost her pet puppy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>王女はペットの子犬をなくしても平気な人です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My husband was fired, but I’m surprisingly calm.
Context 3-JP: <jp>夫が会社を首になったが、意外と平気だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Part</kanji> of your <kanji>energy</kanji> is your <vocabulary>feeling</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>mood</vocabulary>. Just think of it like you're breaking up your energy into parts. One part is sugar giving you energy. Another part is your happiness. So, when you combine these together you get the total: your mood!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been feeling great since this morning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日はあさから気分がいいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I feel like going on a picnic now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんとなくピクニックに出かけたい気分です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you marry me, I think I’ll be in a good mood for the rest of my life.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君が僕と結婚してくれたら、残りの人生ずっといい気分ですごせると思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned the reading for this word via the kanji, so you should be able to read this word just fine.
Context 1-EN: I’ve been using my computer too much so my neck hurts.
Context 1-JP: <jp>パソコンのしすぎで、首がいたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I cricked my neck in my sleep.
Context 3-EN: Is the bubonic plague the illness that made people grow boobs on their necks?
Context 3-JP: <jp>腺ペストって、首から胸が生えてくる病気のことですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: There are many <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>bird</kanji>s out there, for sure, but one really stands out if you ask me. That bird is the <vocabulary>swan</vocabulary>. It's big, it's white, and it's majestic.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Pulling a swan out of the lake just to take a selfie with it is too cruel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自どりをするためだけに白鳥をみずうみから引きずり出すなんてひどすぎるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: They say that white wine goes well with fish, but do you know what kind of wine would go well with swan?
Context 2-JP: <jp>白ワインは魚りょうりに合うっていうけど、白鳥りょうりに合うワインは何か知っていますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Swans are so pretty, but they use foul language.
Context 3-JP: <jp>白鳥はとても美しいが、汚らしい言葉遣いをする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This implies that it is your older brother, by the way. Not somebody else's.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your <vocabulary>older brother</vocabulary> is different from everyone else's. He has odd powers... some would say powers of the force. Do you know what his name is? It's <reading>Ani</reading> (<jp>あに</jp>), short for Anikin... wait a sec, does that sound familiar?
Context 1-EN: You look like my older brother, Mr. Yamashita.
Context 1-JP: <jp>山下さんはわたしの兄ににていますね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A month ago, my older brother came home with a black labrador.
Context 2-JP: <jp>一ヶ月まえに兄がくろラブをつれていえにかえってきました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My older brother likes eating tofu covered in coffee.
Context 3-JP: <jp>兄は、とうふにコーヒーをかけてたべるのがすきだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>grip</kanji> with your <kanji>hand</kanji> (onto another hand) is a <vocabulary>handshake</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With <jp>手</jp> just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.
Context 1-EN: I bought a CD that came with two handshake tickets as a bonus. (Handshake tickets are similar to meet and greet tickets.)
Context 1-JP: <jp>CDを買うと、オマケで握手券が二枚ついてきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>grip</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji> is your <vocabulary>handgrip</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He is your father so you should give him the benefit of the doubt. His grip has gotten worse with age and that’s why he dropped your vintage Baccarat crystal‎ glass.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分の父親なんだから、善意に解釈してあげるべきよ。例えば、年を取って握力が弱っているせいで、あなたのビンテージのバカラのグラスを割っちゃったんだ、っていう風に。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> and the verb vocab is <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If everything starts <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary> what else will shake along with it? <reading>You</reading> (<jp>ゆ</jp>), of course.
Context 1-EN: Don’t rock the canoe!
Context 1-JP: <jp>カヌーを揺らないで！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>artisan</kanji> who's good enough to be a <kanji>teacher</kanji> has to be a <vocabulary>master</vocabulary> of her craft.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: May I call you "master?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>師匠と呼ばせてもらえませんか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something <kanji>move</kanji>s then <kanji>shake</kanji>s, it is <vocabulary>shaking</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trembling</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Her natural beauty and charming smile took my breath away and I was trembling during the meeting.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女の自然な美しさと魅力的な笑顔に息も出来なくなり、会議中ずっと動揺していました。</jp>

Meaning: In A Little While,In A Short While,In A Moment
Meaning Mnemonic: Please <kanji>temporarily</kanji> wait. <vocabulary>In a little while</vocabulary> something will happen, but temporarily you'll have to sit still.
