Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: <vocabulary>In a little while</vocabulary>, we're going to be listening to <reading>shiba rock</reading> (<jp>しばらく</jp>). This is a form of rock and roll performed by shiba dogs. You should look up shiba inu puppy pictures if you haven't ever heard of shiba inus.
Context 1-EN: I haven’t done any housework in a while because I have terrible morning sickness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>悪阻がひどくて、暫く全然家事ができてないんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>right</kanji>. What happens when you get "a right?" You get <vocabulary>a success</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the <jp>あ</jp> portion of this word to read it. What is the correct answer that will give you <vocabulary>a success</vocabulary>? It is the first answer, <reading>A</reading> (<jp>あ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: The odds of winning the lottery are very low.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たからくじで当たりが出るかくりつはとてもひくいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Such a weak-hit grounder can't be a hit.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あんなしょっぼい当たりのゴロでヒットになるわけがない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The party I threw for my father’s 50th birthday was a success and he even found a new girlfriend there.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕が開いた父さんの５０歳の誕生日パーティーは大当たりで、父さんはそこで新しい彼女まで見つけてしまった。</jp>

Meaning: Whisper In Ear,Whisper In One's Ear,Whisper In Someone's Ear
Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hit</kanji> to someone's <kanji>ear</kanji>... you'd think that would be like yelling into their ear, but it's not. Think of it like you're hitting your mouth to their ear so that it's nice and close so you can <vocabulary>whisper in ear</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, but you know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: He secretly whispered in my ear.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれは、わたしにこっそり耳打ちしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I happened to witness Koichi whispering something in Nikka's ear during the meeting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ミーティングのときに、コウイチがニッカになにか耳打ちしてるのをみてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I told him to whisper something sexy in my ear and he said, "Do you like tapes and CDs?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>私が彼に、何かセクシーな言葉を耳打ちしてというと、彼は「テープやCDは好きかい？」と囁いてくれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>read</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to read</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go read something else, now.
Context 1-EN: Please read the following text and answer the questions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>次の文を読んで、しつもんに答えてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I secretly read the hush-hush diary that is exchanged between Viet and Koichi.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトとコウイチのひみつの交かん日記を内しょで読んでしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you read the note your boyfriend left you about your trip? It says that you should bring two or three umbrellas with you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あんたの彼氏が書いた「旅の注意書き」読んだ？二、三本傘を持参するべきって書いてあるけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It <kanji>hang</kanji>s on an <kanji>axis</kanji> point. The axis opens up, and reveals a <vocabulary>hanging scroll</vocabulary>. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.
Reading Mnemonic: For <jp>掛</jp> you'll want to think back to the word <jp>掛ける</jp>, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the <jp>かけ</jp> part at least). For <jp>軸</jp> that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.
Context 1-EN: I want Aya to paint a picture for the hanging scroll.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アヤに、掛軸のための絵を描いてもらいたいんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>year</kanji> that is <kanji>next</kanji> is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is <vocabulary>annual</vocabulary>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Let’s decide on this year’s annual project.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年の年次けいかくを立てましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How much annual paid leave do you get, Mariko?
Context 2-JP: <jp>マリ子は年次有きゅう休か、何日もらえるの？</jp>
Context 3-EN: We write an annual report on how much our Japanese language students are improving.
Context 3-JP: <jp>生徒たちの日本語がどれだけ上達したかに関する年次報告書を作成する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Japanese style</kanji> <kanji>style</kanji>. The Japanese often like to think they're very unique and have a very special kind of style (and often times they do). So, you'll hear this word used when someone wants to describe this unique sense of style. Wafuuuu! Note that this word uses alternative kanji meanings in both of the kanji. They're in the kanji explanation, but they're not the primaries, so it may take a little extra effort to learn this word depending on what you studied!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I do like Japanese flavors.
Context 1-JP: <jp>和風のあじ付けがすきなんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you get Japanese sesame dressing from a grocery store on the way back?
Context 2-JP: <jp>かえりにスーパーで、和風ごまドレッシングを買ってきてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This is the Japanese style hotdog.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これが和風ホットドッグです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji>. Where is that? Probably just in <vocabulary>heaven</vocabulary> (or if you want to be fancy, the <vocabulary>kingdom of heaven</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>国</jp> is changed to the reading <jp>ごく</jp>, though because of rendaku. Even heaven changes a little bit.
Context 1-EN: Poochie is definitely in heaven.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ポチはきっと天国にいるんだよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am so disappointed to learn the Kingdom of Heaven is that kind of place.
Context 2-JP: <jp>天国がこんなとこだったなんて、本当にがっかりです。</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>タバコを天国で吸いましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>axis</kanji> is where the <vocabulary>axis</vocabulary> is, of course, but it's also where the <vocabulary>pivot</vocabulary> is too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Last night I had a dream about a coral insect’s axial skeleton.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日、珊瑚虫の中軸骨格を夢に見た。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi reading, but lucky for you that's the reading you learned with the kanji, meaning you should be able to read this vocab too.
Context 1-EN: Please put some paper, a pencil, and an eraser on your desk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>紙とえんぴつとけしゴムをつくえに出してください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm so looking forward to buying a new piece of paper.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あたらしい紙をかうのがたのしみでしかたがない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yesterday, I saw a wolf writing a poem on a piece of paper.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日、紙の切れ端に詩を書いている狼を見かけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>direction</kanji> <kanji>yonder</kanji> over there is still just the <vocabulary>direction</vocabulary> of something, though a complicated way to say it, I think. This direction is the "what direction did he go in?" sort of direction.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I lost my bearings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは、方向が分からなくなりました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>めっちゃ方向音ちなんですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Are we going in the right direction? I thought Chuck E. Cheese was the other way.
Context 3-JP: <jp>こっちの方向であってるの？チャッキー・チーズは反対方向だと思ってたんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>country</kanji> <kanji>pattern</kanji> is the pattern of things a country does. This is the <vocabulary>national character</vocabulary> of a nation.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. <jp>国</jp> is <jp>くに</jp> and <jp>柄</jp> is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Each country has their own national character and I think that’s something we should all respect.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それぞれの国にはそれぞれのお国柄ってものがあって、私達はそれをお互いに尊重し合うべきだと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: What <vocabulary>time</vocabulary> is it? It's time <reading>to key</reading> (<jp>とき</jp>) your enemy's car. Imagine yourself looking at your watch, waiting until the correct time to perform a synchronized keying of someone's car. Who do you hate the most? Whose car would you like to key?
Context 1-EN: When you want to turn on the air conditioning, please press the white button.
Context 1-JP: <jp>れいぼうをつける時は、白いボタンをおしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We can do nothing but wait for time to solve this.
Context 2-JP: <jp>時がかい決してくれるのをまつしかないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Whenever I’m happy, I always think it would be nice if I could stop time.
Context 3-JP: <jp>幸せな時、いつも時が止まればいいのに、と思う。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>overnight</kanji> is a <vocabulary>one night's stay</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened <jp>一</jp> and the rendaku in this one.
Context 1-EN: Come on! Don’t be so stiff. Stay over at my place! Just for one night!
Context 1-JP: <jp>ねぇ、そう堅いこと言わないでさ。うちに泊まってけばいいじゃん。たったの一泊だけだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji>'s <kanji>pattern</kanji> is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their <vocabulary>personal character</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For <jp>人</jp> you'll just have to remember this. With <jp>柄</jp> that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!
Context 1-EN: Don’t judge people’s personalities by their appearance like you’d judge a book by its cover.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本の内容を表紙で判断するみたいに、人の人柄を見た目で決めつけないでよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Usually if you're going to the left in Japanese, it's not a good thing. So if you <kanji>transition</kanji> to the <kanji>left</kanji> it's seen as a <vocabulary>demotion</vocabulary>. Going to the right is way better.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was demoted to a branch store in the country.
Context 1-JP: <jp>田舎の支店に左遷されました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>fish</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fish shop</vocabulary>, a place from which you buy fish. Especially in Japan, very important.
Reading Mnemonic: The kun'yomi reading is used for the <jp>魚</jp> (so it's <jp>さかな</jp>) and the kun'yomi reading is used for <jp>屋</jp> (<jp>や</jp>). You'll have to use the reading of <jp>魚</jp> from the vocabulary from a couple levels ago to remember the reading of this one.
Context 1-EN: We went to buy splendid red bream at the fish store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>魚屋で金目だいを買ってきたの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This fish shop floor is very slippery, so be careful.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この魚屋のゆかはすべりやすいから気を付けてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The fish shop gave me a 100 yen discount.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの魚屋さんは百円おまけをしてくれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>relax</kanji>ed, what do you feel? <vocabulary>Uneasiness</vocabulary> is what you'd feel.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m anxious about passing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ごうかくしているか不安です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm so nervous about the impending childbirth.
Context 2-JP: <jp>出さんを目前に不安な気もちでいっぱいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Since I witnessed the murder, I haven't been able to rid myself of these feelings of anxiety.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの殺人事件を目撃してからというもの、不安を取り除くことができない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Look down! You're holding something covered in <vocabulary>fur</vocabulary>. It's a furry <reading>ke</reading>ttle (<jp>け</jp>)! It's the weirdest kettle you've ever seen, but presumably it keeps the water hot for much longer.
Context 1-EN: My leg hair is bushy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あしの毛がボーボーです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our dog's fur falls off a lot.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの犬の毛はよくぬける。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Right now the most important thing to me is the hair on my head.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今一ばん大切なのはあたまの毛だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> of the <kanji>sea</kanji> is someplace <vocabulary>overseas</vocabulary>. It can also be <vocabulary>foreign</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>abroad</vocabulary> if those words are easier to remember for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I want to work overseas in the future.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しょう来は、海外ではたらきたいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After having worked in the insurance industry for eight years, I went to America to study abroad.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ほけんぎょうかいに八年つとめた後、アメリカへ海外りゅう学しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to live somewhere overseas, but I hate traveling.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はどこか海外で住みたいと思っているが、旅行は嫌いだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>construction</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is a <vocabulary>factory</vocabulary>. A factory is a place where you or machines do a bunch of construction!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’d like to go to the Toyota factory - which way would be the most convenient?
Context 1-JP: <jp>トヨタの工場に行きたいんですけど、何で行くのがべんりですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's my husband's job to lock up the bacon factory every night.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎ばん、ベーコン工場のせじょうをするのは、わたしの主人の役目です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The only factory I would want to work in is a factory that makes cookies.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私が働きたいと思う唯一の工場は、クッキー工場です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>guest</kanji>'s <kanji>room</kanji> is the <vocabulary>guest room</vocabulary> (the room you put guests in, duh!).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My dream is to stay in a guest room attached to an open air bath with the idol I love.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大すきなアイドルと、ろ天ぶろ付の客室にとまることがゆめなんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In this hotel, all the guest rooms have concierge service.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このホテルでは全ての客室にコンシェルジュサービスが付いてきます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I just finished renovating the guest room. Come over and tell me what you think.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょうど客室のリフォームが終わったところなんですの。是非うちにいらして、ご意見を聞かせてくださいな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: There is a <vocabulary>man</vocabulary>. Think of the manliest man you can. He works in an auto shop. As a child, he was an <reading>auto </reading> (<jp>おとこ</jp>), working at the auto shop from an early age. This turned him into a man very quickly. Like other mnemonics that aren't lined up quite perfectly, your goal here is to get close enough to remember the true reading. Step, step, step, jump!
Context 1-EN: Who is that man?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの男はだれですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I plan to go play pachinko with my guy friends today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は男友だちとパチンコを打ちにいくよていです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I developed quite a rapport with a man I didn't know at a fireworks show.
Context 3-JP: <jp>知らない男と花火大会で意気投合した。</jp>

Meaning: To Stay The Night,To Stay At
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>overnight</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to stay the night</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: We are just going to stay <reading>to</reading>night (<jp>と</jp>) and maybe <reading>to</reading>morrow (<jp>と</jp>) tonight.
Context 1-EN: I bought a DVD of the funniest comedy skits ever, so why don’t you stay over and watch it with me tonight?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今までで一番面白い最高傑作のお笑いのDVDを買ったんだけど、今日うちに泊まって一緒に観ない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>slippery</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to slide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to slip</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: It wouldn't be so slippery in here if your friend Beth hadn't spilled something all over the floor. This is the third time you've slipped this month! You know what you have to do. You have to <reading>sue Be</reading>th (<jp>すべ</jp>)! She'll pay for making you slip and slide!
Context 1-EN: Although the snow is starting to thaw, there are still some places where it’s easy to slip, so you should be careful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>雪解けは始まったけど、まだ滑りやすい場所もあるから気をつけてね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>generation</kanji> is the <vocabulary>second generation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: He’s one of the second generation Japanese-Americans.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かれは、日けいアメリカ人二世の一人です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Not many children of celebrities can be celebrities too.
Context 2-JP: <jp>せいこうしている二世タレントは少ない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I didn’t know that my father is second generation Japanese-British.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、父が日系イギリス人二世だということを知らなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're going to the far <vocabulary>north</vocabulary> where it's very cold (north pole, perhaps?). One of the most important things you bring with you is a survival <reading>kit</reading> (<jp>きた</jp>).
Context 1-EN: There is a hospital on the north side of the station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>えきの北には、びょういんがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: North Korea launched a missile again.
Context 2-JP: <jp>北ちょうせんが又ミサイルをはっしゃした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The ghosts in North America are so scary.
Context 3-JP: <jp>北アメリカのゆうれいはとてもこわい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are able to <kanji>stand</kanji> using your <kanji>self</kanji>. Nobody is helping you. Nobody is holding you down. This is your <vocabulary>independence</vocabulary>!.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My son is finally starting to be self reliant.
Context 1-JP: <jp>むすこもようやく自立しはじめました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm thinking of being on my own, if I recover from autonomic dysfunction.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自立しんけいしっちょうしょうがなおったら、自立しようとおもっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Share this if you are a strong, independent Japanese woman who doesn’t need a man.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もしあなたが強くて自立した日本人女性で、男なんて必要ないというなら、これをシェアしてください。</jp>

Meaning: To Copy,To Photograph,To Take A Picture
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>copy</kanji> so you know this means <vocabulary>to copy</vocabulary>. You know this word means "to copy" because it ends with <jp>す</jp>. You're copying the documents you need to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) someone who screwed you over.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the <jp>うつ</jp> part. To remember that, think of yourself as a beatboxer. You're saying <reading><jp>うつうつうつ</jp></reading> over and over again. Thing is, the other beatboxer is going <vocabulary>to copy</vocabulary> everything you do. That's why you're suing him.
Context 1-EN: Please copy the characters onto the next page of your workbooks.
Context 1-JP: <jp>となりのページに、この字を写してください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm a big fan of the photos Viet takes.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトの写す写しんの大ファンです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You must pay 1,000 yen in order to transcribe a sutra by hand.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お経を書き写すには、千円支払う必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>dry</kanji> <kanji>lagoon</kanji> is a <vocabulary>tidal flat</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>干</jp> is an exceptional one. Just think to why the lagoon is dry. It's because of the <reading>he</reading>at (<jp>ひ</jp>) of the sun. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: We went to a tidal flat to go clamming for the one month anniversary of our friendship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>交際一ヶ月記念の日に、干潟に潮干狩りに行ってきたの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Someone yells out "NEXT!" because the first thing didn't work on you. That was a single guillotine. Now they are going to try <reading>two gui</reading>llotines (<jp>つぎ</jp>) and see how that works on your thick neck. NEXXXXT!
Context 1-EN: Let’s catch the next train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>次のでん車にのりましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll let you know once we decide on the next plan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>次のよていは、決まり次だいお知らせします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The next destination on this bus tour is Michael Jackson’s house.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このバスツアーの次の目的地は、マイケル・ジャクソンの家です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>char</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is the part you're looking at so hard it burns a little hole in it. Just imagine yourself looking at a single point so hard that it begins to smolder. This is the <vocabulary>focal point</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>focus</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When our teacher explained how to focus the microscope, I was spacing out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生が顕微鏡の焦点の合わせ方について説明をしてくれていた時、私は上の空でした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>char</kanji>, but the verb version is <vocabulary>to be burned</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get burned</vocabulary>. You're not doing the burning, of course, but you're getting burned (owch!).
Reading Mnemonic: The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a kid (<reading><jp>子</jp></reading>). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.
Context 1-EN: My mom told me that constant stirring keeps the bottom of the pan from burning.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一定にかき混ぜることで、鍋の底が焦げることが防げるとお母さんが言っていたわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>bustle</kanji> and <kanji>run</kanji> around all day from being busy you end up <vocabulary>running about</vocabulary> to get them all done. You'll <vocabulary>be busy</vocabulary> getting it all done, but your <vocabulary>efforts</vocabulary> won't be in vain!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My company is busy running around financing.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの社長は資金繰りに奔走しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Distract</kanji> me with a <kanji>twist</kanji> in what we're doing. Just imagine you're working on something. Then, you get distracted by a twist in whatever it is that you're working on. This little twist doesn't destroy everything, but it does cause a <vocabulary>complication</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>confusion</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don’t want to complicate this problem any more.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この問題をこれ以上紛糾させたくないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned as well!
Context 1-EN: If they say that those vegetables are all safe, they should set an example for us by eating them first.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしその野菜が全部安全だというのなら、まず先に彼らがそれを食べて我々に範を垂れるべきだ。</jp>

Meaning: Long Time No See,It's Been A While
Meaning Mnemonic: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that 久 means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that she buried you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "LONG TIME NO SEE!"
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned <jp>久しい</jp>. It's the same one!
Context 1-EN: Long time no see!
Context 1-JP: <jp>久しぶりですね！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Beer after being sober for so long was so good it brought me to tears.
Context 2-JP: <jp>久しぶりのビールは、なみだが出るほどおいしかった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was told "long time no see" by a person that I had never met before.
Context 3-JP: <jp>久しぶり！とあったことのない人にいわれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> thing you talk about in your <kanji>language</kanji> becomes the <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary> of the sentence.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Can you make the subject clear?
Context 1-JP: <jp>主語をハッキリさせてくれないかな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This new service that clarifies the subject is very useful.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この主語を明かくにする新サービスは、本当に役に立つ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Japanese is a subject-object-verb language whereas English is a subject-verb-object language.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本語は、主語ー目的語ー動詞の言語ですが、英語は主語ー動詞ー目的語の言語です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You are going to <kanji>release</kanji> and <kanji>send</kanji> something out. Imagine this message going out through the sky to everyone around you. You are going <vocabulary>to broadcast</vocabulary> it to the world! The <jp>する</jp> is on there to make this noun a verb. Without the <jp>する</jp> it would be the noun "broadcast."
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It’s been a while since this drama was broadcast.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このドラマが放送されるのは、久しぶりです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A rebroadcast of the game is scheduled to run on NHK at 5pm today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのし合のさい放送なら、今日五時からNHKで放送される予定ですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: President Koichi’s important announcement will be broadcast on television tonight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチ社長は今晩テレビで重大な決定を放送することになっている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>artisan</kanji> has an <kanji>idea</kanji> and makes a brand new <vocabulary>design</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This is a work that had a splendid design applied to it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、意匠が凝らされた素晴らしい作品です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Did you water the lawn for me?
Context 1-JP: <jp>芝に水は撒いてくれた？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have the ol' <kanji>liver</kanji> <kanji>flame</kanji> then you probably have <vocabulary>hepatitis</vocabulary>. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The hepatitis A patient is starving for love and always tries to get attention from the nurses and doctors.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのA型肝炎の患者は愛に飢えており、いつも医者や看護師の気を引こうとしている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mix</kanji> of cars that <kanji>pass through</kanji> a <kanji>net</kanji>, that's a <vocabulary>traffic network</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A massive earthquake paralyzed the transportation network in and around Tokyo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大地震が首都圏の交通網を麻痺させました。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Right,To Be On Target,To Touch,To Hit
Meaning Mnemonic: You know this is a verb because it ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound. The kanji for this word is <kanji>right</kanji> or <kanji>success</kanji>, so what's the verb form of that? Turns out it's a ton of things. Like, a crazy amount of things. I tried narrowing it down for you, but it will still be a lot. This word tends to be about getting an answer right. As in, <vocabulary>to be right</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be on target</vocabulary>. It means many other things too, but I think these are the two meanings you'll see the most, so focus on those.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember the <jp>あ</jp> portion. You need to guess the correct answer. What do you choose? You guess <reading>A</reading> (<jp>あ</jp>) and hope it's right. Turns out you were right on the money. Well done! Imagine yourself winning a fabulous prize.
Context 1-EN: I’m glad my guess was right.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分の予想が当たって、嬉しいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If a person was hit with a stone, what would you do?
Context 2-JP: <jp>人に石が当たったらどうするんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In a packed train, my hand accidentally touched the butt of the woman next to me and I was so worried I’d be mistaken for a molester.
Context 3-JP: <jp>まんいんでん車で、手がとなりの女のしりに当たってしまい、ちかんにまちがえられたらどうしようと不あんでいっぱいになった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>lawn</kanji> of <kanji>life</kanji> is just your <vocabulary>lawn</vocabulary>. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>芝</jp> is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for <jp>生</jp> is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's <jp>ふ</jp>, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a <reading>foo</reading>l (<jp>ふ</jp>) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.
Context 1-EN: Walking on the lawn in this park is prohibited.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この公園では、芝生の上を歩くのは禁止されています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>east</kanji> <kanji>lawn</kanji> isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company <vocabulary>Toshiba</vocabulary>. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the readings you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The email from Toshiba’s customer center was all garbled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東芝のお客様センターから届いたメールは、全文文字化けしていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. So, put that knowledge in a <vocabulary>sack</vocabulary> and move on to the next item.
Context 1-EN: I sewed a bag for my kid to use at school.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもが学校で使う用の袋を縫いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>bathe</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> are the clothes you take with you to bathe with. This is <vocabulary>Yukata</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is totally an exception. The reading comes from the meaning, though. Yukata = <jp>ゆかた</jp>.
Context 1-EN: She clung to her old ways of thinking and wore a yukata instead of pajamas every night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は自分の古い考え方にしがみついて、毎晩パジャマの代わりに浴衣を着て過ごした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word was probably made pretty recently. A <kanji>horse</kanji>'s <kanji>power</kanji>? That is <vocabulary>horsepower</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Take note that the reading for <jp>力</jp> is the <jp>りき</jp> version of the reading. You can remember this by thinking about how it's <reading>Ricky</reading> who drives the high <vocabulary>horsepower</vocabulary> cars. Vroom vroom Ricky!
Context 1-EN: What’s the best way to increase a car’s horsepower?
Context 1-JP: <jp>自どう車の馬力を上げるには、どうすればいいですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Asahi, your grandpa is such an energetic person, isn't he?
Context 2-JP: <jp>アサヒのじいちゃんって、本当に馬力があるよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I tinkered with my lawnmower for about four years and now it has 450 horsepower.
Context 3-JP: <jp>約四年間いじくり回したおかげで、今俺の芝刈り機は450馬力もあるんだぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If something is moving towards <kanji>sincerity</kanji> then it <vocabulary>indeed</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> did happen. <vocabulary>Absolutely</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: <reading>My </reading> (<jp>まこと</jp>) really did happen! <vocabulary>Indeed</vocabulary> it did!
Context 1-EN: I am very sorry, but smoking is prohibited in all rooms of this hotel.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誠に申し訳ありませんが、当ホテルは全室禁煙となっております。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>decision</kanji> is <kanji>split</kanji>, causing a <vocabulary>breakdown</vocabulary> in all we've decided. A big ol' <vocabulary>rupture</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That guy must have eagerly waited out their breakdown from behind bars.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの男は奴らの決裂を、牢屋の中で舌なめずりをしながら待っていたに違いない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>rare</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a <vocabulary>delicacy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I have gout and I know I should avoid beer, but I can’t help drinking it today because my friend gave me some delicacies that go well with beer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は痛風なのでビールを飲まない方がいいのは分かっているんですが、友人からビールに良く合う珍味をもらったので今日ばかりは我慢できませんね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>attack</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an <vocabulary>attack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assault</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A police car was attacked by a motorcycle gang.
Context 1-JP: <jp>警察の車は、暴走族に襲撃された。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word covers a lot of meanings so it can be <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>taste</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>vibe</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If something has <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>, your thought/<jp>思</jp> (<jp>おも</jp>) goes in that direction/<jp>向き</jp> (<jp>むき</jp>).  You feel the vibe? Do you get the gist?
Context 1-EN: I’ve never seen such a tasteful doggie bag before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんなに趣のあるお持ち帰り用の容器を見たのは初めてです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tribute</kanji> I <kanji>offer</kanji> is my <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why did G20 reject financially contributing to the bailout?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうしてG20は財政支援への貢献を否認したのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.
Context 1-EN: How many arrows are left?
Context 1-JP: <jp>矢はなん本のこっていますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Cupid is about to fire an arrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こいのキューピッドが矢をはなとうとしているよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A Native American arrowhead flew towards me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ほくべい土人の矢じりがとんできた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about the <vocabulary>south</vocabulary>. What's down there? <reading>Mean Amy</reading> (<jp>みなみ</jp>) lives down there. Think of the last mean thing she did to you and imagine it while yelling out "MEAN AMYYYYY" at the sky.
Context 1-EN: There is a police station on the south side of the library.
Context 1-JP: <jp>としょかんの南に、交ばんがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why isn't there a North Japan Railway Company and a South Japan Railway Company, even though there's an East Japan Railway Company and a West Japan Railway Company?
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうして東日本りょかくてつ道と西日本りょかくてつ道はあるのに、北日本りょかくてつ道と南日本りょかくてつ道はないんだ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I saw Brad Pitt at the south baseball stadium.
Context 3-JP: <jp>南球場でブラッド・ピットを見た。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Here you have <kanji>both</kanji> <kanji>direction</kanji>s / <kanji>way</kanji>s. Every time you have to choose between something it's like having to choose between two ways. That's why this word is simply <vocabulary>both</vocabulary>. Close to the kanji is the meaning <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>, as well. Learn either for <jp>両方</jp>, they're pretty similar.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My older and younger sisters both live in Osaka.
Context 1-JP: <jp>姉も妹も、両方とも大さかにすんでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You've got time, so why don't you try it both ways?
Context 2-JP: <jp>じかんはあるんだから、両方やってみたら？</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>ダメだよ！両方とも僕のだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Enroll</kanji> your <kanji>door</kanji>... and by door, I mean enroll your family, because each family has one door to their house. Enrolling your family means you are enrolling them into the <vocabulary>family register</vocabulary>. This is actually an interesting topic. Look up "koseki" in Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>戸</jp> is an exception. Instead of <jp>と</jp> it's <jp>こ</jp>. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of children (<reading><jp>こ</jp></reading>).
Context 1-EN: I need an official copy of my family register.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は戸籍謄本の写しが必要です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You visit the <vocabulary>sea</vocabulary>. Strangely, it asks you who is visiting. You're so full of yourself (even in front of the sea/ocean) that you reply: "<reading>um, me</reading>?" (<jp>うみ</jp>). Imagine yourself feeling this full of yourself.
Context 1-EN: The teacher is talking to her students in Marine Park.
Context 1-JP: <jp>海の公えんで、先生が学生にはなしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I got red eyes after swimming in the sea.
Context 2-JP: <jp>海でおよいだあと、目がじゅう血しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The movie Water World was actually written by a race of super-intelligent fish that live at the bottom of the ocean.
Context 3-JP: <jp>映画「水の世界」は、実は、海の底に住んでいる超頭のいい魚によって書かれた作品だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I would like to <kanji>enroll</kanji> into this <kanji>country</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>citizenship</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I don’t have Japanese citizenship, but is it possible for me to take the bar examination?
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本国籍がないんですが、司法試験を受験することは可能ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>expose</kanji> my <kanji>bone</kanji>s for a second here and be <vocabulary>blunt</vocabulary> with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was pretty surprised at how blunt she was.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女があまりに露骨にものを言うもので、少々面食らいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Using <kanji>violence</kanji> I'm going to <kanji>expose</kanji> the truth! This is <vocabulary>disclosure</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>暴</jp> is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step <reading>back</reading> (<jp>ばく</jp>) to deal with the new information.
Context 1-EN: I’m having second thoughts about publishing a tell-all book.
Context 1-JP: <jp>暴露本の出版については現在再考中です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>expose</kanji>d <kanji>shop</kanji> is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a <vocabulary>street stall</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Every accessory I bought from the street stall broke immediately.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの露店で買ったアクセは全部すぐ壊れちゃったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When what you <kanji>expose</kanji> is <kanji>exit</kanji>ed out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>. It can also refer to <vocabulary>photographic exposure</vocabulary> too, in case you were wondering.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I thought better of it and refrained from wearing such a revealing dress.
Context 1-JP: <jp>思い直して、肌の露出が激しいドレスを着るのは控えることにしました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>フランス</jp> is "France." So what is a "France person?" That would be a <vocabulary>French Person</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>ふらんすじん</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>フランスじん</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: ふらんすじん,フランスじん
Reading Mnemonic: You can treat this word and the <jp>人</jp> kanji on the end like jukugo (combo kanji). Usually, in the case of jukugo, you use the on'yomi reading. So here you'll want to remember to use the on'yomi reading for <jp>人</jp>. If you want, you can add <jp>人</jp> to the end of any place name to describe the people that live there!
Context 1-EN: I made a French friend.
Context 1-JP: <jp>フランス人のゆうじんができました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Two of them are American and the other three are French.
Context 2-JP: <jp>二人はアメリカ人で、あとの三人はフランス人です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I met a very sexy French chef.
Context 3-JP: <jp>とてもセクシーなフランス人シェフにあった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What do you think a <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>letter</kanji> is? If I were to guess, I'd say a <vocabulary>bold letter</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is a bit odd. The <jp>太</jp> uses the <jp>ふと</jp> from <jp>ふとい</jp> (kun'yomi) and the <jp>字</jp> is just the normal on'yomi reading for "letter." You have to remember this weird mismatched reading pair on your own, I'm afraid. Perhaps if you think about how fat letters don't really fit with the rest of the text, kind of like how the readings of both kanji also don't fit in it will help?
Context 1-EN: Make this character bold, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この字は太字にしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I got on the elevator in my apartment, the bold, red message appeared saying "Earthquake! Get out of this elevator right now," on the electric bulletin board so I got really scared.
Context 2-JP: <jp>マンションのエレベーターにのったら、でんこうけいじばんに赤い太字で「じしんです今すぐ外に出てください｣とかひょうじが出てきて、マジびびったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Let’s put this in bold to add more emphasis.
Context 3-JP: <jp>太字にすることで、その言葉を強調しましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When a vocab is a single kanji and alone like this, it usually steals its meaning from the parent kanji. That goes for this word too, making the meaning of this word <vocabulary>three</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually uses its kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, though, and use the on'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi reading when you learned this kanji, so you already know that the reading for this vocab is <reading>さん</reading>.
Context 1-EN: There are three pages of these questions total.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このもんだいようしは、ぜんぶで三ページあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Turn around three times and bark!
Context 3-JP: <jp>三かいまわってワンとほえろ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> is cloudy and fuzzy. What do you think when you look into the fuzzy clouds? It is the <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>unclear</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>uncertain</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The author of this story is unknown.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このはなしの作しゃは不明です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This milk doesn't have an expiration date on it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この牛にゅうのしょうみきげんは不明です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Huh? When you were sleeping you used an onion for a pillow? I don’t really get what you’re saying.
Context 3-JP: <jp>え？寝る時、玉ねぎを枕にしたの？あんたの言ってること、意味不明なんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>teacher</kanji> is one who leads his flock around through life. This is a <vocabulary>pastor</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>minister</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>clergyman</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Has the pastor already left the church for the day?
Context 1-JP: <jp>牧師さんはもう今日は教会を出ちゃいましたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:You see a child and walk up to him. Then, you punch him in the face (oh no, how could you!!?). He flies through the air, and he's knocked out. A ref nearby yells that it was a "<reading>KO</reading>!" (<jp>こ</jp>). That's a knock out.Make sure you learn this reading pretty well too. Both readings for <jp>子</jp> are going to show up a lot, and this is how you're going to learn the kun'yomi one.
Context 1-EN: You aren’t my real child.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたは、わたしのほんとうの子ではないの。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When that Russian kid grew up she got better than a salmon at swimming upstream.
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのロシア人の子は、大人になって、さけよりも上手に川を上れるようになりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t you think my kid looks similar to Beyoncé?
Context 3-JP: <jp>わたしの子、ビヨンセににているとおもわない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>Shamisen song</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to sing</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>歌う</jp> means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!
Context 1-EN: My uncle is a singing accordion player.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私のおじさんは、唄うアコーディオン弾きです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Since the kanji <jp>月</jp> means both "moon" and "month," what is the sixth month of the year? January, February, March, April, May, <vocabulary>June</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, this is a specific month, so it uses the <jp>がつ</jp> reading.
Context 1-EN: I went to Tokyo in June.
Context 1-JP: <jp>六月にとうきょうへいきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I will buy two katanas in May and test them at the Tofugu office in June.
Context 2-JP: <jp>五月に刀を二本かって、六月にトーフグのオフィスでつじぎりをします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The weather for June is cloudy with a chance of meatballs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>六月のてんきは、くもりときどきミートボールです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is <vocabulary>pasture land</vocabulary>. It's also a <vocabulary>ranch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"
Context 1-EN: In a few years my father will die and I’ll inherit his ranch.
Context 1-JP: <jp>二、三年くらいしたら、父親が死んで、俺は父さんの牧野を相続する事になると思うよ。</jp>

Meaning: To Give A Ride,To Give Someone A Ride,To Place On
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>ride</kanji> so this word has to do with riding. There's another word that's similar (<jp>乗る</jp> which means to ride). This particular one means <vocabulary>to give a ride</vocabulary>. Use the <jp>せ</jp> as a hint. The <jp>せ</jp> is a "sail" (<jp>せ</jp>) that you use on your boat to give someone a ride. How nice of you.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is kun'yomi (see that hiragana?) but that's the reading you learned with the kanji so you should be okay with this. Allow me to give you a ride to the next item to study.
Context 1-EN: It’s dangerous to let children ride in the passenger's seat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもを助手せきに乗せるのはきけんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Putting your feet on a table is bad manners.
Context 2-JP: <jp>机に足を乗せるのは行ぎがわるいですよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The man saw that the woman’s bicycle was completely destroyed so he offered to give her a ride back to town.
Context 3-JP: <jp>男は、女性の自転車が完璧に壊れているのを見て、「町まで車に乗せてあげるよ」と言った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I am the king of this country.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このくにの王はわたしだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please show me the King's sword.
Context 3-JP: <jp>王さまでもカレーをたべるのだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>grass</kanji> is the <vocabulary>pasture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grass</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: With <jp>草</jp> you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this <vocabulary>pasture</vocabulary> you have to constantly <reading>sew</reading> (<jp>そう</jp>) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.
Context 1-EN: It has been below freezing for days, so all my grass is dead.
Context 1-JP: <jp>氷点下の日々が続いているせいで、牧草が全てやられてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Any number with a <jp>つ</jp> attached is a word that means "NUMBER Things." In this case, it's <vocabulary>four things</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can assume it uses the kun'yomi reading. The <jp>ん</jp> part of <jp>よん</jp> gets converted to a small <jp>っ</jp> though, so watch out for that.
Context 1-EN: There are four oranges in this box.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このはこには、みかんが四つあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please give me four small onions.
Context 2-JP: <jp>小さい玉ねぎを四つ下さい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This morning, I ate four or five croissants.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今朝、クロワッサンを四つか五つ食べました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When the thing that is <kanji>exit</kanji>ing is <kanji>blood</kanji>, you are probably <vocabulary>bleeding</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <jp>しゅつ</jp> from <jp>出</jp> gets shortened to <jp>しゅっ</jp>. That's a small <jp>つ</jp> there, not a big one.
Context 1-EN: The bleeding won’t stop.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なかなか出血が止まりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu is providing you with a huge discount!
Context 2-JP: <jp>Tofuguはぜっさん出血大サービス中です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think my nose would stop bleeding if I kept my finger out of it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>指を抜いていれば、鼻からの出血は止まると思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>livestock farm</vocabulary>. It's also a <vocabulary>ranch</vocabulary>. The place where things pasture is this place.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This farm boasts a good ice cream shop that uses fresh milk.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この牧場には、絞り立ての牛乳を使った自慢のアイスクリーム屋さんがあるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: As an alone single kanji vocab, you know that this vocab word has the same meaning as its parent kanji: <vocabulary>Ball</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned when learning the kanji: たま.
Context 1-EN: I played ball-toss during sports day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うんどうかいで玉入れをしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are nine white balls here.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ここに、白の玉が九つあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Have you ever seen an animal that looks like a ball of wool?
Context 3-JP: <jp>けいとの玉のようなどうぶつをみかけませんでしたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you see a katakana word, it's a safe bet that it is a foreign loan word from somewhere else. This one's interesting, because it combines katakana and kanji! The first <vocabulary>marble</vocabulary> came to Japan from Portugal, so the <jp>ビー</jp> part of the word is short for "vidro," which means "glass" in Portuguese. Anyway, don't get thrown off by that <jp>ビー</jp>. Maybe just imagine that your favorite marble is black and yellow like a 🐝
Reading Mnemonic: If you know katakana as well as the reading that you learned when you learned the kanji 玉, you should be able to read this. Just watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Let’s play a game that uses marbles.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビー玉をつかってゲームをしましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In America, there is a contest every January where French people who are good at marbles gather.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカではまいとし一月にビー玉をつかったゲームが上手なフランス人がつどうコンテストがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He gave me a single marble as proof of our marriage.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かれは、けっこんのあかしに一つぶのビー玉をくれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>interval of time</kanji> is just the <vocabulary>time</vocabulary>. As is often the case, if two similar meaning kanji are combined into one word, they tend to produce a word with a similar meaning. Excuse me, friend, what's the <jp>時間</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When do you have time, professor?
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生はいつ時間がありますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Are there any available spots for a checkup this afternoon?
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日の午後でしんさつしてもらえる時間ってありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Superman then asked Aquaman the most serious question, "Do we have enough time to go on the waterslides again?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>スーパーマンは、アクアマンに、最も真剣な質問をした。「もう一度、ウォータースライダー に乗る時間、ある？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is really just <vocabulary>every time</vocabulary>. Do you get your kanji readings correct <jp>毎回</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I enter this marathon every time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このマラソン大会には、毎回出じょうしています。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは毎回ミーティングのと中でクネクネうごく。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Every time I try to smile, my gums start bleeding.
Context 3-JP: <jp>笑おうとすると、毎回歯茎から血が出始める。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>family name</kanji> because it goes after a family name in very formal situations. So, it's really closely tied to that. Because only men got the respect back in the day, we're calling this vocab word <vocabulary>mister</vocabulary>. You can call me Mr. Koichi if you'd like, too.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji.
Context 1-EN: As we all know, Mr. Abe’s statements never change.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やはり、アベ氏のはつげんはいつも全くブレませんね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Mr. Koichi and Mr. Viet have good chemistry.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチ氏とビエト氏はとても気が合う。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Yo, Mr. White, why don’t you just sit down?
Context 3-JP: <jp>おお、ホワイト氏、ちょっと座れば？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This counter is used to count musical <vocabulary>beat</vocabulary>s when you're listening to or playing music.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: For music in four-four time, the stress usually comes to a head at the first and third beats.
Context 1-JP: <jp>4分の4拍子の曲では、通常、1拍目と3拍目の頭に強拍が来ます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He used to be a cheerful young man.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はかつては明朗快活な青年だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>printing</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to print</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.
Context 1-EN: How many New Year’s cards should we print this year?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今年は年賀状何枚刷ればいいかなあ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the na-adjective version of <kanji>bright</kanji>. The word is <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cheerful</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Of all the people who are bright and cheerful, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk <reading>Hoga</reading>n (<jp>ほが</jp>).
Context 1-EN: I got an international call from someone I didn’t know with a melodious voice.
Context 1-JP: <jp>朗らかな声をした知らない人から国際電話がかかってきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>full</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> is a <vocabulary>high tide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>full tide</vocabulary>. That's when the water comes up.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Is high tide the best time to go fishing?
Context 1-JP: <jp>一番釣りに適しているのは満潮時でしょうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something is in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of an action but it's <kanji>stop</kanji>ped, this means it's put into <vocabulary>suspension</vocabulary>. Imagine getting frozen while you're running. It's kind of like that.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The baseball game was called off due to rain.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やきゅうのしあいは、あめで中止になりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Sorry, but it was decided that this project will be canceled for now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ざんねんですが、このきかくはいったん中止することになりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The live show I had been looking forward to was canceled.
Context 3-JP: <jp>たのしみにしていた生ほうそうが中止になった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji that makes up this word. Lucky you!
Context 1-EN: She suddenly lost consciousness.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かのじょはとつぜん、気をうしなった。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>気をつけてかえってきてね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Are you out of your mind?

Meaning Mnemonic: If someone asks you to <kanji>alternate</kanji> what you're doing <kanji>again</kanji>, they want you to <vocabulary>change</vocabulary>. You need to <vocabulary>switch</vocabulary> it up if you want to make them happy, or they'll just ask you to redo it again.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We’re looking for a replacement supervisor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>監督の更迭が求められている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>tide</kanji>s <kanji>stream</kanji> is the stream going through the tide. It's the <vocabulary>tide</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>tidal current</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It’s not easy to row against the rough tide, but that’s the only way for us to get back to our cottage.
Context 1-JP: <jp>荒い潮流に逆らってボートを漕ぐのは簡単ではないが、コテージに戻るにはそれしか方法がない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>rights</kanji> of the <kanji>majesty</kanji> are clear. His and Her Majesty have <vocabulary>authority</vocabulary> over all in the realm.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He's awfully persistent as he still clings to his faded glory even though he lost his authority.
Context 1-JP: <jp>権威を失ったのにまだ過去の栄光にしがみついていて、全く往生際が悪いったらありゃしないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.Note that for the word fence in Japanese, <jp>フェンス</jp> is typically used. <jp>垣</jp> isn't very common but it's sometimes used in literature.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The girl built a wall around her heart.
Context 1-JP: <jp>少女は心に垣をめぐらせていた。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It was necessary to build a hedge to prevent wild animals from destroying the fields.
Context 2-JP: <jp>野生動物に畑を荒らされないように垣を造る必要があった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A strong fence of stone and wood was built around the castle.
Context 3-JP: <jp>城の周りに石や木で強固な垣が築かれた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hedge</kanji> (or <kanji>fence</kanji>) <kanji>root</kanji> is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a <vocabulary>hedge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fence</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With <jp>垣</jp> that's the one you learned and with <jp>根</jp> that's the vocab version of the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The man placed his prosthetic hand gently on the hedge.
Context 1-JP: <jp>男は垣根の上にそっと義手を置きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: At <kanji>night</kanji> you are <kanji>serve</kanji>d an <vocabulary>evening drink</vocabulary>. It's okay to have a strong <vocabulary>drink with dinner</vocabulary> every now and then.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I’m holding back from evening drinks because of my diet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ダイエットのために晩酌を控えています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>old</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>old</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>ancient</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>out-of-date</vocabulary>.This word is used for things like clothes, food and friendships, but not for people! So a <jp>古い友人</jp> (old friend) is someone you've been friends with for a long time, not an elderly friend.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji with some hiragana attached, it's going to use the kun'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi when learning the kanji portion, so let's use a mnemonic to help you with the reading of this word: If you're <vocabulary>old</vocabulary>, you're also <reading>full</reading> (<jp>ふる</jp>) of memories. And you're probably full of old secrets. And you're full from old people food.
Context 1-EN: Those clothes are old, so I don’t need them anymore.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのふくは古いので、もういりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you hold onto old stuff, you can't get anything new.
Context 2-JP: <jp>古いものにしがみついていては、あたらしいものをうけとることができません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I found an old pair of underwear in our garage.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ガレージで、古いパンツをみつけた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is one outside of your own country. That is a <vocabulary>foreign country</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>other countries</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>overseas</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We haven’t gone to other countries yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしたちはまだ外国に行ったことがありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is my first time making an overseas call.
Context 2-JP: <jp>外国へでんわをするのはこれがはじめてです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wouldn’t mind being a celebrity if I was in a foreign country.
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし外国にいるなら、有名人になっても構わない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>dwelling</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is the place you live. How do you identify one's dwelling place? By using the <vocabulary>address</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word is made up of the on'yomi readings that you've already learned with the kanji. Have at it!
Context 1-EN: Please write down your home address here.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こちらにあなたの家の住所をかいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Can you please give me your address so I can send you a Christmas card?
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリスマスカードをおくりたいので住所をおしえてくれませんか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Does the land I purchased on the Moon have an address? I want to mail myself some oxygen tanks.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私が月に購入した土地には、住所はありますか？自分宛に酸素を送りたいので、よろしくお願い致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>sharpen</kanji> <kanji>research</kanji> you're just doing a <vocabulary>study</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>investigation</vocabulary>. Or in other words, you're doing <vocabulary>research</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I was so absorbed in my research that when I noticed it was already past 12 o'clock.
Context 1-JP: <jp>研究にねっ中しすぎて、気がついたら12時をすぎていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm a Tofugu researcher taking part in the study of biopharmaceutical production.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしは、トーフグの研究者で、バイオ医やくひんのせいぞう研究にたずさわっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We are currently accepting applicants to participate in our research study of Titans.
Context 3-JP: <jp>現在、我々の巨人に関する研究に参加を希望する申込者を受付けている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take my <kanji>majesty</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it. Your majesty is so stretched! That makes me so proud! That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be proud</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be arrogant</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is from <jp>威</jp> and <jp>張る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Kenichi acts like the top dog of the company and he's being really arrogant.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ケンイチは会社のトップのような顔をして威張ってる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>アメリカ</jp> part is pretty easy so long as you know katakana. It's the word for "America." You know that <kanji>人</kanji> means "person," so you can figure out that America + Person = <vocabulary>American</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>あめりかじん</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>アメリカじん</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: あめりかじん,アメリカじん
Reading Mnemonic: Often times when two kanji come together to form a combo kanji you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. So, the reading of <jp>人</jp> is the on'yomi reading <jp>じん</jp>, which you learned already in the kanji. This pattern works with almost any location as well. Just add a country name + <jp>人</jp> and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.
Context 1-EN: Am I American?
Context 1-JP: <jp>おれはアメリカ人か？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I made friends with an American girl.
Context 3-JP: <jp>アメリカ人の女とともだちになった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned when learning the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I was born in Osaka City.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大阪市で生まれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The new mascot of the city has been decided.
Context 2-JP: <jp>市のあたらしいマスコットキャラクターがけっていしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I puked on a Kyoto city bus.
Context 3-JP: <jp>きょうとの市バスの中で、はいてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look at your younger brother. He's a scheming one. He's smiling up at you. Why? Because he's lit a firecracker on your foot. It explodes, sending your toe flying. You yell <reading>"OH. Toe? TOE!"</reading> (<jp>おとうと</jp>) as you realize what's going on.
Context 1-EN: My little brother doesn’t watch TV.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの弟は、テレビを見ない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That young man with blue hair is my younger brother.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その青いかみの青年はぼくの弟です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I ended up going to the hospital last night because my younger brother threw a pool ball at my head.
Context 3-JP: <jp>弟がビリヤードのボールを頭に投げつけてきたので、昨夜僕は病院に行くはめになった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you think about <kanji>direct</kanji> <kanji>go</kanji>ing (aka transportation) how would you make it better? You'd make it so everything was <vocabulary>nonstop</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>direct</vocabulary>. Just imagine how much nicer it would be if every airplane you took was direct and you never had to stop. So nice!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The <jp>ちょく</jp> of <jp>直</jp> is shortened with a small <jp>っ</jp>, though, so make sure to take note of that.
Context 1-EN: This airplane is nonstop to Tokyo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このひ行きは、東京に直行します。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Today after the meeting with Japan, I'll go directly to the appointment with Tofugu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は、日本との会ぎの後、トーフグとのアポに直行します。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry, I can't talk right now. I’m on a nonstop trip to the bathroom.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ごめんなさい、今は話せません。トイレへ直行しているところなのです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sphere</kanji> of <kanji>majesty</kanji>, is the majesty someone has over a sphere, that sphere being a baseball, making this <vocabulary>a pitcher's stuff</vocabulary>, as in what he throws and how he throws it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As it gets closer baseball season in spring, that pitcher gets better at his pitches.
Context 1-JP: <jp>野球のシーズンが到来する春に近づくにつれて、あの投手の球威は益々増しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>blue</kanji>? It's still <vocabulary>blue</vocabulary>! It can also mean <vocabulary>unripe</vocabulary>, which might sound confusing, but it comes down to the fact that in Japanese there's some overlap between blue and green. So while in English we think of the "go" traffic light and unripe bananas as "green," in Japanese they're actually called "blue."
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to remember the <jp>あお</jp> portion to read this word. Think of <vocabulary>blue</vocabulary> things on your body. Those are bruises. Touch them. What would you say? <reading>OW!</reading> (<jp>あお</jp>).
Context 1-EN: There is a blue bird.
Context 1-JP: <jp>青いとりがいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That apple hasn't ripened enough yet, has it?
Context 2-JP: <jp>そのリンゴ、まだ青いんじゃないの。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wow, this blue paint smells exactly like the red paint.
Context 3-JP: <jp>うわっ、この青いペンキ、あの赤いペンキと全く同じ臭いがする。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Useful,To Be Of Use,To Be Helpful,To Be Of Service
Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>stand up</kanji> to do your <kanji>duty</kanji> you're standing up and finally being useful. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be useful</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>役</jp> is the one you learned with the kanji. The <jp>立つ</jp> reading is that of the <jp>立つ</jp> vocabulary, which you should be familiar with by now.
Context 1-EN: I found a website that is helpful for studying Japanese.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本ごのべん強の役に立つサイトを見つけました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Hungary there is a proverb meaning, "Running away is a shame, but it's useful."
Context 2-JP: <jp>ハンガリーには、にげるははじだが役に立つ、ということわざがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Would a sword be more useful than a gun for walking through a city full of zombies?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ゾンビがいっぱいの町を歩くなら、銃よりも剣の方が役に立つだろうか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Majesty</kanji> is <kanji>strict</kanji>. If you don't have <vocabulary>dignity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>majesty</vocabulary>, you won't be very majestic.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: He said that with dignity.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼はそれを威厳をもって言いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I show my <kanji>consolation</kanji> by <kanji>apologiz</kanji>ing. This is <vocabulary>consolation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do I have to declare the consolation money I receive from an insurance company to the revenue office?
Context 1-JP: <jp>保険会社から受け取る慰謝料は、税務署に申告する必要がありますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>discussion</kanji> is a little more formal than a friendly talk (because it's a discussion), but it's still fairly informal on the discussion scale, making it an <vocabulary>informal talk</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: She was tightly clutching her handkerchief throughout the friendly talk with the teacher on parent’s day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>授業参観日の先生との懇談の間、彼女はずっとハンカチを握りしめてていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>grate</kanji> (as in, "to grate" on something). The verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to chafe</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary>, which is pretty close.
Reading Mnemonic: If you're going <vocabulary>to chafe</vocabulary> on me like that, I'm going to <reading>sue</reading> (<jp>す</jp>) you. It's making me very uncomfortable.
Context 1-EN: Petticoats prevent skirts from rubbing against your skin.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ペティコートは、スカートが肌と擦れることを防ぎます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>chastise</kanji> but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to learn by experience</vocabulary>. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
Reading Mnemonic: As a <reading>child</reading> (<jp>こ</jp>) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).
Context 1-EN: You got turned down by her three times already and you still haven’t learned, have you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女に三度も振られてるっていうのに、お前まだ懲りてないのか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>paper</kanji> is a <vocabulary>letter</vocabulary> because letters are generally written by hand on paper.If you want a more graphic image, imagine writing a letter on your hand, and how much it would hurt to chop off your hand and send it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is double kun'yomi (body parts tend to make kanji in words change to a kun'yomi reading). Both kanji in this word had you learn that reading right from the start, though, so you should be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku making it <jp>がみ</jp>, not <jp>かみ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I sent a letter to a foreign country.
Context 1-JP: <jp>外国に手紙を出しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why don't you put up the letter from Kim Jong Il for online auction? I think somebody would buy it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その金正日からの手紙、ネットオークションに出しちゃえば？きっとだれかしらかうと思うよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to write a very heated letter to Coca-Cola and ask why there is so much sugar in their products.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はコカコーラ宛に、心のこもった手紙を書いて、どうして彼らの製品にたくさん砂糖が入っているのかについて尋ねたいと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>delicious</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. It also means "<vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary>" and "<vocabulary>clever</vocabulary>" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?
Reading Mnemonic: What's especially delicious? <reading>Horse</reading> (<jp>うま</jp>) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.
Context 1-EN: I found a really delicious okonomiyaki restaurant, wanna go with me next time?
Context 1-JP: <jp>めっちゃ旨いお好み焼きの店見つけたから、今度一緒に行かへん？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What happens when <kanji>light</kanji> travels a <kanji>year</kanji>? You have a <vocabulary>light-year</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It is four one hundred millionths of a light-year from the earth to the moon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちきゅうから月までは、一おく分の四光年です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If we go north from the center of Portland for four light-years, where will we be?
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポートランドの中しんから北の方に四光年すすんだら、どこにつきますか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: A light-year is the distance that light can travel over the course of one year. You are 10,000 light-years too early to be facing me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>光年とは、光の速度で1年間進み続け到達出来る距離だ。貴様が俺と対決しようなんて、一万光年早いわ。</jp>
