Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>three</kanji> <kanji>generation</kanji> is the <vocabulary>third generation</vocabulary>. You can use this alone to say you're third generation Japanese or you can specify and say you're third generation something else.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Louis III was a French noble.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ルイ三世は、フランスのきぞくです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Most of the third generation Koreans residing in Japan cannot speak Korean.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ざい日三世のほとんどはかんこくごがはなせません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I watch the anime "Lupin the Third" every day.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕はアニメルパン三世を毎日見ます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The parts we <kanji>need</kanji>. The <kanji>point</kanji> of that. That is the <vocabulary>point</vocabulary>. That is the <vocabulary>essentials</vocabulary>. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I think it would be a plus to understand the fundamentals of the book before the lesson.
Context 1-JP: <jp>授業前にその本の要旨を理解しておくと、プラスになると思うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>gentle</kanji> <kanji>path</kanji> is, surprisingly, <vocabulary>judo</vocabulary>. Yep, the sport / art based on throwing people around.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If you don’t know what Judo is, here is a book with a very brief introduction of it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もし柔道が何かを知らないって言うなら、ここに超簡単な入門書があるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>point</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>principle</vocabulary> of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word <jp>胸</jp> (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as <reading><jp>むね</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I explained the gist of our family policy and how my husband and I don’t want to let our kid read comic books to the teacher.
Context 1-JP: <jp>先生には、家庭の方針として、主人と私は子どもにそうした漫画は読ませたくないと思っているという旨を伝えました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Sink</kanji> and <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of <vocabulary>stagnation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inactivity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: A lot of laborers were laid off due to business stagnation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>景気の沈滞により、たくさんの労働者が首を切られました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Gentle</kanji> and <kanji>peace</kanji>. These are signs of <vocabulary>gentleness</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You didn't learn this reading of <jp>柔</jp> with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to provide a lot of <vocabulary>gentleness</vocabulary> if you want to touch something that's <reading>new</reading> (<jp>にゅう</jp>) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs gentleness.
Context 1-EN: That gentle looking barber over there is actually this area’s pimp boss.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あそこで柔和な笑みを浮かべている理髪師は、実はこの辺りのポン引き男どもの親分なんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>inside</kanji> your <kanji>body</kanji>... hmm, could be a lot of things, but we can generalize and just say it's <vocabulary>internal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do you know what function blood has within the body?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちが、体内でどんなはたらきをしているのかしっていますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The kabocha squash is high in beta-carotene and it's converted into vitamin A in the body.
Context 2-JP: <jp>カボチャに多くふくまれるβカロテンは体内でビタミンAにかわります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Blood circulates through the body regardless of whether it’s the body of a human or the body of a vampire.
Context 3-JP: <jp>人間の体か吸血鬼の体かにかかわらず、血液は体内を循環する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>next</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> you look at this kanji, you should know that it means <vocabulary>next time</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m looking forward to the next production.
Context 1-JP: <jp>次回の作ひんも、たのしみにしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is no next time. We only live once.
Context 2-JP: <jp>次回なんてないんだよ。人生は一どきりなんだから。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t worry, bro. We’ll get them next time, yo.
Context 3-JP: <jp>兄貴、心配するなよ。次回は絶対あいつらを仕留めてやろうぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something is <kanji>versus</kanji> the <kanji>outside</kanji>. Back in the day, everything was a battle with the outside. You had the Mongols... the rebels... and the foreigners. So, when you say something is "versus the outside" you're just saying it's something compared to where you are right now. It's something that's <vocabulary>foreign</vocabulary> or from <vocabulary>overseas</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How did Japan’s foreign policy change postwar?
Context 1-JP: <jp>せん後、日本の対外せいさくはどのようにかわっていったのでしょうか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are recording a podcast about Japan's foreign policy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本の対外せいさくについてのポッドキャストをレコーディングしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Is it just a coincidence that my personal debt shot past $5 million when America’s foreign debt shot past $500 billion?
Context 3-JP: <jp>アメリカの対外債務が5000億ドルを突破した時に、俺の個人負債が500万ドルを突破したのは、単なる偶然なのか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have <kanji>strong</kanji> <kanji>power</kanji>. This is your <vocabulary>strength</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This glue is pretty strong, so please be careful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このボンドは、かなり強力なので気をつけてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was taught how to make a powerful, mini water pump.
Context 2-JP: <jp>強力なミニウォーターポンプの作り方をおしえてもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When I look at her, I feel as though I have the strength of ten men.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼女を見つめると、まるで十人力ぐらい強力になったように感じる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it's supposed to use the kun'yomi reading. But, there is no useful kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so even the single kanji vocab word version uses the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned!
Context 1-EN: I’ve watched this movie three and a half times.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしはこのえいがを三かい半みました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is only a month and a half left until the JLPT.
Context 2-JP: <jp>JLPTまであと一ヵ月半しかありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She is as cute as a half-cooked egg.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かの女は半じゅくたまごのようにかわいいね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji>... once known of as a mystical thing that kept us from flying into space. Now we know this is the <vocabulary>air</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>atmosphere</vocabulary>, though, because that's what a bunch of air between the earth and space is called. <jp>ここの空気はいいね！</jp>
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Please just take the hint.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ちょっとは空気をよんでください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The morning winter air is cold.
Context 2-JP: <jp>冬のあさの空気はつめたい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The monkey in the pirate’s space ship will be reentering the atmosphere in 3 hours. He can’t wait to draw as much air into his lungs as possible.
Context 3-JP: <jp>海賊の宇宙船に乗っている猿は、三時間後に大気圏に突入する予定だ。猿は、肺に好きなだけ空気を吸い込むことが待ちきれない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Win</kanji>, <kanji>lose</kanji>... both will happen in tonight's <vocabulary>match</vocabulary>! What a <vocabulary>showdown</vocabulary> it will be!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that <jp>ふ</jp> becomes <jp>ぶ</jp> because of rendaku here.
Context 1-EN: The match ended in a tie.
Context 1-JP: <jp>勝負は引き分けにおわった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is a contest decided by a single round.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは、一発勝負のコンテストです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think this is the year things happen for me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この一年は、勝負の年だと思っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>task</kanji> you're looking for a certain <vocabulary>action</vocabulary> and/or <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary>. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Remember when you learned the kanji for <jp>作</jp> and we said you'll see some that take just <jp>さ</jp> instead of the whole <jp>さく</jp>? This is one of those!
Context 1-EN: Teach me about the effects of alcohol.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アルコールの作用をおしえてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I learned Newton's third law of motion at school today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日、学こうで、作用・はん作用のほうそくを学んだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Does this cake-flavored medicine have any side effects?
Context 3-JP: <jp>このケーキの味がする薬には、副作用はありませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Relax</kanji> in <kanji>peace</kanji>. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly <vocabulary>peace</vocabulary>. You feel <vocabulary>security</vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Who would want to believe that horrible family would have eternal peace?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの忌まわしい家族が未来永劫安泰でいられるなんて、誰が信じたいと思う？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mud</kanji> <kanji>bog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bog</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>marsh</vocabulary>. Seems kind of redundant to call a bog muddy, but whatever.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, <jp>泥</jp> and <jp>沼</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I saw some green basilisk lizards, known as Jesus lizards, in a marsh in Costa Rica.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コスタリカの泥沼で、忍者トカゲとしても知られているバシリスクを見ました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Destroy</kanji> to <kanji>death</kanji>. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your <vocabulary>downfall</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ruin</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: If the super volcano erupted, we would not be able to escape destruction.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もしその超巨大火山が噴火をすれば、我々は滅亡を免れないだろう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Slap</kanji> that bug and <kanji>destroy</kanji> it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is <vocabulary>extermination</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We all support the eradication of drunk driving.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私達はみんな、飲酒運転撲滅運動をサポートしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>destroy</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to destroy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to annihilate</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You are going <vocabulary>to destroy</vocabulary> the <reading>hoe roe</reading>. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.
Context 1-EN: They are trying to ruin Japan by manipulating information.
Context 1-JP: <jp>奴らはメディアで情報操作を行って、日本を滅ぼそうとしているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: America is the <kanji>country</kanji> of <kanji>rice</kanji>. I guess this is from all those rolling plains and such we have. Another way to say America in Japanese is <jp>アメリカ</jp>, but this is another more formal (and older) way. "Rice Country" aka <vocabulary>United States Of America</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>United States</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>America</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>USA</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Do you know the name of the president of the United States?
Context 1-JP: <jp>米国の大とうりょうの名まえを知っていますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I never expected anything from the US anyways.
Context 2-JP: <jp>米国には元々何もきたいなんてしてなかったよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Many people immigrate to the United States solely for the super-size combos at McDonald’s.
Context 3-JP: <jp>多くの人は、単にマクドナルドのスーパーサイズコンボのために米国に移住する。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Nourishing</kanji> and <kanji>foster</kanji>ing. The thing that gives you this is <vocabulary>nourishment</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When you get a cold, eat nourishing food like soy beans or apples.
Context 1-JP: <jp>風邪を引いたら、大豆だとか林檎だとか、滋養のある物を食べなさい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>furnace</kanji> <kanji>heart</kanji> is the heart of the furnace. The heart of this particular furnace, the one we're talking about here, is the <vocabulary>nuclear reactor core</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Why did they try to hide that the core of the nuclear reactor had melted?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして奴らは原子炉の炉心が溶解してしまったことを隠そうとしたんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>break</kanji> and <kanji>destroy</kanji> something, that is <vocabulary>destruction</vocabulary>. That is <vocabulary>annihilation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The city was annihilated by the atomic bomb.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その都市は原爆により壊滅しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Extinction</kanji> where everything is <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed is <vocabulary>destruction</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>extinction</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Not all species of whales are endangered.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全ての種の鯨が絶滅の危機に瀕している訳ではない。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>high</kanji> <kanji>furnace</kanji> is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a <vocabulary>blast furnace</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I read in the newspaper this morning that the steel company is planning to build the world’s largest blast furnace.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝の朝刊で、その鉄鋼会社は世界一大きな高炉の建設を計画していると読んだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is the kanji <kanji>color</kanji> repeated twice (the <jp>々</jp> character just repeats the kanji before it). When you have colors and colors and colors, you have a lot of variety. That's why this word means <vocabulary>various</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this kanji is just the kun'yomi reading twice. Since you've learned the kun'yomi reading already, you should be able to read this word as well. Nothing tricky about it.
Context 1-EN: I’ve read various types of novels.
Context 1-JP: <jp>色々な小せつをよみました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: After thinking about various things, I've decided to hold a takoyaki party on Sunday.
Context 2-JP: <jp>色々考えたけっか、日よう日にたこやきパーティーをすることにしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: There are various species of trolls that live under my bed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私のベッドの下に住んでいるトロールには色々な種類がいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If a <jp>原子</jp> is an <kanji>atom</kanji> and a <jp>炉</jp> is a <kanji>furnace</kanji>, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an <vocabulary>atomic reactor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nuclear reactor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Some people warned the government against building nuclear reactors.
Context 1-JP: <jp>原子炉の建設について、政府に忠告をした人もいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>philosophy</kanji> <kanji>scholar</kanji> (<jp>学者</jp>) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a <vocabulary>philosopher</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The philosopher had to hang on to his beret as he walked through the strong wind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その哲学者は強風を通って歩いたので、自分のベレー帽をしっかりと掴まなくてはならなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you have a certain <kanji>duty</kanji> then it's your job to play that <vocabulary>role</vocabulary>. You have to play the <vocabulary>part</vocabulary>. Like in a play!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, meaning you should be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi played the role of Kumaman in the drama.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチが、クママン役でドラマに出えんすることになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In order to prepare for the part, Koichi became a homeless for a year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは役作りのために、一年間ホームレスになってみました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Michael is throwing himself into the role very well, eh?
Context 3-JP: <jp>マイケル、めちゃくちゃ役になりきってるじゃん。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>握る</jp> is "to grasp"? This is the noun version, making it a <vocabulary>grip</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>握る</jp>, so get a grip on that!
Context 1-EN: Angry Koichi banged on the desk with his clenched fists.
Context 1-JP: <jp>怒ったコウイチは、握りこぶしで机をバンバン叩いた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have the kanji <kanji>what</kanji> and <kanji>year</kanji>, as in: "<vocabulary>what year</vocabulary> is it?" This also means <vocabulary>how many years</vocabulary> too, depending on the context. As in: "<vocabulary>How many years</vocabulary> did you play soccer?"
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both the readings you learned with the separate kanji, meaning you should know them. How many years have you been studying kanji now? You should be able to read this one.
Context 1-EN: What year were you born?
Context 1-JP: <jp>何年生まれですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What year did your kid enter college?
Context 2-JP: <jp>おたくのお子さんは、何年に大学に入りましたか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How many years did the American Civil War last?
Context 3-JP: <jp>アメリカの南北戦争は、何年間続いたんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>泊まる</jp> is "to stay the night." The noun version is a <vocabulary>overnight stay</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleepover</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>泊まる</jp>, so pull from that and you shall know this.
Context 1-EN: My kid was really looking forward to the kindergarten sleepover, but he got a cold and I just made him take antibiotics. So, sadly, he’ll be absent tonight.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの子、幼稚園のお泊まり会をすごく楽しみにしてたんだけど、風邪を引いちゃって、今抗生物質を飲ませたところなんです。だから、残念ながら今夜は欠席させて頂きます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shake</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shake</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>揺る</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Viet held onto the branch because Koichi shook the tree.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチが木を揺さぶったので、ビエットは枝に掴まった。</jp>

Meaning: To Let Someone Stay Over,To Let Someone Stay The Night
Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>泊まる</jp> is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this <vocabulary>to let someone stay over</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to let someone stay the night</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>泊まる</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I don’t want to have some stranger stay at our house.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちに知らない人を泊めるのは嫌です。</jp>

Meaning: To Be In A Hurry,To Be Impatient
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is <kanji>char</kanji>, and a previous word you learned (<jp>焦げる</jp>) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going <vocabulary>to be in a hurry</vocabulary> and you're going <vocabulary>to be impatient</vocabulary>. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, <jp>る</jp>, which stands for <reading>ru</reading>de. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.
Reading Mnemonic: You're being rude, but you're also being a big <reading>ass</reading> (<jp>あせ</jp>) with your impatience.
Context 1-EN: Take your time. Other than needing to pee, there is no rush. One day at a time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>焦るなよ。小便に行きたい以外は、急ぐ必要はないよ。一日一日を着実にな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wild</kanji> <kanji>wave</kanji> will make for some <vocabulary>stormy seas</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>raging waves</vocabulary>. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, <jp>荒</jp> (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and <jp>波</jp> (just the vocab version).
Context 1-EN: He is just a young boy who hasn’t been tossed in the stormy seas of life yet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アイツはまだ社会の荒波に揉まれた事のないただの若造だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>netting</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen door</vocabulary>. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.
Reading Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>網</jp> on its own. We're going to use that reading. Then, add the <jp>戸</jp> reading with rendaku and you have yourself <jp>あみど</jp>.
Context 1-EN: That old screen door is so gross!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの古い網戸は本当に気持ち悪いね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hand</kanji> <kanji>sack</kanji> is a sack for your hands... better put, these are <vocabulary>gloves</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are both the kun'yomi vocab readings, so think of <jp>手</jp> and <jp>袋</jp> as individual words, put together to make hand sacks. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: Why are you running around naked with only gloves on? You’re such an idiot!
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして裸んぼで手袋だけはめて走り回ってるの？あんたは本当に馬鹿ね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: A <vocabulary>chicken</vocabulary> is a <reading>newer </reading> (<jp>にわとり</jp>). Well, it's a newer type of <jp>鳥</jp> compared to falcons and condors that have been around for ages. But chickens have only been around as long as us humans. Making them newer birds.
Context 1-EN: The chick I raised became a chicken.
Context 1-JP: <jp>育てたひよこが鶏になりました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Let's take the <kanji>edge</kanji> and <kanji>discuss</kanji> it. That edge is the edge of getting married. But, when you reach that edge, before you jump over, you have to do a <vocabulary>marriage proposal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: How dare you to bring me a marriage proposal from a guy who has less than a high school education?!
Context 1-JP: <jp>高卒以下の学歴の男との縁談を私に持って寄越すなんて、一体どういう神経してる訳？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good luck</kanji> is <vocabulary>ominous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>sinister</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>bad luck</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>ill omen</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I had such an ominous dream that it made me really worried about you, and that’s why I called.
Context 1-JP: <jp>すごく不吉な夢を見たもんで、あんたのことが心配になってこうして電話をした訳さ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: In each political <vocabulary> wing</vocabulary> there are <reading>two boss</reading>es (<jp>つばさ</jp>). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.
Context 1-EN: Please pick up the wings you want to wear.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つけたい翼を選んで下さいね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>endure</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Those who are able <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary> are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The <reading>shino</reading>bi (<jp>しの</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Why do we have to endure their insults, dad?
Context 1-JP: <jp>父さん、どうして僕たちはアイツらの侮辱を忍ばなきゃならないの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>peach</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is a <vocabulary>peach color</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the vocab readings (and kanji readings, actually) of the two kanji.
Context 1-EN: I was embarrassed when my mom came to pick me up in the peach colored van.
Context 1-JP: <jp>桃色のバンで母親が迎えにきた時は、恥ずかしかったですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>spicy</kanji> <kanji>win</kanji> is a <vocabulary>narrow victory</vocabulary>. Kind of makes sense, right?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Tofugu won a narrow victory in a copyright infringement suit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>Tofuguは著作権侵害の裁判で辛勝しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Recreation</kanji> and <kanji>comfort</kanji> are things you do for <vocabulary>pleasure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>amusement</vocabulary>. So nice!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What’s wrong with reading light novels?
Context 1-JP: <jp>娯楽小説を読むことの何が悪いって言うんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>artisan</kanji> who is a <kanji>giant</kanji> in their field is a <vocabulary>master</vocabulary>! Everyone knows their name! Or, they're just really large... like tall, so everyone calls them a master cause they don't want to get crushed.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: This actress made many great masters grunt in admiration.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この女優は、多くの巨匠たちを唸らせた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>shout</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary>. Can also be <vocabulary>to scream</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start <vocabulary>to shout</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to scream</vocabulary> when you drink way too much <reading>sake</reading> (<jp>さけ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: "Turn the light off when you’re done screaming about your emotions." "Roger."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「感情を吐き出すために叫ぶのが終わったら、ちゃんと電気を消してね。」「了解。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>small animal</kanji> is <vocabulary>one small animal</vocabulary>. Use this to count small animals like cats and dogs.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening and the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: "Do you want to hang out with us tonight? Downtown Tokyo is crazy on Fridays." "I’m a lone wolf. Leave me alone."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「なあ、今夜俺たちと遊ばないか？金曜日の東京の繁華街はめちゃくちゃ楽しいぜ。」「俺は一匹狼なんだよ。放っておいてくれ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You walk into this town. You hate it (because it's vocab, and who doesn't hate vocab?). So what do you do? You pull out a <reading>match</reading> (<jp>まち</jp>) and burn this town to the ground. Whoa, you some kind of psycho?
Context 1-EN: There are a lot of convenience stores in this town.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この町には、コンビニがおおいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's dangerous to walk alone in this town at night.
Context 2-JP: <jp>よる、一人でこの町をあるくのはきけんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My town is famous for making the best invisible guitars.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の町は、最高のエアギターを作ることで有名です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Throw a "the" in there if you'd like, as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You've reached <vocabulary>the end</vocabulary> of the universe. Nothing is there. You step out, and you're surprised because you get greeted by an old Canadian man. <reading>Sue, eh?</reading>(<jp>すえ</jp>) he asks you, over and over. The poor man is looking for his wife Sue, and he's searched to the end of the universe. That's true love. As he walks off into the distance, you hear him calling out, "Sue, eh? Sue, eh? Sue, eh?"
Context 1-EN: If this kind of game is popular, then it’s the end of the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こんなあそびがはやるとは、世も末だな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You must be looking forward to seeing what your son might end up being in the future.
Context 2-JP: <jp>おたくのむす子さんは末が本当にたのしみですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After a heated discussion, my youngest son left to bury my gold somewhere.
Context 3-JP: <jp>激しい口論の末、末息子は私の金をどこかに埋めるために出て行ってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>close</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s are years that aren't too long ago. They are the <vocabulary>recent years</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There has been another boom in Japanese alcohol in recent years.
Context 1-JP: <jp>近年、日本しゅがまたブームになっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's a total lie that Disneyland hasn't been that packed in recent years.
Context 2-JP: <jp>近年のディズニーランドは、あまりこんざつしていないというのはかんぜんなるデマです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The existence of a tofu-eating fugu has slowly been coming to light in recent years.
Context 3-JP: <jp>豆腐を食べている河豚の存在が、近年徐々に明らかとなってきた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fishing</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to fish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I’ll let you know how many fish we caught later.
Context 1-JP: <jp>後で何匹釣れたかお知らせしますね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!
Context 1-EN: Fishing is his favorite pastime, just like his father. They say like father, like son.
Context 1-JP: <jp>父親同様、魚釣りは彼のお気に入りの気晴らしだ。蛙の子は蛙ってことだね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Extinction</kanji> caused by a <kanji>shout</kanji>. You are making everyone else's voices go extinct, and you <vocabulary>scream</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>shout</vocabulary> over them. You are making an <vocabulary>exclamation</vocabulary>, gosh darn it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening.
Context 1-EN: Someone screamed "brace yourself!" on the roller coaster.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰かがジェットコースターの上で、「覚悟しろ！」と絶叫した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Just be sure to know that this is the hair on your head.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I wonder if I should give my newborn baby a bath and wash her hair every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>生まれたての赤ちゃんは、毎日お風呂に入れてあげて髪を洗ってあげた方がいいのかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>hair</kanji> <kanji>fur</kanji> is the hair fur that's specifically on your head. It's your <vocabulary>head hair</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings, <jp>髪</jp> and <jp>毛</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: "Salmon, what are you doing right now?" "I am doing my hair." "After that, do you have time?" "Nope. I have to do my nails next."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ねえ、サーモン。今何してんの？」「髪の毛セットしてるとこ。」「終わったら、ちょっと時間ある？」「無理〜。これが終わったらネイルもしなきゃなの。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Below</kanji> the <kanji>ground</kanji> is <vocabulary>underground</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: There is a restroom in the basement of this building.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このたてものの地下に、トイレがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I ate a lot of food samples at the food section of the department store basement.
Context 2-JP: <jp>デパ地下でたくさんし食をしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The Apocalypse is coming soon so I’m building an underground cellar.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ヨハネの黙示録がもうすぐ実現されるから、私は地下室を建設しているのだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You pick up a <vocabulary>stone.</vocabulary> You throw it through a window. Huh. That was surprisingly <reading>easy</reading>.Do it again. Throw the stone again. It's so easy, just do it.
Context 1-EN: You shouldn’t throw stones at people.
Context 1-JP: <jp>人にむかって石をなげるんじゃない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A stone got in my shoe.
Context 3-EN: The sound of stones colliding annoys me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>石と石がぶつかるおとにいらいらする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I secretly put some edelweiss flowers on my girlfriend’s conical hat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は彼女の笠にこっそりエーデルワイスの花を飾りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji>. What is this witchcraft? The only way to talk via electricity is with a <vocabulary>telephone</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m talking on the phone with my family.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電話で家ぞくと話しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Sorry to call you so late at night.
Context 2-JP: <jp>夜おそくに電話してごめんね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wonder what ringtone Alexander Graham Bell had on his telephone.
Context 3-JP: <jp>アレクサンダー・グラハム・ベルが自分の電話の着信音を何にしていたのかが気になります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>cannon</kanji> is... wait for it... just a <vocabulary>cannon</vocabulary>. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The cannon went off with a bang and the man passed away leaving three children behind.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大砲がズドーンと鳴り響き、男は三人の子どもたちを残したまま逝ってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>teardrop</kanji>s is a feeling that makes you cry. But, it's not a bad feeling, these are <vocabulary>tears of gratitude</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When do you think people would burst into tears of gratitude?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どんな時に人は感涙にむせび泣くと思いますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like <reading>can</reading>.
Context 1-EN: My father works in a peach canning factory.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私のお父さんは桃の缶詰工場で働いています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>can</kanji> of <kanji>beer</kanji> (<jp>ビール</jp>) is a <vocabulary>can beer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>canned beer</vocabulary>. Not a bottled one.
Reading Whitelist: かんびーる,かんビール
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Oh, this canned beer is way too good for me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ああ、この缶ビールはマジでうますぎる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>can</kanji> <kanji>coffee</kanji> (<jp>コーヒー</jp>) is coffee that's in a can. That's <vocabulary>canned coffee</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>can coffee</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>かんこーひー</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>かんコーヒー</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: かんこーひー,かんコーヒー
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: They’re making a killing selling delicious canned coffee.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼らは、とても美味い缶コーヒーを販売して、大儲けしている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is <jp>かき</jp> <kanji>ice</kanji>, which is <vocabulary>shaved ice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>氷</jp> is the same as the one you learned (<jp>こおり</jp>) except it gets converted to <jp>ごおり</jp> because it comes after <jp>かき</jp>, so it's rendaku'd.
Context 1-EN: I eat shaved ice a lot in hot summers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かき氷は、あついなつによくたべられます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This shaved ice with red syrup is tomato flavored.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この赤いシロップがかかったかき氷はトマトあじです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The best feeling in the world is when you throw super cold shaved ice with syrup on someone you hate.
Context 3-JP: <jp>世界で一番いい気分になる時は、嫌いなやつに冷たいかき氷をぶちまけてやった時だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you have something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>correct</kanji>, you have no justice. In fact, you have <vocabulary>injustice</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself being put in an unjust situation, and think about how not correct it is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Who did something dishonest?
Context 1-JP: <jp>不正をはたらいたのはだれですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There was unauthorized access from China and all of Tofugu's social media accounts were hacked.
Context 2-JP: <jp>中ごくからの不正アクセスにより、トーフグのSNSアカウントがぜんぶのっとられてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My aunt always talks about her personal acts of injustice and deception.
Context 3-JP: <jp>俺の叔母は、いつも自分が今までにした不正やごまかしについて話をする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are the same. This word is a bit broader than <vocabulary>cow</vocabulary> though, and can also be used to be <vocabulary>bull</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ox</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it uses the kun'yomi reading. Here's a mnemonic to help you to remember it: You're leading the cows around the field. To get them to move, you yell out "<reading>USH</reading>, USH, USH!" (<jp>うし</jp>) because you have a speech impediment and want to say "MUSH MUSH MUSH." Go ahead and say this out loud, yelling it if you can.
Context 1-EN: Apparently Kyoko is raising a cow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きょうこさんは牛をかっているらしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: She came to a gyudon restaurant in a cow-spot patterned dress.
Context 3-JP: <jp>かの女は、牛がらのドレスをきて、牛どんやに行ってきました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Fugu calls me fat. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. (Literally: to talk about it while putting himself up on the shelf)
Context 1-JP: <jp>フグが僕のことをデブって呼ぶんだよね。自分のことを棚に上げてよく言うよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Grains</kanji> are made of single <vocabulary>grain</vocabulary>s. You can also use this to refer to a <vocabulary>bead</vocabulary> or use it as a <vocabulary>counter for grains</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You take all the <vocabulary>grain</vocabulary> and put it in a <reading>tube</reading> (<jp>つぶ</jp>). Just imagine doing this, grain by grain.
Context 1-EN: I wrapped a single grain of rock salt in a wafer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私は一粒の岩塩をオブラートで包みました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>book</kanji> <kanji>shelf</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bookcase</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bookshelf</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: I found a book in this bookcase about how to eat and run.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼の本棚に、食い逃げの仕方について書かれた本を見つけたんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word is so simple. <kanji>North</kanji> + <kanji>West</kanji> = <vocabulary>Northwest</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The airplane is heading northwest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ひこうきは、北西にむかっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you drive about an hour and a half northwest from Portland, you will arrive at a city called Seaside.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ポートランドから車で一じかん半ほど北西の方にいくと、シーサイドというまちにつきます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I lost my pantyhose somewhere northwest of here.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ここから北西の方角のどこかに、パンストを落とした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>grain's</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is even smaller than a grain. It's a <vocabulary>particle</vocabulary>, sometimes even an <vocabulary>atomic particle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I was thinking about whether light was a particle or a wave and I couldn’t sleep last night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>光が粒子なのか波なのかを考えていて、昨日は眠れませんでした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>thunder</kanji> <kanji>rain</kanji> is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think <vocabulary>thunderstorm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For <jp>雨</jp>, you haven't seen the on'yomi reading, which is <jp>う</jp>. To remember this, just think about how in a thunderstorm, it rains <reading>u</reading>ni (sea urchin). You go outside, dodging the thunder, to collect these uni.
Context 1-EN: The severe thunderstorm this morning caused a power outage, so I can’t use the internet right now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今朝の強烈な雷雨で停電になったので、今はインターネットが使えません。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Fish</kanji> <kanji>thunder</kanji> is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a <vocabulary>torpedo</vocabulary>. Load the fish thunder!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When I opened the package there was a homing torpedo inside it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>小包を開けると、中には自動追尾魚雷が入っていた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a <vocabulary>pagoda</vocabulary>. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I paid the deposit on a contract for a five-storied pagoda.
Context 1-JP: <jp>五重の塔の売買契約の手付金を支払いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: How do you usually cook the garlic shoots?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ニンニクの芽はいつもどうやって料理に使いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: To remember the reading think about thunder. Back in the day, it was probably terrifyingly loud. Like the cry of the gods! Wait a sec, the "cry of the gods" would be 神鳴り (かみなり).
Context 1-EN: The thunder reminded us that we had laundry to bring inside.
Context 1-JP: <jp>雷の音で、洗濯物を取り入れなくちゃいけないことを思い出しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When your <kanji>heart</kanji> is <kanji>relax</kanji>ed, how do you feel? What if this is after something startling happens? You would feel <vocabulary>relief</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>peace of mind</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That’s a relief.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これで安心です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I never know what that kid will do next, so I can't get peace of mind.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの子は次の行どうがよそくできないから、安心できないのよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I feel so relieved now that I know my dad no longer has cancer.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お父さんの癌が無くなったことを聞いて、とても安心した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: I felt frozen in the cold air at dawn.
Context 1-JP: <jp>暁の冷たい空気に、気持ちが張り詰めた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Eiffel</kanji> (<jp>エッフェル</jp>) <kanji>tower</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Eiffel Tower</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>えっふぇるとう</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>エッフェルとう</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: えっふぇるとう,エッフェルとう
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What did you like about the Eiffel Tower?
Context 1-JP: <jp>エッフェル塔のどんなところが好きでしたか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>バベル</jp>'s <jp>塔</jp> is Babel's tower. That's the <vocabulary>Tower of Babel</vocabulary>.
Reading: <reading><jp>ばべるのとう</jp></reading>,<reading><jp>バベルのとう</jp></reading>
Reading Whitelist: ばべるのとう,バベルのとう
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.
Context 1-EN: What’s the fastest way to get to the Tower of Babel?
Context 1-JP: <jp>バベルの塔に辿り着く一番速い方法はなんですか？</jp>

Meaning: To Tear Up,To Tear Off,To Split
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>裂く</jp> is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're <kanji>pull</kanji>ing it at the same time, you are going <vocabulary>to tear up</vocabulary> that thing, or more accurately perhaps <vocabulary>to tear off</vocabulary> something, since you're pulling.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>引く</jp> and <jp>裂く</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I’ll let you know if I succeed in splitting up the couple.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのカップルの仲をうまく引き裂く事ができたら、お知らせ致します。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>make</kanji>! What is your big make? Bigger than anything else. It is your <vocabulary>epic</vocabulary> (as in an epic that you write). Also could be <vocabulary>an epic</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>epic saga</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>masterpiece</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This movie is a Hitchcock epic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このえいがは、ヒッチコックの大作だ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The title of the most epic film this century is said to be, "A Life of Fugu."
Context 2-JP: <jp>今世き一ばんの大作ともいわれているえいがのタイトルは「フグの一生」です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Every score that Beethoven wrote was a masterpiece.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ベートーベンが作曲した曲は、どれも大作だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>襲撃</jp> is an <kanji>assault</kanji> or <kanji>attack</kanji>? This is the verb form, so it's <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to assault</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Little did they know they would be able to attack titans by air.
Context 1-JP: <jp>飛行機で巨人を襲撃することができるようになるとは、知る由もなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>距離</jp> is a <kanji>distance</kanji> and <jp>近</jp> is <kanji>near</kanji>. A near distance is a <vocabulary>short distance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Taxi drivers generally dislike short distant trips, don’t they?
Context 1-JP: <jp>タクシーの運ちゃんは大体みんな近距離乗車は嫌がるよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: My grandfather was gathering firewood in the mountains.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おじいさんは、山で柴刈りをしていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>stiff</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>stiff</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as a very similar word, <jp>固い</jp>. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!
Context 1-EN: I thought that it was the hardest bacon I’d ever had, but it was a dream and it seemed that I was biting my smartphone. No wonder it was so hard.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なんて硬いベーコンなんだと思ってたら、夢を見ながらスマートフォンを噛んでたみたいなのよね。どうりて硬いはずだわさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>一斉</jp> is <kanji>simultaneous</kanji> or <kanji>all at once</kanji>. Add the <jp>に</jp> in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes <vocabulary>simultaneously</vocabulary>. For "all at once" it stays at <vocabulary>all at once</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>一斉</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The temporary workers are worried about being fired simultaneously in the recession.
Context 1-JP: <jp>派遣社員たちは、景気の悪化で一斉に解雇されることを心配しています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>destroy</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be destroyed</vocabulary>. You know you're not destroying things because of the <reading>beer</reading> (<jp>びる</jp>). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.
Reading Mnemonic: "THE <reading>HORROR</reading>!" (<jp>ほろ</jp>) you cry, as your beer is about <vocabulary>to be destroyed</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: If the earth is going to be destroyed, why should I resist eating bacon?
Context 1-JP: <jp>地球がじきに滅びるんだとしたら、どうしてベーコンを食べるのを我慢しなくちゃいけないの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Bird</kanji> <kanji>skin</kanji> is <vocabulary>goosebumps</vocabulary>. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, <jp>鳥</jp> and <jp>肌</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I get goosebumps just from hearing the name "cockroach."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「ゴキブリ」という名前を聞くだけで、鳥肌が立ちます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Skin</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is <vocabulary>flesh colored</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>skin colored</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, <jp>肌</jp> and <jp>色</jp> combined into one.
Context 1-EN: The guy used high pressure sales tactics to sell me a box of skin colored crayons.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その男は強引な押し売りで私に肌色のクレヨンを一箱売りつけました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The person who's holding the <vocabulary>spear</vocabulary> is a little <reading>hoe </reading>. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a <vocabulary>spear</vocabulary> to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.
Context 1-EN: This beautiful spear is made from white gold and platinum.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この美しい矛は、白金とプラチナで作られています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>villain</kanji> who is <kanji>bad</kanji> is the most <vocabulary>atrocious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fiendish</vocabulary> villain of them all.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Everyone believed that the atrocious criminal would not fare well in prison.
Context 1-JP: <jp>誰もが、その凶悪犯が刑務所で大人しく刑期を務めるのは無理だろうと思っていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> was the previous approximate time, which is <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the other day</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's <jp>先</jp> and <jp>頃</jp> (the reading you learned) put together. The <jp>頃</jp> is the rendaku'd version, <jp>ごろ</jp> so be careful.
Context 1-EN: We’d been good friends until just recently, but he suddenly grew really cold toward me. I don’t understand why.
Context 1-JP: <jp>つい先頃までとても仲良くしてたのに、彼が急によそよそしくなったんだけど、理由が全然分からないの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>villain</kanji> <kanji>vessel</kanji> is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a <vocabulary>dangerous weapon</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: As he screamed, "Achooo!" Koichi knocked the dangerous weapon from Viet’s hand.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「アチョーーーーーー!」と叫び声を上げながら、コウイチはビエトの手から凶器を叩き落とした。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have the noun version of <kanji>hunt</kanji>. That is <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading uses the reading from the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I’ll be hunting in the mountains all of next week.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来週はずっと山で狩りをしている予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>year</kanji> <kanji>approximate</kanji> is your <vocabulary>approximate age</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading of the vocab version of <jp>年</jp> plus <jp>頃</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: What have you done with my adolescent daughter?
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの年頃の娘に一体何をしてくれたんだ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's <kanji>possible</kanji> that it's <kanji>considerably</kanji> considerable. It's <vocabulary>considerably</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>fairly</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>quite</vocabulary>... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I was quite surprised when I bumped into my first love in Japan.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本で初恋の人にバッタリ出くわした時は、可也驚きました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>足</jp>, which also means <vocabulary>leg</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>foot</vocabulary>.
Context 1-EN: My legs are restless at night and I can’t sleep well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夜になると脚がムズムズして、よく眠れないんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>well</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.
Reading Mnemonic: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for <jp>戸</jp>, but in this case it's rendaku'd so it becomes <jp>ど</jp> instead of <jp>と</jp>. You didn't learn the kun'yomi version of <jp>井</jp> with the kanji. Think of this <vocabulary>well</vocabulary>, and look inside. There you see an <reading>ea</reading>gle (<jp>い</jp>), stuck inside. As you pull it out, it scratches your eyes out.
Context 1-EN: When I drank cold water from the well, I got brain freeze like when I ate cold ice cream.
Context 1-JP: <jp>よく冷えた井戸水を飲むと、冷たいアイスクリームを食べた時のように頭がキーンと痛みました。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Pleased,To Be Satisfied,To Be Happy
Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>enter</kanji> into the <kanji>energy</kanji>. When you entering into (positive) energy, you are going <vocabulary>to be pleased</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be satisfied</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary> with something. Just imagine yourself entering into some happy energy when you see something you're pleased with. Smile and feel pleased as well!
Reading Mnemonic: The <jp>気</jp> portion is pretty straight forward. The <jp>入る</jp> reading is the same as the one you learned with the vocabulary <jp>入り口</jp>. Just imagine you're really, really, reeeally pleased with your lovely new pet <reading>ea</reading>gle (<jp>い</jp>)! You're so satisfied and happy with it. Feel the good energy your eagle is bringing you.
Context 1-EN: I’m very happy with this hat.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このぼうし、とっても気に入りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In order to please Prince Onion, I bought all the onions in America and built an onion palace.
Context 2-JP: <jp>玉ねぎ王子に気に入ってもらうために、アメリカ中の玉ねぎをかいしめて玉ねぎごてんをたてました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I hope you’re happy with your new puppy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君の新しい子犬が気に入ってもらえるといいんだけど。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>now</kanji> <kanji>times</kanji> is <vocabulary>this time</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I decided to pass this time.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今回は、やめておきます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I was the first place winner at this marathon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今回のマラソン大会では一いでした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll drive the fishing boat this time because last time you drove it, we almost ran into the shore.
Context 3-JP: <jp>前回お前が運転した時は、岸にぶつかりそうになったじゃん。だから今回は俺が釣り船を運転するよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: As long as you know both of the individual kanji meanings, you should be able to put together this one to get <vocabulary>five machines</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I bought five scales.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たいじゅうけいを五台かいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are five police cars parked in front of that house.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのいえのまえに、パトカーが五台もとまっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The five vans smashed into each other.
Context 3-JP: <jp>五台のバンがげきとつしてめりこんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something involves <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>country</kanji> you know it's <vocabulary>nationwide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>national</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The flu is spreading nationwide.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全国でインフルエンザがはやっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Which prefecture is the largest producer of apples nationwide?
Context 2-JP: <jp>リンゴのしゅうかくりょうが全国で一ばん多いけんはどこですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: He was involved in a nationwide cyber bullying scandal.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は全国規模のサイバーいじめのスキャンダルに関与していた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>heaven</kanji> <kanji>well</kanji> is the well that goes up into the heavens. This is above you, and it is a <vocabulary>ceiling</vocabulary>. Maybe the "well" part is referring to the chimney that goes up through the ceiling to the heavens when you look up in a super old house?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: One day I saw a small hole in the ceiling, then later I found out that I had a stalker who would occasionally peep at me through the hole from my attic.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ある日天井に小さな穴が空いてるのを見つけたんですが、ストーカーがたまに屋根裏に上ってその穴から私のことを覗いていたことが後から判明したんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What is <kanji>noon</kanji> <kanji>after</kanji>? That is <vocabulary>PM</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>afternoon</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What are the women going to do tomorrow afternoon?
Context 1-JP: <jp>女の人は、あしたの午後、何をしますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What's the closest time in the afternoon that's available for an appointment?
Context 2-JP: <jp>直近の午後で空いているじかんは何じですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have an appointment with my doctor at 3PM to remove an ingrown toenail.
Context 3-JP: <jp>午後三時に、足の巻き爪を取り除くためのお医者さんの予約がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have something that's <kanji>before</kanji> (or in <kanji>front</kanji> of) <kanji>noon</kanji>. What is before noon? That is <vocabulary>AM</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This department store opens at 10:00 am.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このデパートは、午前十じにひらきます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My son still needs to take a nap in the morning.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのむす子は、まだ午前中にあさねをするひつようがあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’ll be posting telepathically at 9AM today, so if you think of something funny, that was me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日は午前9時にテレパシーで投稿する予定にしているので、もし君がその時何か面白いことを考えたら、それは私の仕業だから。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>electricity</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji>. What is a really small part of electricity? What makes up electricity? That would be the <vocabulary>electron</vocabulary>. This word can also refer to things that are <vocabulary>electronic</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How much does an electron weigh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>電子のおもさはいくらですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: How long do you think it will take to fix the electric piano?
Context 2-JP: <jp>その電子ピアノを直すのに、どれくらい時間がかかると思いますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Mom bought me a microwave oven.
Context 3-JP: <jp>母親が電子レンジを買ってくれました。</jp>

Meaning: To Curse,To Put A Curse On
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>curse</kanji>, and the verb version is <vocabulary>to curse</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put a curse on</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: After my husband was diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder I cursed whoever it was that started the war.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夫が心的外傷後ストレス障害と診断された後、私はそれが誰であれその戦争を始めた人を呪いました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>study</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is an <vocabulary>academy</vocabulary>. That's where all the fancy people study, anyways.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I graduated from Tofugu Academy in 2014.
Context 1-JP: <jp>2014年に、トーフグ学院をそつぎょうしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Many students from Kwansei Gakuin University get to study abroad while at college.
Context 2-JP: <jp>かん西学院大学の多くの学生はざい学中にりゅう学をけいけんします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey! This guy is WaniKani, a.k.a. the Crabigator. He works for Tofugu Institute for Industrial Education.
Context 3-JP: <jp>やあ！こいつはワニカニ。あだ名はクラビゲーターだよ。トーフグ工業学院で働いてるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: When looking at a calendar, the <reading><jp>子読み</jp></reading> (<jp>こよみ</jp>) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.
Context 1-EN: Our company’s business days follow the regular calendar.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの会社は暦通りの営業になります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji for <kanji>death</kanji> and <kanji>body</kanji> put together make for a <vocabulary>dead body</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have to use or see this vocab too much.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Who found the dead body?
Context 1-JP: <jp>だれが死体を見つけましたか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Who did you say was arrested for abandoning a corpse?
Context 2-JP: <jp>だれが死体いきのようぎでたいほされたって？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The first time I saw a dead body was when I was six years old.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私が初めて死体を見たのは、六歳の時です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're <kanji>buddy</kanji>-buddy with the <kanji>master</kanji> of a <kanji>country</kanji>, you are rewarded splendidly. Why? Because this is a <vocabulary>monarchy</vocabulary> where being buddies with the master is a very advantageous thing!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Japan has an emperor, so is it a monarchy or a democracy?
Context 1-JP: <jp>天のうのいる日本は君主国ですか、それとも民主国ですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Ah, I'm finally back in this monarchy!
Context 2-JP: <jp>やっとこの君主国にもどって来たぜ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: The British Monarchy is long overdue for making another rap music video.
Context 3-JP: <jp>イギリス君主国は、別のラップ音楽のビデオを作る締め切りをまた大幅に過ぎている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Imagine someone riding a horse. Who is that person? It's <reading>Uma</reading> (<jp>うま</jp>) Thurman, the famous actress.
Context 1-EN: Is it okay to give that horse carrots and apples?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの馬に、ニンジンやリンゴをあげてもいいですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: My horse has overcome yet another difficulty.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの馬は、また一つこんなんをのりこえました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I find it unreasonably funny when old people fall off of horses one after another.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お年寄りたちが次から次へと馬から落ちたの、めちゃくちゃ面白いと思うんだけど〜！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>support</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need <vocabulary>to support</vocabulary> someone. In order to support them, you grab two saws. One saw and another saw. A <reading>saw saw</reading> (<jp>ささ</jp> combination good enough to do all the supporting you need - and maybe cut some supports too).
Context 1-EN: After all, it’s difficult to support a family on just my income.
Context 1-JP: <jp>やっぱり、おれのしゅう入だけで、一家を支えるのはきびしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The United States economy is supported by Tofugu.
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカのけいざいは、トーフグによって支えられている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: It was very fun for me to support myself up against the wall.
Context 3-JP: <jp>壁に寄りかかって体を支えるのがとても楽しかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>former</kanji> <kanji>calendar</kanji> is the calendar from before. It's the <vocabulary>lunisolar calendar</vocabulary> and the <vocabulary>traditional Japanese calendar</vocabulary>. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: When will it be the lunar calendar’s New Year?
Context 1-JP: <jp>旧暦の正月といえばいつになりますかね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>see</kanji> so the vocab here means <vocabulary>to see</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji (kun'yomi) so you should be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: In this problem, please listen to the questions while looking at the pictures.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このもんだいでは、えを見ながらしつもんをきいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I looked closer, the driver of the car the woman was in was my husband.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その女がのっていた車のうんてん手は、よく見るとわたしの主人でした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Can you please look at my hand and tell me if it is shrinking?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと僕の手を見て、それが縮んでいるかどうか教えてくれませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The name of the city (シアトル／しあとる) with a 市 attached to it means it is "the city of ____." You can do this with any city (try it out on your hometown!). So this word means Seattle, or more specifically City of Seattle.
Reading Whitelist: しあとるし,シアトルし
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses on'yomi reading, which you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I live in Seattle now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今はシアトル市にすんでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My mother grew up in Seattle.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしのお母さんは、シアトル市でそだちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I will send that funny picture of you to Seattle.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたのへんがおしゃしんを、シアトル市におくります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>skin</kanji> on the <kanji>meat</kanji> is kind of like the outer shell. It's not very nice, and people who eat only meat skin tend to use <vocabulary>sarcasm</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>irony</vocabulary>. That being said, Japanese people don't really understand sarcasm. So, maybe that's why "meat skin" means "sarcasm." Is this ironic? Now I'm not even sure.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: That’s really ironic, isn’t it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>まったく皮肉なものですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That butcher is a such a sarcastic person.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの肉やさんは、大した皮肉やだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Not one thing in the song "Ironic" is a proper example of irony.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「Ironic」という曲の中に、うまい皮肉はひとつも見当たらなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>brighten</kanji> your <kanji>research</kanji> it's like you're shedding light on it. To do that, you have to perform an <vocabulary>investigation</vocabulary>. This word is particularly used in academic and scientific situations.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Are you really going to investigate the truth?
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前は本当にしんそうを究明するつもりがあるのか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The true motive behind Koichi's strange words and deeds have not yet been brought to light.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチのおかしな言どうのしんのどうきはまだ究明されていない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: One of the classes I’m taking in college is currently investigating whether the chicken or the egg came first.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私が大学で取っている授業の一つで、現在「鳥が先か卵が先か」について究明しているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same with a little hiragana sticking out. Because the hiragana doesn't really indicate what it is, it's okay to assume that they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a kanji plus some hiragana attached, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Something is very, very <vocabulary>flat</vocabulary>. Perhaps someone who doesn't eat much, like a model? Which model? Let's imagine it's <reading>Tyra</reading> (<jp>たいら</jp>) Banks.
Context 1-EN: Put your PC somewhere flat, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>パソコンを、どこか平らなところにおいてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That girl put eight red marbles in a flat place.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その女の子は赤のビー玉を八つ平らなところにおいた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Do you remember the name of the pasta that is thin, long and flat?
Context 3-JP: <jp>平らで細長いパスタの名前覚えてない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>West</kanji>'s <kanji>calendar</kanji> shows the history and time period of "The West." To the Japanese and Chinese, this era is known as the <vocabulary>Christian Era</vocabulary>. It also used to be used as a way to refer to the <vocabulary>Western Calendar</vocabulary>, though we usually just say <jp>カレンダー</jp> nowadays.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: What year in the Western calendar did the Showa era end?
Context 1-JP: <jp>昭和は西暦何年に終わったんですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Some day you'll <kanji>run</kanji> around, <kanji>release</kanji>d from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary>. All your actions will be completely <vocabulary>uninhibited</vocabulary> when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because <jp>ほう</jp> becomes <jp>ぽう</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: I was attracted to his free and uninhibited personality.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの自由奔放な性格に惹かれてしまったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>enter</kanji> a <kanji>place</kanji>. So, you have been given (or forced) <vocabulary>admission</vocabulary> into this place. You have been given <vocabulary>entrance</vocabulary>. For example, "<vocabulary>admission</vocabulary>" into a prison is something you could gain by not doing your WaniKani reviews in certain Crabigator ruled countries.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My mother will be admitted to a nursing home next spring.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしの母は、来年のはるから、かいごしせつに入所することになりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please write down your admission date here.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こちらに入所年月日を記入してください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My yakuza boss is in jail now.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so don't get all feverish over this one.
Context 1-EN: I have a bit of a fever today so I can’t go out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は少し熱があるので外出できません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: OMG! I thought I was just a little feverish but my temperature is over 40 degrees!
Context 2-JP: <jp>なんてこった！ちょっと熱っぽいだけだと思ってたら、体温40度以上あるじゃん！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Touch this 500-degree-heat iron and write about your experience.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この五百度の熱を持った鉄をさわってみて、その体験を感想文に書いてください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You hopefully know that <jp>証明</jp> means "proof." So, when the <kanji>proof</kanji> is <kanji>written</kanji> down, what kind of proof is it? It's a <vocabulary>certificate</vocabulary> of some kind. I'm going to need to see some <jp>証明書</jp> if you want to get in here, sir.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing <jp>証明</jp>'s reading will also be helpful.
Context 1-EN: I forgot my bag with the certificate on the train.
Context 1-JP: <jp>電車の中に証明書が入ったかばんを忘れてきてしまった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do I have to show my credentials?
Context 2-JP: <jp>証明書のていじは必要ですか？</jp>
Context 3-JP: <jp>身分証明書をご提示頂けますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You <kanji>stare</kanji> at <kanji>hope</kanji>. It looks good. That is your <vocabulary>prospect</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>view</vocabulary>, as you stare at hope.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: We were able to view the beautiful blue ocean from our hotel room.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そのホテルの部屋からは美しく青い海を眺望することができました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>晩ご飯</jp> is "dinner"? Well, that word is so 12 hours ago. This is morning and in the <kanji>morning</kanji> your <kanji>meal</kanji> is <vocabulary>breakfast</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: <jp>朝</jp> is like the vocab version, <jp>あさ</jp> and <jp>ご飯</jp> is like the word you learned, <jp>ごはん</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My nose twitched when I smelled the delicious breakfast.
Context 1-JP: <jp>朝ご飯の美味しそうなにおいに鼻がひくひくしました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Our family always has rice, miso soup, omelets, and dried fish for breakfast.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わが家の朝ご飯は、ご飯と味そしる、玉子やきに干し魚と決まっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Did you just tell Koichi about his surprise breakfast party?" "Oh! I didn’t know it was a surprise."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇ、さっきコウイチにサプライズ朝ごはんパーティーの事を教えたでしょ？」「えっ！サプライズだったなんて知らなかった！」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>army</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Because there are American military bases in Okinawa, there are a lot of soldiers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おきなわにはアメリカ軍のき地があるから、軍人さんがたくさんいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That soldier's brave acts saved a lot of lives.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その軍人の勇気ある行動が、多くの人の命をすくいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My boss told me yesterday that I am going to be fired, so now I’m seriously thinking about becoming a soldier.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨日、上司に俺はリストラで首になるって言われちゃってさ。だから、今、軍人になることを真剣に考えてるんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Giving <kanji>evidence</kanji> (or a <kanji>guarantee</kanji>) that you will <kanji>preserve</kanji> something, is giving a <vocabulary>guarantee</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>assurance</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>warranty</vocabulary>.This word is used when the emphasis is on taking responsibility for something, as in a guarantor, a product warranty, or quality assurance.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I can't guarantee that your position will still exist when you come back next year.
Context 1-JP: <jp>来年もどってきても、あなたのポジションがあるかは保証しませんよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is no guarantee that I can strengthen the organization well.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うまく組織を固められる保証はありませんよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am a lifetime member of WaniKani, but I don't really think I can use it for life, as there is no guarantee that Tofugu will still be around in five years.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私はワニカニのライフタイムメンバーですが、トーフグが五年後もあるなんて保証はないから本当にライフタイムでワニカニが使えるなんて思っていませんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You're <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>naked</kanji>, which makes you <vocabulary>completely nude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>totally nude</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You only live once! Come on. You should go skydiving nude with me. It would be a great experience for us.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一度しかない人生だろ！なぁ！一緒に全裸でスカイダイビングしに行こうぜ。すんげぇいい経験になると思うんだよね。</jp>
