Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>status</kanji> of your <kanji>bones</kanji> (aka how they're all arranged and put together) equals your <vocabulary>skeleton</vocabulary>. That bone status is lookin' good on you!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that <jp>こつ</jp> changes to <jp>こっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I like a man with a sturdy build.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ガッシリした骨格の男性がタイプです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Yesterday, I completed an outline for this article.
Context 2-JP: <jp>昨日は、この記事の骨格をまとめ終えました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Is the rumor that cola is detrimental to skeletal development true?
Context 3-JP: <jp>コーラが骨格の発育に悪影響を与えるという噂は本当ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>morning</kanji> <kanji>sun</kanji> is not only the <vocabulary>morning sun</vocabulary>, but it's the <vocabulary>rising sun</vocabulary> as well (because that's when the sun rises, right?).
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which is convenient since you've learned both of them by now with the words <jp>朝</jp> (<jp>あさ</jp>) and <jp>日</jp> (<jp>ひ</jp>). Put them together and what do you get? <jp>あさひ</jp>!
Context 1-EN: Would you like to climb a mountain with me tomorrow morning to see the morning sun?
Context 1-JP: <jp>明日の朝、一しょに山にのぼって朝日を見ませんか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Why did you take the picture of the rising sun off of the wall?
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうしてあの朝日の絵をかべから外してしまったんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Japan is known as "the Land of the Rising Sun," which is excellently depicted on its "Rising Sun" flag.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本は「日出ずる国」として知られているが、それは「朝日国旗」に見事に描写されている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're <kanji>half</kanji> <kanji>naked</kanji> you're <vocabulary>half nude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>half naked</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Ahh! My dream just came true! It was the dream where a half naked hunk said "Good morning" the moment I woke up, while drinking freshly brewed coffee!
Context 1-JP: <jp>きゃー！たった今夢が叶っちゃった！半裸のイケメンが淹れたての珈琲を飲みながら、私が目を覚ました瞬間に「おはよう」って言ってくれるっていう夢が！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Letter</kanji> <kanji>rule</kanji>s can be found in a <vocabulary>character dictionary</vocabulary>. In Japanese, one kanji "letter" or "character" can hold a lot of information, so you have dictionaries dedicated to kanji meanings. That's what this is.This word is a little old-fashioned these days, so you might also see <jp>漢字辞典</jp> used for a character dictionary. (You'll learn <jp>辞典</jp> soon, if you haven't already!)
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Koichi demanded an explanation about the wet character dictionary from Viet.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ぬれた字典について、ビエトにせつ明を要求しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It suddenly started pouring rain and the kanji dictionary I was holding got soaking wet.
Context 2-JP: <jp>とつ然大雨になったので、手でもっていた字典がびしょぬれになっちゃったんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I bought this calligraphy character dictionary at a secondhand bookstore over there.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この書道字典はあそこの古本屋で買ったんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>money</kanji> (and <kanji>gold</kanji>) you <kanji>borrow</kanji> is your <vocabulary>debt</vocabulary>. Be sure to pay it back before the yakuza come for you.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <jp>しゃく</jp> gets shortened to <jp>しゃっ</jp> though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*
Context 1-EN: I wanted to have new experiences, so I got myself in debt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しいけいけんをしてみたくて、借金を作りました。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ビエトに五千万円借金している。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Excuse me, excuse me. I’m trying to get through here. I’m running away from a debt collector.
Context 3-JP: <jp>失敬、失敬、通らせて。借金取りに追われているんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>road</kanji> you <kanji>walk</kanji> on is the <vocabulary>sidewalk</vocabulary>... at least I hope that's where you walk.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Why can’t bicycles travel on sidewalks?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして自てん車が歩道を走ってはいけないんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: You are approaching the end of the moving walkway. Please watch your step.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まもなくうごく歩道がおわりますので、足元にごちゅういください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Bicycles should be ridden on sidewalks, not on busy city streets.
Context 3-JP: <jp>自転車は、忙しい車道じゃなく、歩道を走るべきだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>天気</jp> is weather (and how <jp>天</jp> often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have <vocabulary>dry weather</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Because of the continuous, twenty-nine day drought, Fugu is about to dry out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>れんぞく干天日数が二十九日をむかえ、フグは干からびるすん前だった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The long, cruel dry weather killed all the vegetables in my field.
Context 2-JP: <jp>無じ悲な干天がつづき、はたけのやさいが全てかれてしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The supply of bacon Koichi got for the starving workers was like a welcome rain after a drought.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチから腹ペコの社員への差し入れのベーコンは、まさに干天の慈雨だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>cold</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji (<reading>Sam</reading>urai (<jp>さむ</jp>)). Remember?
Context 1-EN: It's too cold to get out of bed.
Context 1-JP: <jp>寒すぎてふとんから出られない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I had to wait an hour in this cold for the bus.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この寒い中、一時間もバスを待たなきゃならなかったんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m going to Hawaii not only to escape the cold, but to see my family.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕がハワイに行くのは、寒さから逃れるためだけではなく家族に会うためでもあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen the word <jp>化ける</jp> (to transform) before. Now we have a similar word. This word means <vocabulary>to bewitch</vocabulary> because when you cuss (<jp>かす</jp>) you are saying a magic word and bewitching the person in front of you. Imagine yourself yelling out cuss words, and every time a new enchantment falls upon your victim.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>化ける</jp>, so make sure you know that word and you'll be able to learn this word's reading as well.
Context 1-EN: Tanuki and foxes are good at bewitching humans.
Context 1-JP: <jp>たぬきやきつねは、人間を化かすのがとくいだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My friend enchants men with makeup all the time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの友人はいつも化しょうで男の人を化かしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m sorry I’m late. I was bewitched by a fox." "No worries. Things like that can’t be helped."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「遅くなってすみません。いやあ、きつねに化かされちまってねえ。」「心配しないでください。それはどうしようもないことですからね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: What you <kanji>believe</kanji> in your <kanji>heart</kanji>, and not in your head, is your <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary>. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that <jp>しん</jp> changes to <jp>じん</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My mother believes in Buddhism.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の母は仏教を信心しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't really like her because she sanctimoniously criticizes people.
Context 2-JP: <jp>信心ぶって他人をひはんしてくるから、あの子のことあんまり好きじゃないんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: His family is very religious and spiritual, so they don't drink any alcoholic drink other than spirits.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼の家族はとても信心深くてスピリチュアルなので、他のお酒を飲まずにスピリッツだけ飲みます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: You are <vocabulary>naked</vocabulary> now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You <reading>had a ca</reading>r (<jp>はだか</jp>), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.
Context 1-EN: Gross! I just saw a naked dude wearing just a sleeveless apron at the crosswalk over there. Should we call the police?
Context 1-JP: <jp>キモイ！今あそこの横断歩道で、裸に袖無しエプロンを着た男を見かけたんだけど。警察に通報した方がいいかな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've probably seen the words <jp>知る</jp> and <jp>合う</jp> by now. This is someone you "know" because you have "come together" before, but that's pretty much it. You don't really know them well, you just met them a couple times so you know who they are. This person is an <vocabulary>acquaintance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are that of <jp>知る</jp> and <jp>合う</jp>. So long as you know those words, you should be able to read this one too.
Context 1-EN: I asked an acquaintance if they could get me Koichi’s autograph from Tofugu.
Context 1-JP: <jp>知り合いにたのんで、トーフグのコウイチからサインをもらいました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I’m consulting my acquaintance about my relationship with my boyfriend right now, so I probably won’t be able to join the karaoke party. Sorry!
Context 2-JP: <jp>今知り合いにれんあい相だんしてるから、カラオケには行けないかも。ごめんね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t tell a soul but my boss is having an affair with a married woman who is an acquaintance of mine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ここだけの話なんだけど、上司が知り合いの人妻と浮気しているのよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gamble</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gamble</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: She gambles considerable amounts of money at the horse races.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は競馬で、中々の大金を賭けるんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of the <kanji>world</kanji> is the <vocabulary>society</vocabulary>. It's what holds everything together, for us humans. You can also call it <vocabulary>the world</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. Why? Because this word is really two separate words connected together into one bigger word. You know the kun'yomi readings from vocab practice in previous levels.
Context 1-EN: There are many types of people in the world.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この世の中には、色んな人がいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In this society, not knowing the truth is sometimes better.
Context 2-JP: <jp>世の中には、しんじつを知らない方がいいことだってあるんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We live in a great society where pizza gets to your house before the police.
Context 3-JP: <jp>我々は、警察よりも先にピザが家に到着するような素晴らしい世の中に住んでいる。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji you learned, too, making this one an <vocabulary>ease</vocabulary> to learn!
Context 1-EN: You only think about taking the easy way out!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あんたはそうやって楽することばっかり考えて！</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>このいすめっちゃ楽だわー。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I am most at ease when I am with my dog, Toto.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は愛犬トトと一緒にいる時が一番楽です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>army</kanji> are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The <vocabulary>navy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: By my standards, I was almost too nice to you when we were in the navy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>海軍にいた時、おれ的にはお前には十分すぎるぐらいやさしくしてたつもりなんだけどな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: As an institution of this navy, if someone is genuinely sorry about something, they have to volunteer to clean the toilet to show their good faith.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この海軍のしきたりでは、本当に悪かったなと思って反せいしている人は、自らすすんでトイレそうじをすることでせい意を見せることになっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry I couldn’t catch your call. Believe it or not, I’m actually on a navy ship right now. I’ll call you when I get off.
Context 3-JP: <jp>電話に出れなくてごめん。信じられないかもしれないけど、実は今海軍の船の上なんだよね。降りたら電話するね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>finger</kanji> <kanji>ring</kanji> is the kind of <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, <jp>指</jp> and <jp>輪</jp>. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as <reading><jp>ゆびわ</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: I lost my precious ring and I feel awful.
Context 1-JP: <jp>大事な指輪を失くしてしまい、気分が晴れません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't get this ring off of my finger.
Context 2-JP: <jp>指輪が指から外れなくなってしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "When I get a bonus, I’ll buy you a diamond ring." "You always say that, but words are just words."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ボーナスが出たら、ダイヤモンドの指輪を買ってやるよ。」「あなたはいつも口先ばかりでしょ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>protect</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary> and also <vocabulary>to defend</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to protect</vocabulary> against breast cancer, so you get yourself a <reading>mammo</reading>gram (<jp>まも</jp>).
Context 1-EN: It may not seem like he's here, but he is always with you, protecting you.
Context 1-JP: <jp>分からないかもしれませんが、かれはいつもあなたのそばにいて、あなたのことを守ってくれているんですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's dog protected him from danger.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの犬は、コウイチを危険から守りました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Listen to me, my dog. It’s your responsibility to defend your family.
Context 3-JP: <jp>いいか、わが愛犬よ、よく聞け。家族を守るのは、お前の責任だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>action</kanji> of <kanji>eat</kanji>ing is when you have your <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m in the middle of eating a meal, so I’ll call you back later.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今、食事中なので、後でまたかけます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please relax and enjoy your meal!
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうぞごゆっくりお食事をお楽しみください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: If you could only have one meal every day for the rest of your life, what would you choose?
Context 3-JP: <jp>もし残りの人生毎日同じ食事しか食べられないとしたら、何を選びますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>announce</kanji> something and make it <kanji>white</kanji> is to make a <vocabulary>confession</vocabulary>. Think of a completely blank sheet of paper - your confession clears all the announcements from the sheet of paper, making it white.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: "Why did you take so long for the confession?" "Because I didn't know how to do it."
Context 1-JP: <jp>「どうして告白にそんなに時間がかかったの？」「告白の仕方が分からなかったんだ。」</jp>
Context 2-EN: Jamal has been publicly declaring that he is a fan of Dragon Quest, but recently, he finally confessed that he is a secret admirer of Final Fantasy.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ジャマルはずっとドラクエファンだと公言していたのに、最近ついにファイナルファンタジーのかくれファンだったことを告白した。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After getting an assistant position in a finance office, she confessed that she is actually bad at math.
Context 3-JP: <jp>会計事務所でのアシスタントの仕事を得た後に、彼女は実は数学があまり得意ではないことを告白した。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing and <kanji>talk</kanji>ing with each other. This is <vocabulary>English Conversation</vocabulary>. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My older brother is good at English conversations, but bad at calculations.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の兄は、英会話は上手だけど、計算は下手なんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Oh no, I can’t believe I failed another English conversation test. I’m so shocked.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まさか。また英会話のテストに落ちちゃったよ。ショックすぎる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I knew I made one mistake on the English conversation exam and I was so flustered that it ended up setting off another mistake.
Context 3-JP: <jp>英会話の試験でミスをしたことで動揺してしまい、さらに別のミスを誘発することになってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Take a look at your own <vocabulary>bone</vocabulary>s. They have been upgraded with special technology, allowing you to <reading>hone</reading> (<jp>ほね</jp>) in on targets, then shoot your bones at them. Go ahead and imagine yourself using this crazy new bone technology. Wolverine is jealous.
Context 1-EN: Let's aim with that bone as our target!
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの骨を的にしてねらおう！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Kristen acted calm even when she fell and broke her arm.
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリステンは、転んでうでの骨を折った時もれいせいに行動していました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Last night, I dreamt that I was burning the Tofugu office. In the ashes of the ruins, I saw a mountain of fish bones.
Context 3-JP: <jp>昨夜、Tofuguのオフィスに放火する夢を見たんだけど、焼け跡の灰には、大量の魚の骨があったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>fault</kanji> of <kanji>romance</kanji> isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience <vocabulary>heartbreak</vocabulary>. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: My heart was broken because of my flat, red nose.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぺちゃんこの赤い鼻が原因で、失恋しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Heartbreak is an everyday occurrence for me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>失恋なんて、日常茶飯事だよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m heart broken and it really hurts. I want to go shopping to get rid of my stress. Why don’t we go to the sale this weekend and have lunch together?
Context 3-JP: <jp>失恋しちゃって、超切ないよ。ストレス解消に買い物に行きたい。今週末バーゲンに行ってお昼も一緒に食べようよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Okay, so you <kanji>guess</kanji> but you also kind of <kanji>know</kanji>. You can make an <vocabulary>inference</vocabulary> as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that <jp>察</jp> gets shortened to <jp>さっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Last night, Viet detected unauthorized use of the computers.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨夜、ビエトがコンピューターの不正利用を察知しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet and his foot soldiers seemed to have sensed that the police would raid them.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトと手下たちは、警察の手入れがあることを事前に察知していたようだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Our baby is very sensitive to the emotions and anxieties of his mom, Salmon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>僕達の赤ちゃんは、母親であるサーモンの感情や不安をすごく敏感に察知するんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>change</kanji> so you'd think the verb version is "to change" but it's a little different. This word means <vocabulary>to transform</vocabulary>, which is a lot like "to change" but this is more like when a person transforms into something else, like a dinosaur.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You try to transform. You want to turn into something awesome, like a dinosaur, but then *poof* you turn into a sheep. "<reading>Ba</reading>aaa," you say. "Baaa."
Context 1-EN: She’s famous for transforming into a beautiful woman with makeup.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かの女は、化しょうをすれば、び人に化けることで有名です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That yokai can transform to a person.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あのようかいは、人間に化けることができる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My house was so completely transformed after the renovation that my son didn't know which home to go to after school.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の家はリフォームの後で全く違う家に化けてしまったので、息子は学校が終わった後にどの家に帰るのか分からなくなってしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The noun version of <kanji>gamble</kanji> is <vocabulary>gambling</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>betting</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a gamble</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a bet</vocabulary>. Whatever you do, put it all on black 13. Trust me.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: I won a bet against him.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつとの賭けに勝ったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Three</kanji> <kanji>books</kanji> equals <vocabulary>three books</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>name</kanji>s. These are the <vocabulary>kana</vocabulary> (that's hiragana and katakana). Why are the "temporary names" kana, though? Perhaps they were never meant to be a main way to write the names of the kanji... They are just a temporary way to write the name of kanji you don't know how to write the "correct" way (aka kanji)? That's just a guess, but it should help you to remember that this word means "kana," at least.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>仮</jp> is the one you learned with the kanji. The <jp>名</jp> portion is not, however, and uses its kun'yomi reading (<jp>な</jp>), which you saw with the kanji <jp>名</jp> (<jp>な</jp>). How to remember all this, though? Think of it this way: The people who made kanji really don't want you to know <vocabulary>kana</vocabulary>. It's bad for business. They want anyone who uses the word "kana" to suffer, so they decided to make one part on'yomi and another part kun'yomi. Don't let them get you!

Context 2-JP: <jp>ワニカニでかん字をべん強するのに、まずは仮名を全部知っている必要がある。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Could you add kana to all the kanji in this document, please?

Meaning: To Roll,To Tumble,To Lie Down,To Be Scattered About
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the kanji here means <kanji>revolve</kanji>. The verb version of this is similar. It means <vocabulary>to roll</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to tumble</vocabulary>. When something is doing these things it is revolving, right?

That's why they have it rolling down hill after hill, because they don't have anything else to keep it spinning like that, preventing it from exploding. This core is very important!If you have trouble remembering the hiragana ending, just imagine a <reading>girl</reading> (<jp>がる</jp>) rolling down the hill too.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Here's the <vocabulary>place</vocabulary>! Either you have to <reading>talk or row</reading> (<jp>ところ</jp>). If you talk, maybe you can talk your way out of this problem you're in. If you row, you may be able to escape. Either way, this is the place for it.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. What did you do at school today? I beat up this kid. "Oh yah?"

Meaning Mnemonic: The thing that is <kanji>attach</kanji>ed to your <kanji>face</kanji> isn't a big booger or anything like that. It's something that's always there. It's your <vocabulary>expression</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>ごはん</jp> is a food or meal (maybe you'll learn the kanji for it later, but it's not usually used, so you're learning it this way now). What is your <kanji>morning</kanji> meal? That is <vocabulary>breakfast</vocabulary> (not to be confused with second breakfast, you hobbit).

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Hand</kanji>s <kanji>beat</kanji>ing together is actually <vocabulary>applause</vocabulary>. Though... you might be doing it wrong if you're actually beating them together.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>練習</jp>, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to practice</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word <jp>練習</jp>. You should be able to read this!

Context 2-JP: <jp>「おんをあだで返すような子に育てたおぼえはないよ！」というしばいのセリフを言うのを練習しています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Dude, we were absolutely crushed." "Yeah, it was a complete failure. I guess we need more practice."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「俺達、惨敗しちまったな。」「ああ、惨敗しちまった。もっとたくさん練習しないとな。」</jp>

Meaning: Amount Of Time,Interval Of Time,Time Interval,Period Of Time
Meaning Mnemonic: When you stick this onto the end of another word that talks about an <kanji>interval of time</kanji> in some way, you're indicating the <vocabulary>amount of time</vocabulary> that has gone past. For example, <jp>二年間</jp> is "two years." <jp>一時間</jp> is "one hour." Any amount of time + <jp>〜間</jp> will make it an "amount of time" instead of just a specific time.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. This should save you at least <jp>二分間</jp>.
Context 1-EN: When I came to, I had been sleeping for almost five hours.
Context 1-JP: <jp>気がついたら、五時間ぐらいねむっていました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: For heaven's sake, can't you just be quiet for three minutes?
Context 2-JP: <jp>たのむから三分間だけだまっててくれないか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: The test involved having to hold my breath for fixed intervals of time. The most difficult one was for 3 hours, but I did it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>試験の中に、一定時間息を止めるというものがありました。一番難しかったのは、三時間息を止めるというものだったけれど、私はなんとかやり切りました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>copy</kanji> of <kanji>reality</kanji> is a lot like magic. How do you make a copy of reality, though? You take a <vocabulary>photo</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>dangerous</kanji> and <kanji>risky</kanji> is probably pretty <vocabulary>risky</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>dangerous</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>unsafe</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: Don't let this word confuse you. It may end in <jp>い</jp>, but it's not an adjective, it's a noun. There are no rules in war, after all. This word describes what happens in <kanji>war</kanji>. Those things are <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>fight</vocabulary>s, and <vocabulary>conflict</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In a fierce <vocabulary>battle</vocabulary>, there's always a lot of collateral damage. One of the things that gets destroyed is your car. But you can't do anything about it, it's battle time! So you wave goodbye to your car saying, "<reading>Ta ta ca</reading>r (<jp>たたか</jp>)!" as you punch some jerk in the face.
Context 1-EN: Koichi looks like a battle-weary soldier today.

Context 2-EN: Whether it's quiet or noisy, I still don't like conflict.

Context 3-EN: On the way to McDonald’s he got in a bloody fight but that didn’t stop him from getting his Big Mac.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼はマクドナルドに行く途中、血みどろの戦いに遭遇したが、その後そのままビッグマックを食べに行った。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>dark</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>dark</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're thrown into something <vocabulary>dark</vocabulary> and small. A lid is closed on top of you, and you are confused. What have you been thrown in? You find out you've been thrown in a <reading>cooler</reading> (<jp>くら</jp>). Feel afraid like you would be if you were thrown in such a dark cooler like this. Is it cold?
Context 1-EN: Can you make your iPhone screen a bit darker, please?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もうちょっとiPhoneの画面を暗くしてくれませんか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard that Mr. Tanaka has nyctophobia, so he can't sleep in a dark room.
Context 2-JP: <jp>田中さんは暗やみきょうふしょうなので、部屋が暗いとねむれないんですって。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Everything in the news has been depressing lately, but there is a great big silver lining to this dark cloud, you know. And... well... I kind of lost my train of thought, but, anyway, will you marry me?
Context 3-JP: <jp>最近、暗いニュースばっかりだけど、こんな暗い世の中でも滅茶苦茶良いことだってあるんだよ。えっと、それで…うーん。何を言いかけたのか忘れちゃったんだけど、とにかく、僕と結婚してくれませんか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>action</kanji> of <kanji>truth</kanji> is just <vocabulary>truth</vocabulary> itself, though it's also <vocabulary>fact</vocabulary>s and <vocabulary>reality</vocabulary> as well. Really, it's the idea of "truth" in a way.

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>学生</jp> is "student"? This plays off that. A <kanji>cram school</kanji> "student" is a student of a cram school, a <vocabulary>cram school student</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: The things you <kanji>wear</kanji> <kanji>below</kanji> your other clothes. That is your <vocabulary>underwear</vocabulary>. You do wear underwear, right?
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. <jp>着</jp> uses the reading you learned with <jp>着る</jp>, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that <jp>き</jp> becomes <jp>ぎ</jp> here.

Context 3-JP: <jp>どの下着が欲しい？植物柄？それともアニマル柄？好きなものを選んでいいよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>さん</jp> on the end is the name honorific <jp>さん</jp>. It's there to show some respect. It's like saying "Mr. Guest!" or something like that. But that sounds dumb in English. We'll just call this word <vocabulary>guest</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>visitor</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>customer</vocabulary>. You'll hear this word a lot when you're at a store or you're a customer somewhere in Japan. You are the <jp>お客さん</jp>, in that situation. Alternatively, you'll also hear <jp>お客さま</jp> which is a more polite version of this word (because it ends in <jp>さま</jp> and not <jp>さん</jp>).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji. Just add the hiragana on the end and you'll be good to go.
Context 1-EN: When customers come in, this bell rings.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お客さんが入ってくると、このベルがなります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I met up with my guest at Tokyo Station.

Context 3-EN: What do you think I should do to get customers?
Context 3-JP: <jp>お客さんを獲得するにはどうすればいいと思いますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>polish</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to polish</vocabulary> or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) <vocabulary>to brush your teeth</vocabulary>.

Meaning Mnemonic: A "<jp>ばい</jp>" <kanji>bacteria</kanji> is a <vocabulary>germ</vocabulary>. In case you're wondering, the <jp>ばい</jp> is referring to the kanji <jp>黴</jp>, but people don't usually write that part.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>shade</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of <vocabulary>gloom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>melancholy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> is <kanji>after</kanji> the <kanji>narrative</kanji>. What narrative was this? It's THE narrative, to many. This is the narrative of Jesus. This was so important that they decided to start a new era after it, making this era <vocabulary>after death</vocabulary>* or <vocabulary>AD</vocabulary>.*Yes, I know it's not actually "After Death" but it's so commonly misconceived as such that I put it in there as the definition. You understand the meaning still, right? Anno Domini is also available as a definition too, so don't fret!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This caveman just calmly waited until he could finally get out of his slump in Common Era.

Context 2-EN: I didn't know that the screw wouldn't go in straight if you do it forcefully until Anno Domini.

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Look at a <vocabulary>shadow</vocabulary>. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a <reading>cage</reading> (<jp>かげ</jp>), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>degree</kanji> of the <kanji>angle</kanji> shows what the <vocabulary>angle</vocabulary> is. 90 degrees? 160 degrees? They're all still angles when you come down to it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. Context 1-EN: She’s a spiritual person with a strong sixth sense and can talk to people on the other side.
Context 1-JP: <jp>彼女は非常に霊感の強い霊能力者で、あの世の人と話をすることができます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is for when a thing is <kanji>hot</kanji>, making this word <vocabulary>hot thing</vocabulary>. When the weather is hot that's <jp>暑い</jp>. This is when you touch something and you burn yourself.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: This has the same reading as <jp>暑い</jp>, so if you've learned that you'll know how to read this word as well. If you haven't run into that word, you've probably run into the kanji <jp>暑</jp> at least. That uses the reading <jp>あつ</jp>. Two similar concepts, but there are two kanji to differentiate, which gets confusing.
Context 1-EN: Please heat the bath to forty-one degrees.
Context 1-JP: <jp>おふろを四十一度まで熱くしてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm planning to brew some tea. Would you prefer hot or cold?
Context 2-JP: <jp>お茶をいれようかと思うんですけど、熱いのとつめたいの、どっちがいいですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Please eat it while it’s hot." "Thank you, but... well, it’s so hot that we can’t eat it yet."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「どうぞ、お熱いうちにお召し上がりくださいね。」「有難うございます。でも、ええっと、ちょっと熱すぎるので、まだ食べられません。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Take all the <kanji>word</kanji>s you use in <kanji>writing</kanji>, put them together and you have a <vocabulary>dictionary</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: When Koichi died, he left Tofugu a ton of dictionaries.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは、トーフグにたくさんの辞書を残して死んだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is the best selling dictionary in the world.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは、世界で一番売れている辞書です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I looked up the word "love" in my dictionary and wrote my boyfriend’s name on top of the definition, but he dumped me when he saw it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「愛」という字を辞書で引いて、その意味の上に彼氏の名前を書いておいたの。そしたら、彼に見つかっちゃって、それで振られちゃったのさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Poison</kanji> Gas is a nasty thing. It is <vocabulary>poison gas</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The <jp>ガス</jp> is of course "gas."
Context 1-EN: I read that poison gas was first used in World War I.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毒ガスは第一次世界大戦で使われ始めたらしいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm sorry, but I'm pretty sure that I took the lesson on how to use the poisonous gas at 10:00 a.m. Can you recheck that, please?
Context 2-JP: <jp>午前十時からの毒ガスの使い方のレッスンを取っていたはずなんですが、もう一度かくにんしてもらえますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: "You bastard! You’ve farted again. It’s as stinky as poison gas!" "I’m sorry. I will never do it again." "No, I’m sure you will. That’s the last straw. You’re fired." "Oh no~!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「この野郎！また屁をこきやがったな！毒ガスのように臭いじゃねえか。」「すみません。もう二度とおならはしません。」「いいや、きっとまたこくさ。もう堪忍袋の緒が切れた。お前は首だ。」「そんな〜。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: An "<kanji>add</kanji> <kanji>damp</kanji>ness <kanji>container</kanji>" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a <vocabulary>humidifier</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Something has been wrong with my humidifier.
Context 1-JP: <jp>最近加湿器の調子が悪いんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>mediator</kanji> <kanji>serve</kanji>s families and even countries by <vocabulary>matchmaking</vocabulary> for them. They know everyone and everything so to stop family fights and wars, they put two people from each side together to get married and it fixes everything.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Thank you so much for all your hard work in our wedding ceremony matchmaking.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私どもの結婚式の媒酌の労をおとりいただき、本当にありがとうございました。 </jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>merchandise</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>merchant</vocabulary>. You want to buy something or you just looking?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: As a merchant, I'm thrilled.
Context 1-JP: <jp>商人の血がさわぎます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My dad is a wholesale trader.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの父は、おろし商人です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: He told me that he was a shopkeeper, but I found out that he was actually a poor homeless man who supported himself by collecting empty cans.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼、私に自分は商人だって言ってたんだけど、でも実は貧乏なホームレスで、仕事はなんと空き缶収集だったの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Do you remember <jp>医者</jp> (doctor)? What happens when you add <kanji>eye</kanji> on there? You have yourself an <vocabulary>eye doctor</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the vocab word <jp>医者</jp> (<jp>いしゃ</jp>) plus the reading <jp>目</jp> (<jp>め</jp>), the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: My eye started hurting yesterday, I went to the eye doctor, and it was a sty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>きのう目がいたくなって、目医者に行ったら、ものもらいだった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm looking for an eye doctor who is open on weekends.
Context 2-JP: <jp>週末も開いている目医者をさがしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Listen, Mr. Eye Doctor. The cat's out of the bag, so there's no need to pretend you don’t know anything about eyes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「よお、目医者さん。もう何もかもばれているんだよ。だから、目について何も知らないふりをする必要はないぜ。」</jp>

Meaning: To Be Damp,To Be Moist,To Be Wet
Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>damp</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be damp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be moist</vocabulary>. Ewww.
Reading Mnemonic: You have to think of something that's damp and moist. To do that, think of He-Man's girlfriend, <reading>She-Ma</reading>n (<jp>しめ</jp>). She has been hanging out in a greenhouse and is now kind of damp. He-Man hands her a towel to dry off.
Context 1-EN: I sweat a lot when I was sleeping last night and my bed is a little damp.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨日の夜、寝汗をたくさんかいちゃったから、ベットが何だか湿ってるのよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>勉強</jp> (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is <vocabulary>to study</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>勉強</jp>. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.
Context 1-EN: It's important to log into WaniKani and study kanji every day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>毎日ワニカニにログインしてかん字を勉強することが大事です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like to study but I don't like to read.
Context 2-JP: <jp>勉強することは好きなんですが、本を読むことはきらいなんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m too busy and I just don’t have enough time to study Einstein’s theory of relativity.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ちょっと忙し過ぎて、アインシュタインの相対性理論について勉強する時間がないだけなんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>bride</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to marry</vocabulary>, because you can't really "to bride" someone.
Reading Mnemonic: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like <reading>Tots</reading> (<jp>とつ</jp>), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).
Context 1-EN: Around the time they got married, my son’s wife pretended she was a prude.
Context 1-JP: <jp>嫁ぎたての頃は、息子の嫁はかまととぶっていました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>outside</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you learned the kun'yomi reading for <jp>外</jp> with the vocabulary, you should be just fine here.
Context 1-EN: I thought this door opened outward, but it actually opens inward, I guess.
Context 1-JP: <jp>外側に開くと思ったら、内側に開くドアだったんだね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I usually put the key in the outside pocket though....weird.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いつもは外側のポケットにかぎを入れておくんですけど...おかしいなぁ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I tried to deep fry some salmon, but the outside got burnt and the inside stayed bloody and orange. I guess the oil might have been too hot.
Context 3-JP: <jp>サーモンのフライを作ろうとしたんだけど、外側だけ焦げちゃって内側は血生臭いオレンジ色のままになっちゃった。油がちょっと熱すぎたのかも。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>distribute</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have <vocabulary>to distribute</vocabulary> some fliers to everyone. On the fliers it talks about a striptease show where <reading>kubla</reading>i (<jp>くば</jp>) Khan does something naughty. Imagine this show, and imagine your shame of being the person handing out these fliers. How far the Khan has fallen.
Context 1-EN: For Valentine’s Day we’ll distribute handmade sweets.
Context 1-JP: <jp>バレンタインデーには、友だちに、手作りのおかしを配るんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I wonder how much I could earn from the newspaper delivering job.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しんぶんを配るバイトって月にいくらくらいかせげるのかな。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This party blows. Even passing out pocket tissues on the street would be better.
Context 3-JP: <jp>このパーティーマジでつまんない。道でティシュでも配ってる方がマシだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>go</kanji> on a <kanji>trip</kanji> you're taking a <vocabulary>trip</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>travel</vocabulary>. You should try to do this occasionally! Perhaps a nice <jp>旅行</jp> to Japan?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We're planning on going to Cuba for a family trip during summer vacation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>夏休みは、家族旅行でキューバに行く予定です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to travel around Southeast Asia before graduating from university.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大学をそつ業する前に、東南アジアを旅行したいんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I know you want to ask about my trip, but first things first, how have you been while I've been away?
Context 3-JP: <jp>私の旅行の話を聞きたいのは分かるんだけど、それより、まずは私がいない間どうしてたのか教えてよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>revolving</kanji> <kanji>car</kanji>. You'd think this would be a regular car, but <vocabulary>bicycles</vocabulary> were probably introduced before cars were, meaning the self revolving car is the bicycle, not the car. Just imagine yourself on a bike, and you don't even have to move the pedals. They revolve themselves, but now you're going too fast and it's scary.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I go to work by bike.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは自転車で会社に行っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll buy you a new bicycle, no strings attached.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自転車を買ってあげるよ。お返しは要らないからね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m sorry. I thought for sure you were the one who broke my bike." "What? That’s awful. You know me better than that."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ごめん。てっきり君が僕の自転車を壊したのかと思ってたよ。」 「何それ！ひどい。私がそんなことするはずないでしょ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>root</kanji> of your <kanji>energy</kanji>. You have to dig deep into your energy, all the way to the origin and source of it, to have enough <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> to deal with this dumb kid who's eating away at your not-root energy. It's all you have, and you need to use it.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This job requires patience, huh?
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは根気のいる仕事だよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The reason for failure in most cases is a lack of perseverance.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ほとんどの失ぱいのげんいんは、根気のなさなんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Keep studying Japanese persistently and you’ll be fluent someday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>根気よく日本語の勉強を続けていれば、いつかはペラペラになれるさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What goes in the <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary>? <reading><jp>水</jp></reading>. But, the reading isn't exactly right. It's <jp>みぞ</jp> not <jp>みず</jp>, but close enough to create a hook.
Context 1-EN: I found a 10,000 yen bill in a ditch beside a coin operated parking space.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コインパーキングの横の溝に、万札が落ちてるのを見つけたんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>body</kanji> goes through <kanji>test</kanji>s and each time it does, it gains a little more <vocabulary>experience</vocabulary>. What has your body experienced? What tests has your body been through?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The number of applicants for the rice harvesting experience activity reached five hundred.
Context 1-JP: <jp>いねかり体験教室への応募者は、五百人に達しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In Japan, the number of people who have experienced war has been decreasing year after year.
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本では戦争体験をした人の数が年々少なくなっています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This is a story based on Koichi’s own experiences from when he studied abroad in Japan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これは、コウイチ自身が日本へ留学した時の体験を元にした作品です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: So there's this weird thing with Japanese people. Many things that most people would consider "green" are actually "blue" in their eyes. So, things like plants and street lights are "blue" even though you may think of them as green. Remember that for this word, where we talk about a <kanji>blue</kanji> <kanji>leaf</kanji>. In your head, though, think "green leaf." Now think of all things that have green leaves. This is <vocabulary>greenery</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings for the kanji in this word are the kun'yomi readings. Since you've already seen the word <jp>青</jp>, hopefully you can just combine it with <jp>葉</jp> (you learned the reading for this part with the kanji). Be sure to pay attention to the rendaku, though. <jp>は</jp> goes to <jp>ば</jp> in this word, making it <reading><jp>あおば</jp></reading>.
Context 1-EN: It's that time of year again when the leaves make my eyes burn.
Context 1-JP: <jp>青葉が目にしみるきせつとなりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are a lot of bugs on the young leaves in our garden!
Context 2-JP: <jp>家のにわの青葉に虫がいっぱい付いてる！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your head smells a little weird. It’s like dried up leaves or something.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お前の頭、ちょっと変なにおいがするぞ。 乾燥した青葉か何かみたいな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>origin</kanji> <kanji>stream</kanji>, that's where everything comes from. That is the <vocabulary>mainstream</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I caught this blowfish underneath the WaniKani bridge in the main stream of the Tofu River.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このフグは、トーフ川本流のワニカニはしの下でつれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is known for having a big influence on mainstream fashion.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは、ファッションの本流に大きなえいきょうをあたえることで有名です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: When you say mainstream Japanese literature, who is the first author that comes to mind?
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本文学の本流と言って、最初に思い浮かぶのは誰ですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: The top team will be awarded with a prize of doing aesthetic waterfall meditation.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一位のチームには、賞品として滝修行が授与されます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Love</kanji> <kanji>Know</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji>! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is <vocabulary>Aichi Prefecture</vocabulary> (jump to the reading to figure this out).
Reading Mnemonic: The reading here is all the on'yomi jukugo madness you can handle. If you learned the kanji, you should be able to read this. If you can read it, you can translate it to "English" even though only half of it is English.
Context 1-EN: There is a beautiful ume grove in Aichi Prefecture.
Context 1-JP: <jp>愛知県には、美しい梅林があります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Aichi Prefecture is gradually entering the rainy season.
Context 2-JP: <jp>愛知県は、そろそろ梅雨入りです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: After Fugu moved to Japan’s Aichi Prefecture, no one knew of Salmon’s hopeless longing for him.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグが日本の愛知県に引っ越した後、サーモンが切ない思いをしていることを、誰一人知らなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>reject</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>gutter</kanji> is <vocabulary>drainage</vocabulary>, which we also call a <vocabulary>drain</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>gutter</vocabulary>. This word covers both the drain in your sink or bathtub, and roadside gutters.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It looks like hair clogged the drain for the bathtub.
Context 1-JP: <jp>お風呂の排水溝が髪の毛で詰まっちゃったみたいなの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drink</kanji> so the vocab verb version is <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go have a drink in the great Allicrab's name!
Context 1-EN: I’m thirsty, so let’s drink something.
Context 1-JP: <jp>のどがかわいたので、何か飲みましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What would you like to drink? Gin, vodka, beer, wine, sake, or shochu? You name it, we’ve got it, but only if it’s alcohol.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「何をお飲みになりますか？ ジン、ウォッカ、ビール、ワイン、日本酒、それとも焼酎？  　何でもおっしゃってください。お酒なら何でも揃っていますから。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: While at a <vocabulary>festival</vocabulary>, a guy named Matt has to go to the bathroom. <reading>Matt’s uri</reading>ne (<jp>まつり</jp>) has been filling up his bladder ever since he began drinking that 64oz cup of soda. Matt’s urine is ready to bust out at any moment. He really has to go to the bathroom.This word can also be written <jp>祭り</jp>, and the pronunciation stays the same.
Context 1-EN: I like the candy apples they sell from food stands at festivals.
Context 1-JP: <jp>祭の屋台で売ってるりんごあめがすきなんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: At the last Sunday's festival, me and my boyfriend held hands for the first time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>こないだの日よう日のお祭りで、かれ氏と初めて手をつないだんだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Many Japanese festivals have connections to Buddhism or Shintoism.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本の多くのお祭は、仏教や神道と結びついています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>kill</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to kill</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You <vocabulary>kill</vocabulary> someone! Oh no, what are you going to do? Where will you put the body? You decide to stuff it into the <reading>core</reading> (<jp>ころ</jp>) of a nuclear silo. It will melt and disappear in there, right? At least, that's what you think. Imagine opening up the core of the nuclear silo and feel the burn of the radiation. You throw the body in and close the core, then run away. Unfortunately, this nuclear core will kill you too, eventually. Then, it will kill everyone in the area, because the body you threw in will overheat the core, causing a giant explosion.
Context 1-EN: I will kill you!
Context 1-JP: <jp>お前なんか殺してやる！</jp>
Context 2-EN: It tastes better to eat fish alive rather than killing it first.
Context 2-JP: <jp>魚は殺さずに生きたまま食べた方がおいしいんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think Cinderella was actually really keen on killing her step mother.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私、シンデレラは実際、継母のこと殺したくて仕方がなかったと思うんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>peoples</kanji> who work in the <kanji>farm</kanji> are the <vocabulary>farmers</vocabulary>... the <vocabulary>peasants</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That doesn't mean all peasants in the Edo period were poor.
Context 1-JP: <jp>え戸時代の農民でも、全てがまずしかったわけではないはずだ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Farmers in this village want to know how to swim the forward crawl.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この村の農民たちは、クロールの泳ぎ方を知りたがっている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Wow! That farmer has some amazing abs.
Context 3-JP: <jp>おぉ！あの農民の腹筋すげぇな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When the <kanji>relationship</kanji> is <kanji>good</kanji>, that means you're <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> with that person. You're also on <vocabulary>good terms</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi, but those are the readings you learned already, so hopefully we can stay on good terms, right?
Context 1-EN: Do you think you'll be on good terms with Satomi?
Context 1-JP: <jp>さとみちゃんとは、仲良くなれそう？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu workers are not on very friendly terms and don't speak to each other much.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの社いんはあまり仲良くなく、おたがいほとんど話をしません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Once you get to know her you’ll understand why we say she’s a friendly drunk.
Context 3-JP: <jp>仲良くなれば、彼女が中々面白い酒飲みだということが分かるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>idea</kanji> you <kanji>see</kanji> in your head is your <vocabulary>opinion</vocabulary>. As the dude once said... "That's just, like, your <jp>意見</jp>, man."
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, meaning <jp>意</jp> is just fine. <jp>見</jp>'s on'yomi (<jp>けん</jp>) is a reading you didn't learn with the kanji because it's so much less useful, but you do have to know it here. You've seen it with <jp>発見</jp> a couple levels ago, so that should help. Still, here's a mnemonic to help you remember:In this case, just think about how <reading>Ken</reading> the samurai has an <vocabulary>opinion</vocabulary> on everything. Ken is such a know-it-all, and you're better off agreeing with his opinions. He's a samurai after all!
Context 1-EN: Don't hold your opinions back, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>意見の出しおしみはしないで下さい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even though they were my close friends, I would probably have difficulty openly telling them about this.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いくら仲の良い友だちでも、ちょっと正直には意見しづらいよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: This is just my personal opinion, but I sometimes think that Japan is a really weird country.
Context 3-JP: <jp>これは俺の個人的な意見なんだけど、たまに、日本は本当に変わった国だなぁと思うんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>peoples</kanji> <kanji>tribe</kanji> (or tribe of peoples) is a group that all stick together. They are one single <vocabulary>ethnic group</vocabulary>. What's your <jp>民族</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I don't want to lose my racial identity.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは民族のアイデンティティーを失いたくありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This ethnic group is known for being very cautious.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この民族は、とてもしん重なことでよく知られている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: India has a lot of ethnic diversity but I wonder if all of them still eat curry.
Context 3-JP: <jp>インドには多様な民族がいますが、みんながみんなカレーを食べるのでしょうか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Imagine someone <kanji>accept</kanji>ing something and then <kanji>attach</kanji>ing something. This person is a <vocabulary>receptionist</vocabulary>, because they are accepting the call, writing down the information, and then attaching said information to a sticky note for you to read. You say, "No, I'm not available."
Reading Mnemonic: For this reading you have to think back to the verb words that get used with this kanji, namely <jp>受ける</jp> and <jp>付ける</jp>. Then just drop off the <jp>る</jp>s and put them together. <jp>受</jp> becomes <jp>うけ</jp> and <jp>付</jp> becomes <jp>つけ</jp> and you're left with <jp>うけつけ</jp>. This is what's called a compound word. And now you know it. Nice!
Context 1-EN: I heard that receptionist lady has a big corn on her left foot.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの受付の女せい、左足に大きな魚の目があるらしいよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Arnold Schwarzenegger will be Tofugu's receptionist starting tomorrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日から、シュワちゃんがトーフグの受付をしてくれます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Huh? I don’t know. Didn't someone at reception explain it to you?
Context 3-JP: <jp>え？知らない。受付で聞いてない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>hope</kanji> you <kanji>request</kanji> is your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wish</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I wish so strongly for world peace.
Context 1-JP: <jp>世界が平和であってほしいと強く願望しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "I had a dream where I retired early and played video games all day, every day." "They say dreams reflect your desires. That must be what you desire."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「お金をためて早期リタイアして毎日一日中ゲーム三まいというゆめを見ました。」「ゆめは願望の表れって言いますよね。それがあなたの願望なんですよ。」</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to get married but can’t find anyone that’s up to my standards.
Context 3-JP: <jp>結婚願望はあるんだけど、なかなか理想通りの相手が見つからなくてさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you're <kanji>year</kanji>s <kanji>above</kanji> someone else, you are <vocabulary>older</vocabulary> than that person.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this one is an exception, because it uses kun'yomi readings even though it is a jukugo kanji. You already know the separate kun'yomi readings from the vocabulary of the last level, but you will have to remember to actually use this knowledge when this word comes up.
Context 1-EN: This is my first date with an older person.
Context 1-JP: <jp>年上の人と、デートするのははじめてです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Life is unpredictable. It's not a zero percent chance that you will get married with a beautiful older woman.
Context 2-JP: <jp>人生はよそく不かのうだ。お前が年上のび人とけっこんするかのうせいだってゼロパーセントではない。</jp>
Context 3-EN: My dad says that my mom’s mom is older than the pyramids.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お父さんが、お母さんのお母さんはピラミッドよりも年上だと言うんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>ordinal prefix number</kanji> <kanji>two</kanji> <kanji>chapter</kanji> has a much simpler way of describing it, which is <vocabulary>chapter two</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Chapter one was good, but two was meh.
Context 1-JP: <jp>第一章はおもしろかったけど、第二章はいまいちだった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is gonna be the second chapter of your life, yeah?
Context 2-JP: <jp>人生の第二章のまく開けですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: No way! Are you reading that book too? I’ve just finished chapter two. Don’t tell me anything if you’re farther than me.
Context 3-JP: <jp>まじで？君もその本読んでるの？俺、昨日ちょうど第二章読み終わったところなんだけど。もしそれより先に進んでるなら、何も言わないでね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>nearby</kanji> is something that happened close to now. It happened <vocabulary>recently</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: How many books has she read recently?
Context 1-JP: <jp>女の人は、最近、どのぐらい本を読んでいますか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't follow the latest fashion trends anymore.
Context 2-JP: <jp>最近のトレンドファッションにはもう付いていけません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The term "Gozaru" doesn’t seem to be used as much lately.
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ござる」という言葉は最近はあまり使われなくなったようだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lunatic</kanji> or <kanji>crazy</kanji>. The verb version of this is <vocabulary>to go mad</vocabulary> (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or <vocabulary>to go crazy</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are <reading>coming</reading> (<jp>来る</jp>) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!
Context 1-EN: "Salmon, let’s get married in Las Vegas this weekend." "Fugu, have you lost your mind?"
Context 1-JP: <jp>「サーモン、今週末、ラスベガスで結婚しよう。」「フグ、気でも狂ったの？」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>建てる</jp> is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be erected</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be built</vocabulary>. You can recognize that because of the <jp>つ</jp>, which tells you that <reading>two</reading> (<jp>つ</jp>) guys are building the building while you watch. So you're not doing it, they are, and it's just happening.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is shared with <jp>建てる</jp>, so if you know <jp>建てる</jp> then you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: New high-rise buildings are being built one after another in Tokyo.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東京には、新しい高そうビルがぞくぞくと建っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi's bronze statue was erected at the White House.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ホワイトハウスに、コウイチのどうぞうが建ちました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Salmon and I are discussing buying a pre-built home at the north end of the beach, but it’s a little expensive for us.
Context 3-JP: <jp>サーモンと僕は、浜辺の北端に建つ家を買おうと相談してるんですが、ちょっと私達には値段が高いんですよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading that you learned with the kanji is the same as this one. <reading>HA!</reading> Take that, kanji.
Context 1-EN: Her seventh tooth came in.
Context 1-JP: <jp>七本目の歯が生えてきました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I smoked so much that my teeth are yellow now.
Context 2-JP: <jp>タバコのすいすぎで歯が黄色くなってしまった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m thinking about buying one of those electric toothbrushes, but they’re so expensive.
Context 3-JP: <jp>電動歯ブラシを買うことを考えているんだが、どれも値段が高いんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>fly</kanji>, so the verb version means <vocabulary>to fly</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!
Context 1-EN: It looked just like a phoenix soaring high in the air.
Context 1-JP: <jp>それは、まるで天空を高く翔る不死鳥のようでした。</jp>

Meaning: To Come Together,To Gather,To Be Gathered
Meaning Mnemonic: I bet you remember <jp>集める</jp> which means "to collect." This is similar to that, except you're not doing the action of collecting, it's just happening. Instead of "to collect" it's <vocabulary>to come together</vocabulary>. You can remember this because a herd of <reading>Maru</reading>s (the cat) will come together into one place if they sense a box there.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as <jp>集める</jp> so if you know that word you'll know how to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: This much money was gathered by crowdfunding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>クラウドファンディングで、こんなにたくさんのお金が集まりました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The company retreat gives all the workers a chance to come together.
Context 2-JP: <jp>社員旅行は、全社員が集まるいいき会になります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Look! A group of miscreants are gathering over there!
Context 3-JP: <jp>見て！あそこにヤンキーたちがたくさん集まってるよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Lunatic</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is <vocabulary>madness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>insanity</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: You must be insane to decline that offer.
Context 1-JP: <jp>その申し出を断るなんて狂気の沙汰だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Every</kanji> <kanji>night</kanji> is simply <vocabulary>every night</vocabulary>. What do you do every night?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In order to improve my health, I drink medicinal alcohol every night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>体を丈夫にするために、毎晩やく用酒を飲んでいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Every night my husband eats dinner at 5 o’clock and goes to bed by 10 o’clock.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の夫は、毎晩五時に夕食を食べて、十時には寝ます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: While holding a crying baby every night, I learned that you need a lot of patience to take care of children.
Context 3-JP: <jp>毎晩泣く子を抱きながら、子供の世話をするには大変な忍耐が必要だということを学びました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji>/<kanji>road</kanji> of the <kanji>god</kanji>(s) is, as you can probably guess, a big Japanese religion. There's two, and I'll give you a hint, this one isn't Buddhism (that would probably have the kanji for Buddha in it, no?). So what's the other big one? It's <vocabulary>Shinto</vocabulary>. If you're having trouble remembering this because you've never heard of it before, skip to the reading. The reading will help.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a bit wonky. <jp>神</jp> should be no problem. <jp>道</jp> on the other hand is almost the one you learned (<jp>どう</jp>) but now it's <jp>とう</jp> for some reason. Perhaps the gods took away the dakuten to make it <jp>とう</jp>, who knows. All I know is that it's best not to question said gods. If you already know of Shinto in English, though, this reading should be really easy. If you don't, perhaps you can use this reading to help you to remember Shinto the religion.
Context 1-EN: This is one Shinto ritual.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、神道のぎしきの一つです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Last night, I had a dream that I was just explaining Shinto to Koichi forever.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きのうの夜、ひたすら神道についてコウイチに語るゆめを見ました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Why doesn’t Shinto have an absolute God?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして神道には絶対的な神がいないのですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>apologize</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to apologize</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you say you're sorry <vocabulary>to apologize</vocabulary>, you'd probably start with: "<reading>I am</reading> (<jp>あやま</jp>) sorry!"
Context 1-EN: Apologize to Koichi right now!
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチちゃんに今すぐ謝りなさい！</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you apologize even though you haven't done anything wrong it makes me uncomfortable.
Context 2-JP: <jp>何も悪いことをしてないのに謝られるとぎゃくにこっちがこまります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I feel bad that you won’t get a satisfying result, but I refuse to apologize for something I didn’t do.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君が満足する結果が得られないのはかわいそうだけど、自分がしたことじゃないのに謝るつもりはないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>simple</kanji> bits of <kanji>language</kanji> are the individual <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>s. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I made a notebook for Japanese vocabulary.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本語の単語の単語ちょうを作りました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: When I don't know the meaning of a word, I look it up in my dictionary.
Context 2-JP: <jp>単語の意味が分からない時は、じしょを引きます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I created a Japanese word game. Do you want to try?
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本語の単語ゲーム作ったんだけど、やってみない？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You have a child cow. What do you think a child cow is? Probably a <vocabulary>calf</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>baby cow</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since you should know the readings of the words <jp>子</jp> and <jp>牛</jp> from the previous level, you should be able to read this word too even though it's using the kun'yomi readings for the kanji.
Context 1-EN: We have a white calf.
Context 1-JP: <jp>白い子牛をかっているんです。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>この子牛は、とても元気です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Daddy! Santa Claus gave me a calf last night!
Context 3-JP: <jp>お父さん！サンタ・クロースが昨夜子牛をくれたわ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>guess</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to guess</vocabulary>. Alternatively, you can learn this as <vocabulary>to sense</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to presume</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this is actually the same as what you learned with the kanji, but the <jp>さつ</jp> is shortened to <jp>さっ</jp>. If you had <vocabulary>to guess</vocabulary> be sure to guess with the shorter <jp>つ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: From Koichi's language and behavior, I presume he is very soft on women.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ふだんの言動から察するに、コウイチは鼻の下が非常に長い。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My husband is not good at guessing my feelings.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うちの夫は、私の気持ちを察するのが下手です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: From reading a few articles, I sense that the Tofugu team has some kind of implicit plan.
Context 3-JP: <jp>いくつかの記事を読んで、私はTofuguチームには何か暗黙の構想があることを察しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <jp>の</jp> is there to indicate that it is the difference of something. For example this is like saying "the <vocabulary>separate</vocabulary> ______" or "the <vocabulary>different</vocabulary> _____" or "<vocabulary>another</vocabulary> ______". <jp>別</jp> by itself just means separate, different, or another.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned. Move on to a <jp>別の漢字</jp>, mmk?
Context 1-EN: Why don't we try a different approach?
Context 1-JP: <jp>別のアプローチをトライしてみない？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think this and that are separate issues.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これとそれは、別のもんだいだと思います。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I own two houses. I bought this place about three months ago and I own another place down in the valley.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は家を二軒所有している。三ヶ月ほど前に購入した場所と、谷底にもう一件別の家がある。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>hard</kanji> <kanji>stubborn</kanji> person is very <vocabulary>stubborn</vocabulary> no matter how you look at them. Try to break through that hard stubbornness and all you'll find is more stubborn.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I'm having a hard time because my kid's stubborn.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子どもが頑固でこまっています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Stubborn Kristen insisted that Koichi and Viet would stay friends till the end.
Context 2-JP: <jp>頑固なクリステンは、コウイチとビエトは死ぬまでずっと仲良しだと思うと言いはった。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Fugu is stubborn to the core and is set in his ways.
Context 3-JP: <jp>フグは根っからの頑固者で、自分のやり方にこだわります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Put aside your steampunk blimp fantasies for a moment. A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>harbor</kanji> is an <vocabulary>airport</vocabulary>, nothing more.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I saw a couple having a huge fight at Narita Airport the other day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この間、成田空港で大げんかをしているカップルを見ました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Are there bathrooms with changing tables in this airport?
Context 2-JP: <jp>おむつがえシートのあるトイレはこの空港にありますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think I left my passport in the car I rented at the airport.
Context 3-JP: <jp>空港で借りた車の中に、パスポートを忘れた気がする。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know how <jp>孝行</jp> is "filial piety," right? Well, this is basically the same thing. You're just showing said filial piety to your <kanji>parent</kanji>s, which, of course, is what filial piety means. That makes this word mean <vocabulary>filial piety</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>孝行</jp> plus the kun'yomi of <jp>親</jp>. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.
Context 1-EN: I think I want to do something to show my filial piety toward my parents.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何か両親に親孝行してあげたいと思っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>hundred million</kanji> <kanji>yen</kanji>! So rich! You have <vocabulary>one hundred million yen</vocabulary>!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We don't get big orders of like one hundred million yen, but we do get steady orders.
Context 1-JP: <jp>一億円とか大きな注文は入ってないけど、コンスタントに注文はあるよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I received a notification saying Tofugu had decided to donate one hundred million yen to me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグがわたしに一億円をめぐんでくれることが決定したというお知らせを受けとりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I just lost a suitcase that had one hundred million yen in it.” "What! I hope you find it."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「さっき一億円が入ったスーツケースを無くしちゃったんだけど。」「えぇっ！見つかるといいね。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen that <jp>代わる</jp> means "to substitute for" or "to replace." This is the noun version of that (no <jp>う</jp> sound on the end). So, what is the noun version of those verb words? It would be <vocabulary>substitute</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>replacement</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: You should be able to figure out the reading from learning <jp>代わる</jp> in the previous level.
Context 1-EN: We’re looking for a substitute teacher.
Context 1-JP: <jp>代わりの先生をさがしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There is no replacement for him anywhere in the world.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この世のどこにも、かれの代わりはいないんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can teach you English and in exchange you can teach me Japanese.
Context 3-JP: <jp>日本語を教わる代わりに、英語を教えることができますよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>米国</jp> can also mean America? That goes for North and South America, actually, not just the United States. So, <kanji>south</kanji> <kanji>America</kanji> is <vocabulary>South America</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In my school days, I took a backpacking trip through South America.
Context 1-JP: <jp>学生時代に、バックパッカーとして南米をりょ行しました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This hotel's tap water is the best water I’ve ever had in South America.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このホテルの水道水は、南米で今までのんだ水の中で一番おいしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m sorry. I thought South America was a part of the United States of America.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ごめんなさい。南米はアメリカの一部だと思っていました。</jp>

Meaning: To Begin To Blow,To Breathe Out,To Burst Out Laughing
Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>吹く</jp> is "to blow" and <jp>出す</jp> is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need <vocabulary>to begin to blow</vocabulary> to do that!
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>吹く</jp> and <jp>出す</jp>.
Context 1-EN: She chuckled when she saw my new hairstyle. That’s rude, isn’t it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>俺の新しい髪型を見て、あいつプッと吹き出したんだぜ。失礼だよな。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: At least way back in the day, things that <kanji>teach</kanji> <kanji>instructions</kanji> to people are things that teach a <vocabulary>lesson</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>moral</vocabulary>. Back in the day, lots of learning was done through storytelling, and storytelling taught lessons and morals, thus, this word.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What moral can you draw from Koichi's story?
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチの話から、どんな教訓がえられましたか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll keep this lesson in mind.
Context 2-JP: <jp>この教訓を無だにはしません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tell me about the biggest lesson you learned from your previous company.
Context 3-JP: <jp>前職から学んだ最大の教訓を教えてください。</jp>
