Meaning: South Exit,South Entrance,Southern Exit,Southern Entrance,South Gate
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>South</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> isn't actually a mouth you find in the south pole or anything, it's an entrance or exit. This is kind of like how <jp>入り口</jp> means entrance (the <jp>口</jp> represents a doorway). You'll see this word a lot in places like train stations or airports. It means both <vocabulary>South exit</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>South entrance</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for these kanji are both kun'yomi. Probably because it's two words put together (South + Exit) rather than a single word. Also, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings as well. So, you've seen vocab words that give you the kun'yomi reading of both <jp>南</jp> and <jp>口</jp>, right? Now you just need to combine the two vocab readings into one to be able to read this word. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes <jp>くち</jp> to <jp>ぐち</jp>.
Context 1-EN: If you’re going there, leaving from the south exit is the fastest.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そこに行くなら、南口から出るのが一番近いです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You can see a UFO at the southern entrance of this mall right now!
Context 2-JP: <jp>このモールの南口で今UFOが見られるよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I was hit on at the south exit of Shinjuku station.

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>new</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>new</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your family buys you a <vocabulary>new</vocabulary> Atari! You're so excited! But wait... what's this? This is no Atari. This is an <reading>Atara</reading>... a knockoff video game system :(
Context 1-EN: This pencil is new, isn’t it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しいえんぴつですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll see you at the new Starbucks!
Context 2-JP: <jp>じゃあ、あの新しいスタバでね！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I can’t believe he used my new scarf to bungee jump!
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの男、バンジージャンプするのに私の新しいスカーフを使うなんて、信じられない！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>吹く</jp> is "to blow" and <jp>込む</jp> is "to be crowded." So if you blow into something to the point where it's crowded, you are blowing into it, making this word "<vocabulary>to blow in</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>吹く</jp> and <jp>込む</jp>.
Context 1-EN: The reality is that the house is so old that the rain and wind blows in whenever a storm comes.
Context 1-JP: <jp>家はおんぼろで、嵐が来る度に雨風が吹き込むのが現実です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>wide</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji>... this isn't helpful on its own, but this wide island is <vocabulary>Hiroshima</vocabulary> (heard of it?). When you do the reading it will make more sense.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of both of these which is what you learned with the individual kanji. Just make sure you know those readings and you'll be able to read this.
Context 1-EN: Are there good mountains to climb in Hiroshima?
Context 1-JP: <jp>広島に、登山にいい山はありますか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm heading into the city from Hiroshima airport by city bus.
Context 2-JP: <jp>広島空港から市バスで市内に向かってるところです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki instantly killed more than 100,000 people.
Context 3-JP: <jp>広島と長崎に投下された原爆は、一瞬で十万人以上の人々の命を奪った。</jp>

Meaning: Way Of Saying,Way Of Talking,Speaking Style
Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>say</kanji>ing something is your <vocabulary>way of saying</vocabulary>. This could be your accent or simply the way you talk.
Reading Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>言う</jp>. Let's steal that word's reading. And, you already know <jp>方</jp> and its reading. Combine those together and you have the reading for this word.
Context 1-EN: That makes sense, but you should think about the way you say things!
Context 1-JP: <jp>そうは言っても、言い方ってもんがあるだろ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Oh, sorry for changing the subject, but don't you think the way Koichi says the word cat is so cute?
Context 2-JP: <jp>そうだ、話はかわるんだけど、コウイチのネコって言ばの言い方、めっちゃかわいくない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Your way of saying that is so stupid.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あなたの物の言い方はとても馬鹿です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen <jp>逃げる</jp> and <jp>逃す</jp>. This one is <jp>逃れる</jp>. This one simply means <vocabulary>to escape</vocabulary>. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.
Reading Mnemonic: This is the same reading you learned for <jp>逃す</jp>, so you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: I’m thinking about how to escape from zombies if they actually showed up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>万が一ゾンビが実際に現れた場合を想定して、どうやってゾンビから逃れるのかを考えているんです。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>口笛</jp> is "whistling." So, if you're <kanji>blow</kanji>ing your whistle you're going <vocabulary>to whistle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are of <jp>口笛</jp> and the reading you learned from <jp>吹</jp>.
Context 1-EN: What attracts you to whistling?
Context 1-JP: <jp>口笛を吹くことにどんな魅力を感じますか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Hey. <kanji>Drop</kanji> yourself down and <kanji>arrive</kanji> back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things <vocabulary>to calm down</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>落ちる</jp> and <jp>着く</jp>. Hopefully you know these words so you can read this word as well! If you don't, just <jp>落ち着く</jp> and everything will be okay.
Context 1-EN: I have no idea what she's thinking, but I can relax when I'm with her.
Context 1-JP: <jp>かの女はとらえどころのない女性ですが、一しょにいると落ち着くんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Viet calmed down the baby by giving her some scotch.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトは赤ちゃんにスコッチをあげて落ち着かせた。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Damn him! I’m sick of my boss. I’m going to quit my job." "Whoa, whoa, whoa. Don’t be in such a hurry. Calm down."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ちくしょう、上司のやつ！もう、頭にきた！こんな仕事、辞めてやる。」「おいおいおい、そう焦るなって。ちょっと落ち着けよ。 」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Meow!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Neko neko neko! Kawaiiiii.
Context 1-EN: Our cat is good at doing math in its head.
Context 1-JP: <jp>うちの猫は、暗算がとく意なんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I have four times the amount of cat clothes in this closet at home.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このクローゼットにあるりょうの四倍の猫の服が家にあります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You’ve got to help me! My cat swallowed an "M" Scrabble tile!
Context 3-JP: <jp>助けてくれ！俺の飼い猫がスクラブルの ’M’のコマを飲み込んじゃったんだ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>make</kanji> <kanji>war</kanji>, you're building it up like you'd build a building. You have to make <vocabulary>strategy</vocabulary>, you have to plan, you have to come up with awesome <vocabulary>tactics</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: At 9 p.m. I want to talk about our strategy for tomorrow.
Context 1-JP: <jp>午後九時に明日の作戦について話したい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Let's work out a strategy one more time.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もう一度、作戦をねり直そう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi thinks that Tofugu needs new sales tactics.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは、トーフグには新しいはん売作戦がひつようだと考えている。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>far</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>far</vocabulary> (or it's <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary>).
Reading Mnemonic: You want to go <vocabulary>far</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary> when you see a <reading>toe... oh</reading> (<jp>とお</jp>)! You realize there is a zombie toe on the ground and it reminds you of where you can go that's far from here—where the zombie that once had this toe went! (Remember the kanji mnemonic? It's that scooter zombie's toe that makes you say oh and want to go.)
Context 1-EN: Koichi's apartment is located about three hours from the Tofugu office, in some faraway woods.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチのアパートはトーフグオフィスから三時間ほど行った、遠い林の中にあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: That newly-built condo was really nice but we gave up on buying it, because it was too far from the station.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの新築マンション、とてもよかったんですけど、駅から遠すぎて買うのをあきらめました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How far is Tokyo from Portland? Is it too far for me to walk?
Context 3-JP: <jp>東京は、ポートランドからどれくらい遠いんですか？歩くにはちょっと遠すぎますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you're moving towards (<jp>に</jp>) <kanji>simple</kanji>, you're saying <vocabulary>simply</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>merely</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>only</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It's simply because Koichi is a very hard worker.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは単に大変な努力家なだけですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi said, "To me, Tofugu is not merely for earning money. It's my life."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「トーフグは、私にとっては単にお金をかせぐためのものではないんです。トーフグこそが私の人生なんです。」と、コウイチは言った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In kendo, it’s important not simply to defeat your opponent but also to train your own mind.
Context 3-JP: <jp>剣道では、単に相手を倒すことだけではなく、自らの心を鍛えることも重要です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that a <jp>医者</jp> is a doctor. So what is a <kanji>tooth</kanji> doctor? A <vocabulary>dentist</vocabulary>. Seriously, don't forget to floss. <jp>歯医者</jp> hate when you forget to floss.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It's better to go see a dentist at least once every six months.
Context 1-JP: <jp>半年に一度は歯医者に行った方がいい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Ms. Handa is too good for this dentist.
Context 2-JP: <jp>花田さんは、この歯医者にはもっ体ないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I think he’s just a wannabe delinquent. I doubt he’ll end up being a real one because he’s still afraid of going to the dentist.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼はただ不良に憧れてるだけだと思うよ。絶対に本物の不良にはならないね。だって、歯医者さんに行くのですら怖がってるんだよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The thing you want to <kanji>take</kanji> has <kanji>escape</kanji>d. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is <vocabulary>to fail to catch</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings come from <jp>取る</jp> and <jp>逃がす</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Don’t you think pretending that you failed to catch the criminal is a bit overkill?
Context 1-JP: <jp>犯罪者を取り逃がすふりをするのは、ちょっとやり過ぎじゃない？</jp>

Meaning: East Exit,East Entrance,Eastern Exit,Eastern Entrance,East Gate
Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>入り口</jp> means entrance and <jp>出口</jp> means exit? This is just the <jp>口</jp> part with a direction on it. That means it can be both entrance or exit. So when you have <kanji>East</kanji> up there this word can mean both <vocabulary>East exit</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>East entrance</vocabulary>. This is a great word to know if you need to know which side of a train station you need to leave on to go somewhere or meet someone!
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses kun'yomi readings, possibly because of <jp>口</jp>, which is a body part (body parts do that quite a bit in words and kanji). You should hopefully have seen both the kun'yomi readings from previous levels meaning you can read this word as well. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes <jp>くち</jp> to <jp>ぐち</jp>.
Context 1-EN: There’s someone doing a street performance at the station’s east exit.
Context 1-JP: <jp>えきの東口で大道げいをしている人がいたよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The photo taken at the east gate is a bit blurry, probably from the camera shaking.
Context 2-JP: <jp>東口でとった写しん、たぶん手ブレしたみたいで、ちょっとブレちゃってる。</jp>
Context 3-EN: In the case of an emergency, please evacuate the building through the east exit. There will be coffee and donuts waiting for you there.
Context 3-JP: <jp>緊急の際には、このビルの東口から避難してください。そこでは、コーヒーとドーナツが支給される予定です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>吹く</jp> is "to blow" and that <jp>飛ばす</jp> is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going <vocabulary>to blow away</vocabulary> it.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>吹く</jp> and <jp>飛ばす</jp>, put together.
Context 1-EN: Let’s go to the party and brush off your depression.
Context 1-JP: <jp>パーティーに行って、憂鬱なんて吹き飛ばしちゃおうぜ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>law</kanji> is something that's against the law. It's <vocabulary>illegal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unlawful</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: None of the Tofugu workers know about the illegal black-market transactions that Viet does.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトが行っている不法のやみとり引のことを、トーフグの社員はだれも知らない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: How many illegal aliens do you think there are in the U.S. at the moment?
Context 2-JP: <jp>アメリカにはげん時てんで何人の不法たいざい者がいると思いますか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: We can’t use evidence obtained through an unlawful search at the court.
Context 3-JP: <jp>不法な捜査で得た証拠は法廷では使えませんよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>name</kanji> that's in the <kanji>front</kanji>. That is not your last name, that is your regular <vocabulary>name</vocabulary> or your <vocabulary>first name</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses both kun'yomi readings (oh darn!). That being said, you've seen the kun'yomi readings for both the kanji that make up this word. The word <jp>名</jp> (<jp>な</jp>) and the word <jp>前</jp> (<jp>まえ</jp>) both are kun'yomi, so use those words and Voltron them into a single word, <jp>なまえ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: What is that person’s name?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの人の名前は何ですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've heard the name, but I don't know much about it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>名前はきいたことがあるけど、あまりよく知らないかな。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I want to change my first name to "Ah" and my last name to "Soso."
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は名前を「ああ」に、名字を「そうそう」に変えたい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>inside</vocabulary>. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With <jp>側</jp> you've already learned it. With <jp>内</jp> you've also already learned the reading. Combine them together and you have <jp>うちがわ</jp>. In case you've forgotten, here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky <jp>うち</jp> portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "<reading>Oo, chee</reading>se!" (<jp>うち</jp>) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"
Context 1-EN: I'll wait for you inside Resona Bank.
Context 1-JP: <jp>りそな銀行の内側で待っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I think I've got a splinter in my inner right heel.
Context 2-JP: <jp>右の内側のかかとにトゲがささったみたいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We need to lower the metal shutters and lock them from the inside to shut the zombies out.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ゾンビを中に入れないために、金属製のシャッターを下ろして、内側から鍵を掛ける必要があります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>seasons</kanji> <kanji>season</kanji> is the <vocabulary>season</vocabulary>. Who likes winter? It's my favorite <jp>季節</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: A lot of seasonal vegetables are sold in this market.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このマーケットには、季節の野さいがたくさん売っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Aren't your clothes a little out of season?
Context 2-JP: <jp>その服そうは、ちょっと季節外れじゃない？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Don’t worry. Catching a cold when the seasons change is kind of a habit of mine.
Context 3-JP: <jp>心配しないで。季節の変わり目に風邪をひくのは、私の習慣のようなものなの。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When something <kanji>has</kanji> <kanji>poison</kanji> it is <vocabulary>poisonous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>toxic</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Are rattle snakes venomous?
Context 1-JP: <jp>ガラガラヘビって有毒なんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Darin ate a poisonous fungus growing on the side road by mistake and was sent to a hospital.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ダリンが道ばたに生えていた有毒キノコを間ちがって食べて、病院にはこばれてしまいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Only Viet knows that Koichi’s farts smell like toxic fumes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトだけがコウイチのオナラが有毒ガスのような臭いがすることを知っている。</jp>

Meaning: To Catch Up With,To Overtake,To Keep Up With
Meaning Mnemonic: To <kanji>follow</kanji> then <kanji>attach</kanji> yourself to the whoever you're following is <vocabulary>to catch up with</vocabulary> someone.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, but you can also just notice that this word includes <jp>追う</jp> and <jp>付く</jp> combined.
Context 1-EN: We took a car and less than five minutes later we overtook Koichi who had departed for Seattle on foot on the previous day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>前日にシアトルまでと歩で出発したコウイチに車で五分もかからず追い付きました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you can catch up with Kristen in the hundred meter dash, you can compete in the Olympics.
Context 2-JP: <jp>100メートル走でクリステンに追い付くことができたらオリンピックに出られるよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu’s coloring book was so popular that production couldn’t keep up with demand.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの塗り絵は人気すぎて、生産が需要に追い付かなかった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>way</kanji> <kanji>method</kanji> or the <kanji>method</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> is the <vocabulary>method</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>way</vocabulary>. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the <jp>方法</jp>? Well, first you...
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That method doesn't work on Viet. It actually works the other way around.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトには、その方法はきかないっていうか、むしろぎゃくこうかですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I want to know the way to make a baby sleep very well in a bed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんをぐっすりベッドでねむらせる方法が知りたいです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Sherlock Holmes has an old method of investigating crimes, doesn’t he?
Context 3-JP: <jp>シャーロック・ホームズって、古びた犯罪調査方法を使っているよね？</jp>

Meaning: Rotating Sushi,Conveyor Belt Sushi,Revolving Sushi,Sushi Train,Sushi Go Round
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>回転</jp> is "rotation" and you probably know what <jp>すし</jp> is (gets rendaku'd in this word to <jp>ずし</jp>). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's <vocabulary>rotating sushi</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>conveyer belt sushi</vocabulary>. Look it up if you don't know what it is.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>回転</jp>, so be sure to know that to know this one. Also, it's just the readings of the kanji you learned too, so shouldn't be too hard.
Context 1-EN: A new conveyer belt sushi shop opened up.
Context 1-JP: <jp>新しく回転ずしのお店がオープンした。</jp>
Context 2-EN: The sushi-go-round turned at 32 rotations per second.
Context 2-JP: <jp>その回転ずしは、毎秒三十二回転していました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, still not ready? I'm too hungry. We'll go to rotating sushi without you, if you still aren't ready in three minutes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねぇ、まだ準備出来てないの？お腹ペコペコなんだけど。三分以内に準備出来なかったら、先に回転寿司に行っちゃうからね！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>news report</kanji> so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "<vocabulary>to report on</vocabulary>," however.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.
Context 1-EN: The entire United States wept when they broke the news that Superman had died.
Context 1-JP: <jp>スーパーマンの死去が報じられ、全米が涙した。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I felt relieved when they reported that Koichi is safe.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチの無事が報じられて、胸をなで下ろしました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Tofugu covered an exclusive interview with Hatsune Miku.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguは、初音ミクの独占取材を報じた。</jp>

Meaning: Beginning,In The Beginning,First Of All,To Begin With
Meaning Mnemonic: This is a time based word (because of the <jp>に</jp>). What is the <kanji>first</kanji> point of time when you are beginning something? That is the <vocabulary>beginning</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. What are you beginning? You are beginning <reading>Haj</reading> (<jp>はじ</jp>). (Haj is the fifth pillar of Islam, and is a pilgrimage to Mecca during the month of Dhu al-Hijja).
Context 1-EN: To begin with, please first slice the beef and then pan fry it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>まず初めに牛肉をスライスして、それからフライパンでいためてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: First of all, please don't improvise.
Context 2-JP: <jp>初めに言わせてもらいますが、アドリブえんそうはしないでください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: R.I.P. Tofugu. At the beginning of this month my favorite Japanese learning site went bankrupt.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguよ安らかに眠ってくれ。今月初めに、僕の一番好きな日本語学習サイトが倒産しちゃったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>deep</kanji>ness is the <vocabulary>water depth</vocabulary>. You should check this before diving into the water so you don't hit your face.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I've dived to depths of one hundred feet before.
Context 1-JP: <jp>水深100フィートまでもぐったことがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You don't have to worry because this pool is very shallow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このプールの水深はあさいから、心配しなくていいよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: While diving at a depth of ten meters, I found rainbow-colored seaweed.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ダイビングをしている際に、水深十メートルのところで虹色の海藻を見つけました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: One of the meanings of <jp>本</jp> is <kanji>main</kanji> (which is what we're using here). The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>public building</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main building</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The main building has a classroom for pre-school children.
Context 1-JP: <jp>本館には、ようじ教室の部屋がへいせつされています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: We are going to make a book that teaches the history of the main building from scratch.
Context 2-JP: <jp>本館のれきしをゼロから教える本を作ります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Lots of the people working in the main building of the department store act like someone is forcing them to work, compared to those working at the annex. They have awfully bad attitudes.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あの百貨店の本館で働いている店員は、別館で働いている人たちに比べて、なんか働かされてるって感じだった。愛想がやけに悪いっていうかさ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>thoughts</kanji> are <kanji>pray</kanji>ers. These pray thoughts are <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>s.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: All people around the world are praying.
Context 1-JP: <jp>世界中の全ての人が、祈念しています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'll attend the peace memorial service for atomic-bomb victims tomorrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>明日は原ばくぎせい者いれい平和祈念式典に出席します。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Let’s pray for more and more growth and prosperity for Tofugu, cheers!
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguの益々の発展と繁栄を祈念して、乾杯！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This vocabulary word is the same as the 'name' meaning of the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll have no trouble remembering this word as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just think of the first part of the English word <vocabulary>name</vocabulary>. What is it? It's <reading>na</reading> (<jp>な</jp>), just like this word!
Context 1-EN: Please tell me the name of this flower.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この花の名をおしえてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Last summer, the movie "Your Name" became popular in Japan.
Context 2-JP: <jp>きょ年のなつ、「きみの名は。」というえいがが日本ではやりました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I still don’t know her name.

Meaning Mnemonic: An <kanji>evidence</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>witness</vocabulary>, because witnesses are people who provide evidence (you know, with their mouths or something).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The witness proved that Viet was guilty.
Context 1-JP: <jp>証人が、ビエトが有ざいであることを証明してくれました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: In my husband's court case, the clerks of the bank where he has his accounts appeared in court as witnesses for him.
Context 2-JP: <jp>私の夫のさいばんでは、夫の口座がある銀行の行員の人たちが証人として出ていしてくれました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: As a witness, I won’t beat around the bush, I’ll answer your question frankly. Yeah, that Fugu was absolutely eating your pudding.
Context 3-JP: <jp>証人として、遠回しに言わずに率直に君の質問に答えさせてもらうよ。ああ、あのフグが確かに君のプリンを食べていたね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your "<kanji>doing</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji>s" are the things you do. What do you say when someone asks "what you do"? You tell them what your <vocabulary>job</vocabulary> is.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <jp>仕</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>事</jp>. Please note that <jp>事</jp> uses the reading <jp>こと</jp>, which you didn't learn with the kanji, but you have come across it once or twice by now, and because of the way rendaku works, it's changed to the voiced <jp>ごと</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Does this job reimburse transportation costs?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この仕事は、交通ひこみですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: The business of a baby is to cry.
Context 2-JP: <jp>赤ちゃんの仕事は泣くことです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Do you think we can finish this work in time?" "Well I wouldn’t bet on it."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「時間内に、この仕事を終えられると思うか？」「さあ、それはどうかな。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wear</kanji> so this word means <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary>. You'll need to differentiate it from <jp>着く</jp> which means (to arrive), though. Just think of how the <jp>る</jp> is the <reading>ru</reading>de guy trying to get you to wear things you don't like wearing.
Reading Mnemonic: What do you want <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary> today? How about a dress made entirely of <reading>key</reading>s (<jp>き</jp>)? Feel the metal on your skin and the weight on your shoulders. It's not a comfortable thing to put on. Maybe just stick with wearing a single key around your neck next time.
Context 1-EN: I was so freaked out that I even wore my t-shirt inside out.
Context 1-JP: <jp>パニクってて、Tシャツをおもてうらはんたいに着てたわ！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi is wearing an apron when he comes to office every day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチは毎日エプロンを着て出きんしている。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I wore a knee-length black dress at my boyfriend’s birthday party the day before yesterday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>一昨日の彼氏の誕生日会には、黒の膝丈のドレスを着ていったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If <jp>伺う</jp> is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say <vocabulary>inquiry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary>. In other words, a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary>. It can also mean a <vocabulary>visit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>伺う</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Could I inquire about your blog’s URL, please?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あなたのブログのURLをお伺いしてもよろしいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Think about a <kanji>part</kanji> of the <kanji>district</kanji>. Separate them out in your mind (these parts). Each part is a <vocabulary>division</vocabulary> of the district. You can also take each division and create a <vocabulary>classification</vocabulary> of them. Go ahead and classify each one.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In this town, the school district is divided into three divisions.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この町では、校区が三つに区分されています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is a problem of budget classification, so I have nothing to do with it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは予算区分の問題なので、私にはどうしようもありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t think it’s necessary to distinguish terrorism from legitimate warfare.
Context 3-JP: <jp>私は、テロ行為と合法的な戦争を区分する必要は無いと思います。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you <vocabulary>sail</vocabulary> in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden <reading>hoe</reading> (<jp>ほ</jp>). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!
Context 1-EN: Looks like you have to replace the sail soon.
Context 1-JP: <jp>そろそろ帆を替えなくちゃいかんなあ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <jp>買う</jp> by now and know it means "to buy." So, <jp>買い</jp> is going to be similar to that. Add that to <kanji>thing</kanji> and you have a "buying things" sort of word. What does "buying things" describe? It describes <vocabulary>shopping</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Also, you can use the reading for <jp>買う</jp> to help you with <jp>買い</jp> as well. <jp>物</jp> is just <jp>もの</jp>, like you learned.
Context 1-EN: I’m shopping at the grocery store.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしはスーパーで買い物をしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: As for shopping, I usually just do it online.
Context 2-JP: <jp>買い物はいつもネットショッピングですませています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: We’re going Christmas shopping today! I’m so excited!
Context 3-JP: <jp>今日はクリスマスの買い物に行くの！すごくワクワクするわ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>群れる</jp>, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is a little different from <jp>群れる</jp>, though. There's an extra <jp>ら</jp> in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small <reading><jp>村</jp></reading> (<jp>むら</jp>). There's a <jp>村</jp> reunion going on, that's why.
Context 1-EN: We were surprised that fans had gathered to wait for us when we arrived at the airport.
Context 1-JP: <jp>空港に到着するとファンが群がっていて、驚きましたよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sail</kanji> <kanji>run</kanji>s boats along the sea by <vocabulary>sailing</vocabulary>! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Look, there’s a yacht sailing over there.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ほら、あそこにヨットが帆走しているよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>wife</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>lady</vocabulary>, because I guess ladies are wife people? I'm guessing this is pretty sexist somewhere, somehow, but words were made a long time ago so hopefully you can give all those dead people a break.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: That lady is getting out of hand. What should I do?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの婦人、俺の手には負えなくなってきたよ。どうしたらいいかな？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>use</kanji> something in a <kanji>cruel</kanji> way it's called <vocabulary>exploitation</vocabulary>. You're probably going to <vocabulary>overuse</vocabulary> it, at that rate too. Cut it out, dude.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: Do you think it’s okay to let black companies that exploit their workers continue to take care of themselves?
Context 1-JP: <jp>労働者を酷使するブラック企業をこのまま野放しにしていてもいいんですか。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When the <kanji>public</kanji> comes <kanji>together</kanji> you have yourself a nice <vocabulary>community</vocabulary> made up of the <vocabulary>public</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I used to volunteer at a public facility.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ぼう公共しせつでボランティアをしていたことがあります。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Once again, I want you to think about what public actually means.
Context 2-JP: <jp>公共とは一体何なのか、今一度考え直してみてほしい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, Rei and Ami. Y’know, this is probably none of my business, but weren’t you guys supposed to not be seen in public together? You guys are celebrities, right?
Context 3-JP: <jp>ねぇ、レイとアミ。これは私が口出しするようなことじゃないだろうけど、あんた達、公共の場で一緒にいるところを見られちゃいけないんじゃなかったの？だって、セレブでしょ？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word:This is a magic <vocabulary>root</vocabulary> that turns you into a horse. You take a bite and let out a loud <reading>neigh</reading> (<jp>ね</jp>)!
Context 1-EN: You can eat the roots of this flower.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この花の根は食べられますよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It seems that this problem has really deep roots.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このもんだいは相当根が深いようですね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You might think he’s a great person but he’s really a horrible man at heart.
Context 3-JP: <jp>彼は素敵な人だと思うかもしれないが、根がひどい男なのだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you are able to <kanji>guarantee</kanji> against <kanji>risk</kanji>, it's probably because you bought some good <vocabulary>insurance</vocabulary>! What do you use? The gecko <jp>保険</jp>?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Why is it more common for women to do insurance sales in Japan?
Context 1-JP: <jp>どうして日本では、女性が保険の外交をすることが多いんですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do I need a birth certificate to get insurance?
Context 2-JP: <jp>保険にか入するのに、出生証明書は必要ですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh no, I left my health insurance card at home again.
Context 3-JP: <jp>しまった。また家に健康保険証を忘れてきちゃった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>weekday</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is the <vocabulary>day of the week</vocabulary>, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn <jp>曜日</jp> to get you prepared.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <jp>曜</jp> and the kun'yomi reading for <jp>日</jp>. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because <jp>ひ</jp> of <jp>日</jp> changes to <jp>び</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: Why don't we make Wednesday the day we try speaking Japanese at the speed of native speakers?
Context 1-JP: <jp>水曜日は、ネイティブが話すスピードで日本語を話す日にしませんか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: What day of the week is today?
Context 3-EN: The bottom line is that we have to finish this Japanese assignment by Friday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>肝心なのは、この日本語の課題を金曜日までに終わらせなければならないということだ。</jp>

Meaning: To Be Connected To,To Be Related
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>関</jp> means <kanji>connected</kanji>. So, when you add <jp>する</jp> to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to be connected to</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Context 1-EN: There is no room for compromise on this matter.
Context 1-JP: <jp>このけんに関しては、妥協のよ地はありません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Kristen is doing research connected to Japanese literature.
Context 2-JP: <jp>クリステンは、日本文学に関する研究を行っています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: While working at the Tofugu office, Viet received a call related to a shooting at his hideout.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ビエトは、Tofuguのオフィスで働いている時に、アジトでの発砲に関する電話を受けた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: It's a <kanji>drawing</kanji> that uses <kanji>reflect</kanji>ions to project the image. And, the image is moving! How amazing! What is this? It is a <vocabulary>movie</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Have you already watched the latest Ghibli movie?
Context 1-JP: <jp>もうジブリの最新映画は見ましたか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Even though I like romantic films, my husband only wants to watch war movies.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしはロマンス映画が好きなのに、主人は戦争映画ばっかり見たがるんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I’m going to be a movie star, buy a private jet, and you will be my wife." "Yeah, dream on, grandpa."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「僕は映画スターになって、自家用ジェット機を買うよ。それから、君は僕のお嫁さんになるんだ。」 「おじいちゃん、何寝ぼけたこと言ってんの。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> of everything is the <vocabulary>atom</vocabulary>. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: In the future, I think I want to study atomic energy.
Context 1-JP: <jp>しょう来は、原子エネルギーの勉強をしたいと思っています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: What was the atomic number and atomic symbol of this atom?
Context 2-JP: <jp>この原子の原子番号と原子記号は何だったっけ？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Aging nuclear power plants are a problem for many countries.
Context 3-JP: <jp>老朽化した原子力発電所は、多くの国々にとって悩みの種です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember how <jp>楽</jp> was used in <jp>音楽</jp> and meant "music"? Well this is that <jp>楽</jp> again. A <kanji>music</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is something that can produce music. It is a <vocabulary>musical instrument</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You have already learned the reading for <jp>器</jp> but <jp>楽</jp> uses the secondary reading so you may not have learned it.  However, you learned this reading in the word <jp>音楽</jp>. Just bear in mind that the <jp>がく</jp> shortens to <jp>がっ</jp>.
Context 1-EN: There are various different types of musical instruments. Which type do you like? I like percussion.
Context 1-JP: <jp>楽器にも色々ありますが、どんな楽器が好きですか。私は打楽器が好きです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please start by trying to play your instrument note for note.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まずは楽器を楽ふ通りにえんそうしてみてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "I forgot to bring your CD." "That’s okay. I can get it another time, but can you play an instrument for background music instead?"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「あなたのCDを持ってくるのを忘れてしまったわ。」「別にいいよ、またの機会で。でも、その代わりにBGMとして何か楽器を弾いてくれない。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that <jp>楽器</jp> means "musical instrument" so adding a couple of <kanji>bowstring</kanji>s to it will make it a <vocabulary>stringed instrument</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My uncle repairs stringed instruments.
Context 1-JP: <jp>私の叔父は、弦楽器の修理をしています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>container</kanji>s refer to <vocabulary>tableware</vocabulary>, including <vocabulary>eating utensils</vocabulary>, such as knives, forks, spoons, and chopsticks, as well as <vocabulary>serving utensils</vocabulary>, like plates, bowls, and saucers. Basically, it's stuff you use to eat your food.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the shortened <jp>しょく</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Can you arrange these plates and utensils on the table, please?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この食器をテーブルの上にならべてくれませんか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Which utensils did you drop in the pond, the gold ones or the silver ones?
Context 2-JP: <jp>あなたが池に落としたのはこの金の食器ですか、それともこの銀の食器ですか。</jp>
Context 3-EN: How come we have one extra place setting?
Context 3-JP: <jp>どうして、食器が一式多いの？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Don't have to use your <vocabulary>brain</vocabulary> for that.
Context 1-EN: He has no brains.
Context 1-JP: <jp>アイツは本当に脳が弱いよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Use your brain when you think!
Context 2-JP: <jp>ちょっとは脳を使って考えろよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: Did you know that people eat brains in this country? It’s a delicacy.
Context 3-JP: <jp>この国の人たちは脳を食べるってこと、知ってる？珍味なんだよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Alcohol</kanji> that comes from <kanji>ume</kanji> is <vocabulary>ume wine</vocabulary>. It can also be called <vocabulary>plum wine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>plum liquor</vocabulary>. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice!
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is just the readings of the kanji that you learned. How about a toast to easy to read words!
Context 1-EN: When I open a can of ume wine after taking a bath, I can't stop until I've finished it.
Context 1-JP: <jp>風ろ上がりに梅酒を開けると、一本飲み切るまで止まりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Is that okay to drink plum wine on the trains in Japan?
Context 2-JP: <jp>日本では、電車の中で梅酒を飲んでもいいんですか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: Thank God it’s Friday! I’m looking forward to drinking homemade plum wine tonight.
Context 3-JP: <jp>よっしゃ〜花金だ〜。今夜の自家製梅酒が待ち遠しい。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading which you learned with the kanji earlier. No problem!
Context 1-EN: I’ll wash your head.
Context 1-JP: <jp>頭をあらってあげましょう。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Taking a nap usually refreshes my mind.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ひるねをすると、いつも頭がすっきりします。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have a headache so please stop talking.
Context 3-JP: <jp>頭が痛いので、喋らないでください。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Remember <jp>大阪</jp> (Osaka)? This is the <kanji>dialect</kanji> they speak, making this word <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: If you know how to read <jp>大阪</jp> you can just add <jp>弁</jp> to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.
Context 1-EN: That supervisor with the Osaka dialect always takes forever to get to the point, it's very annoying.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの大阪弁の上司は、いつも前おきが長いので、うんざりします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've put the past with my ex with the Osaka dialect behind me already.
Context 2-JP: <jp>大阪弁のかれ氏とのかこは、もう忘れました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Don’t worry. I won’t tell anyone that you speak with the Osaka dialect. Your secret is safe with me." "Thanks."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「心配しないで。君が大阪弁を喋るってことは誰にも言わないよ。秘密は守るよ。」「おおきに！」</jp>

Meaning: To Be Emotionally Moved,To Be Moved Emotionally,To Be Moving
Meaning Mnemonic: You know this is a verb from the <jp>する</jp>. Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s have been <kanji>move</kanji>d. So, when your feelings have been moved, you are emotionally moved. This word is <vocabulary>to be emotionally moved</vocabulary> or simply <vocabulary>to be moving</vocabulary>. Just be sure to know this has to do with emotions.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: It was so moving, I can't stop crying.
Context 1-JP: <jp>感動してなみだが止まりません。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I heard the secret story of how Tofugu was established and was really moved.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグのせつ立ひ話を聞いて、とても感動しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh my God! I just made the best Japanese learning material in the history of mankind! Everyone will be really excited!
Context 3-JP: <jp>なんてこった！今までの人類の歴史上で最高の日本語学習教材を作っちまったぜ！みんなマジで感動するだろうな！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: I want you to try to <kanji>bear</kanji> <kanji>this</kanji> <kanji>truth</kanji> and that's these kanji make up the word <vocabulary>clownfish</vocabulary>! Do you think a clownfish is this bear? I'm telling the truth! Maybe.
Reading Mnemonic: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for all the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for <jp>之</jp> or <jp>実</jp> yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:If you get too close to a <vocabulary>clownfish</vocabulary>, it will hide inside its stinging anemone and shout, "YOU DON'T <reading>KNOW ME</reading> (<jp>のみ</jp>)! It's true, you don't know this clownfish, but you want to. I guess all of them are afraid of strangers though... how will you know me if you don't give me a chance, clownfish?!
Context 1-EN: Nemo and his family are fish called clownfish.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ニモやその家族は、隠熊之実という魚だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This one's a little weird. You have a <kanji>group</kanji> of <kanji>cloth</kanji>. Think about this. If you group together a bunch of cloth into one big cloth, you have something nice and soft. What can you use this nice and soft cloth things for? Well, you can sleep on it. This is the Japanese word <vocabulary>futon</vocabulary>, which you may have heard in English before (though the Japanese futon is quite different from the American one). You can also translate this to <vocabulary>bedding</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sleeping mat</vocabulary> too.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for <jp>団</jp> is the secondary reading that went with the kanji, though, so watch out for that. If you can figure out the meaning of this word, chances are you already know how to spell it, so carry that over to Japanese.
Context 1-EN: I think I can see some improvements in the quality of this bedding.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この布団の品しつには、いくらか改善が見られると思います。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I am so embarrassed, I want to bury myself under a futon.
Context 2-JP: <jp>はずかしすぎて布団を頭からかぶってかくれたいよー！</jp>
Context 3-EN: I’m getting sick of these futon salespeople. Can’t they understand that if I don’t buy something after several visits, that I’m never going to buy it? So annoying.
Context 3-JP: <jp>布団の勧誘って、何であんなにしつこいのかなぁ。何度来られても買わないものは買わないっつうの。ほんと、鬱陶しい！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>face</kanji> of this object is so <kanji>white</kanji>! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so <vocabulary>interesting</vocabulary>...
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the <jp>面</jp> part (<jp>白い</jp> is just like the vocab word <jp>白い</jp>). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "<reading>Oh mo</reading>!" (<jp>おも</jp>) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.
Context 1-EN: He is an amusing guy, his only downside is that he gets angry over the smallest things.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつは面白いやつだけど、ちょっとしたことですぐ切れるのがネックだよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This manga is a bit crude but it's very interesting.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このマンガは、ちょっと下品だけどとても面白いんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Ahahaha! You crack me up, Fugu! That’s the funniest thing I’ve ever heard.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あはははは！超ウケるんだけど。今まで聞いた中で、一番面白い話だわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Press <kanji>uneven</kanji> carvings into paper to make the newest <kanji>edition</kanji> of your magazine. What you're using is a <vocabulary>letterpress</vocabulary>. This made mass printing nice and cheap(ish) in Japan!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because <jp>はん</jp> becomes <jp>ぱん</jp> here.
Context 1-EN: At our company we use special techniques to cheaply do resin relief printing and direct plate making.
Context 1-JP: <jp>我が社では、特殊な技術を用いて、樹脂凸版の直接製版を格安で行っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s are in your <kanji>heart</kanji>. When your feelings are in your heart they are pure feelings. You can be happy for people and feel <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary> for their successes. This is a great feeling to have in your heart.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: You have such an admirable child.
Context 1-JP: <jp>感心なお子さんですね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: You earned my admiration by cleaning your room every single day.
Context 2-JP: <jp>毎日休まずに部屋をそうじするなんて、感心、感心。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Katie earned the admiration of her co-workers with her hard work and attention to detail.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ケイティは、真面目で熱心な働きと細かい気配りで、同僚たちを感心させた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This one makes no sense (sorry!). When you <kanji>join</kanji> together with someone at a <kanji>metropolis</kanji>, you do it <vocabulary>at your convenience</vocabulary>. You're important, after all, so you just do what you want and make the other person wait in this giant metropolis while you move along leisurely. Imagine this, and keep thinking "at your convenience" as you walk about.This word is usually used in a nicer way, though. As in, "do it at your convenience!"
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for <jp>都</jp> is an exception from what you learned with the kanji. To remember this, just think about someone who does something at their own convenience. They say, I'm going <reading>to go</reading> (<jp>つごう</jp>) where I want, when I want, at my own convenience.The <jp>合</jp> (<jp>ごう)</jp> part is a reading you know from the kanji, though, so if you can get to "to go" with the mnemonic, you should be able to put two and two together to know that it's a long vowel <jp>ごう</jp>.
Context 1-EN: I'll get in touch with you as soon as possible.
Context 1-JP: <jp>都合がつき次第、こちらかられんらくします。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Depending on the circumstances, Koichi's wedding ceremony may be postponed.
Context 2-JP: <jp>都合次第では、コウイチのけっこんしきはえん期になるかもしれません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Which day is convenient for you, Saturday or Sunday?" "It makes no difference to me."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「土曜日と日曜日、どちらの方が都合がいい？」「どちらでもいいよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>profit</kanji> from the <kanji>left</kanji>, you're probably doing everything on the left. That's your good side. You're probably <vocabulary>left handed</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings, so combine the readings of the words <jp>左</jp> and <jp>利く</jp> together to get the reading of this one. It makes sense since this word is like two words put together.
Context 1-EN: For some reason I'm always attracted to left-handed women.
Context 1-JP: <jp>なぜかいつも左利きの女せいにひかれるんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm buckling down on work for left-handed people.
Context 2-JP: <jp>左利きの人向けの仕事に力を入れています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "May I ask the purpose of your call?" "I just want to know if you are left handed." "I’m afraid I’m not at liberty to disclose that information."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「どういったご用件でしょうか？」「あなたが左利きかどうかだけ知りたいんですが。」「あいにくそれはお伝えできないことになっております。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>room</kanji> where you <kanji>join</kanji> other people to <kanji>wait</kanji>. This is a <vocabulary>waiting room</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember how you learned <jp>待合</jp> already? Well throw the on'yomi for <jp>室</jp> on the end of that and you have your reading!
Context 1-EN: I'm in the dentist's waiting room now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今、歯医者の待合室にいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: There are waiting rooms for tourist groups in airports.
Context 2-JP: <jp>空港には、団体で旅行するグループのための待合室があります。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I read an economics book the other day in the hospital waiting room and it was pretty interesting.
Context 3-JP: <jp>数日前、病院の待合室で経済についての本を読んだんだけど、結構良かったよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>foster</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> you bring into your family is your <vocabulary>adopted child</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I heard that station master's kid is actually an adopted child.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの駅長の子は、どうやら養子らしいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: My friend decided to adopt a child in September.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの友人は九月に養子をむかえいれることにした。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I scolded my adopted child because he has such a bad attitude.
Context 3-JP: <jp>養子の態度が悪いから、叱ってやったんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A surface covered in <kanji>convex</kanji> and <kanji>concave</kanji> parts is going to be really <vocabulary>uneven</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: It has distinctly uneven features, doesn’t it?
Context 1-JP: <jp>凹凸のはっきりした顔立ちですね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've seen the word <jp>高い</jp> from a couple levels ago. This word is related to that. It's like <jp>大きい</jp> versus <jp>大きさ</jp>, where one describes the other. In this case, the <jp>高さ</jp> is the <vocabulary>height</vocabulary> of something (while <jp>高い</jp> is tall). This word isn't "price" though. For that you'd ask <jp>いくらですか？</jp> (how much is it?).
Reading Mnemonic: Use the reading of <jp>高い</jp> (<jp>たかい</jp>) to help you to learn and remember the reading for this one. They are the same with just the hiragana at the end different.
Context 1-EN: His excitement levels are dangerously high, right?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あいつのテンションの高さはやばいよな。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Tofugu's cactus has grown to a height of 1.5 meters.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグのサボテンは、1.5メートルの高さにまでせい長しました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "What do you think about the height of this building? Is it too high?" "Sorry, but I don’t know. It’s over my head."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「この建物の高さについてどう思いますか？少し高すぎますかねえ？」「申し訳ありませんが、分かりません。私には難しすぎます。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>Western</kanji> <kanji>eat</kanji>s are <vocabulary>Western food</vocabulary>. Mmmm, 'dem hamburgers.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: The Western food restaurant was made in cooperation with famous sushi restaurants.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この洋食レストランは、有名なすし屋が共同して立ち上げたものです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm working part-time at a so-called old fashioned Western family restaurant.
Context 2-JP: <jp>いわゆる昔ながらの洋食屋さんで、バイトをしています。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Oh, did you eat the western-style lunch set at that restaurant? Hahaha. No wonder you still feel full.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ええっ！あそこのレストランで洋食ランチセットを食べたの？ははは。どおりでまだお腹がいっぱいなはずだわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A man in a leather jacket <kanji>scold</kanji>s you and is using <kanji>fear</kanji> tactics to get paid. He's <vocabulary>blackmailing</vocabulary> you! That's illegal. Come to think of it, he's probably a member of the yakuza. You should move.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: The yakuza is using my adultery to blackmail me.
Context 1-JP: <jp>不倫をダシにヤクザに恐喝されています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: If you <kanji>love</kanji> your <kanji>self</kanji> that is <vocabulary>self love</vocabulary>. Some would call too much self love <vocabulary>selfishness</vocabulary> as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.
Context 1-EN: I've decided all by myself that today is self love day, so I'm gonna spoil myself all day long.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今日は自愛デーにすることに自分で決めたので、一日中自愛しまくっちゃいます。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I don't think you should make it your purpose in life, if it only works out at the cost of your self care.
Context 2-JP: <jp>自愛をぎせいにして成り立つものを生きがいにするべきではないと思うんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I sincerely hope you’ll take good care of yourself and don't catch a cold or anything like that in times like these.
Context 3-JP: <jp>時節柄、お風邪など召しませぬよう、くれぐれも御自愛くださいませ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>most</kanji> <kanji>deep</kanji> is the <vocabulary>deepest</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Japan's deepest subway line is the Oedo line, which goes as low as 48 meters below ground.
Context 1-JP: <jp>日本で最深な地下鉄は、地下48ｍの場所がある大え戸線です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Jealousy is the deepest sin of human sins.
Context 2-JP: <jp>しっとは人間の最深のつみだ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Salmon and I had our wedding ceremony in a romantic hidden cave located at the deepest part of the ocean that light can still reach.
Context 3-JP: <jp>サーモンと俺は、光が到達できる海の最深部に位置するロマンチックな秘密の洞穴で、結婚式をあげた。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> things in the way that <kanji>nature</kanji> intended, you're doing things in a quite <vocabulary>orderly</vocabulary> fashion. This is the natural state of things, nice and arranged and natural. Orderly!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Even though there are many people in Tokyo, it is well organized.
Context 1-JP: <jp>東京は人が多いけれど整然としています。</jp>
Context 2-JP: <jp>ダリンはいつも理路整然としたせつ明をしてくれます。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The neatly arranged wine bottles on the shelves of the Tofugu office were all emptied out by Mami.
Context 3-JP: <jp>Tofuguオフィスの棚に整然と並べられていたワインボトルを、マミが全部空けてしまった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <jp>い</jp> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>warm</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Touch something that's warm... too warm! You pull your hand back and go "<reading>AH ta ta!</reading> (<jp>あたた</jp>). People make this noise when they touch something that's hot, I hear. It's almost like saying "hot hot hot" while dropping the "h" sound.
Context 1-EN: I want to drink something warm.
Context 1-JP: <jp>何か温かいものが飲みたいなぁ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I'm a beginner, so please go easy on me.
Context 2-JP: <jp>初心者なので、どうか温かい目で見まもってください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Would you like some warm ice cream for dessert?" "No, we’re all set."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「デザートに温かいアイスクリームはいかがですか？」 「いいえ、もう結構です。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You see a man walking <vocabulary>east</vocabulary>, toward the sun rising behind that tree, but it's too bright. He trips and <reading>he gash</reading>es (<jp>ひがし</jp>) his foot on a root that was sticking out of the ground. His foot is torn up really bad, but he tries to take another step and, oh no, he gashes his foot again! This guy is not having an easy time going east.
Context 1-EN: Let’s meet in the cafe that's on the east side of the station.
Context 1-JP: <jp>えきの東がわにあるきっ茶店で会いましょう。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I live on the east side of the airport.
Context 3-JP: <jp>空港の東側に住んでいます。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Do you remember how <jp>米国</jp> can mean "America?" That <jp>米</jp> means America sometimes. So, when you see <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>rice</kanji> (I mean, <kanji>America</kanji>), you can think of this word as meaning <vocabulary>All America</vocabulary> (sort of like how <jp>全日本</jp> means "All Japan.").
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: This is a mega-hit blockbuster that brought all of America to tears.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これは、全米がなみだした、大ヒットチョ～大作えいがです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Hideki Matsuyama finished second at the 2017 U.S. Open.
Context 2-JP: <jp>まつ山ひできは、2017年の全米オープンで二いに入った。</jp>
Context 3-EN: What's the No. 1 song on the U.S. hit chart now?
Context 3-JP: <jp>全米ヒットチャートで今一位の曲は何ですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>taste</kanji> of <kanji>salt</kanji> is a <vocabulary>salty taste</vocabulary> (it's also when something <vocabulary>tastes salty</vocabulary>).
Reading Whitelist: しおあじ,えんみ,しおみ
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of <jp>塩</jp> (you learned the reading with the kanji) and <jp>味</jp> and you have yourself <reading><jp>しおあじ</jp></reading>.If you happen to be a cooking show fan, you might also hear the on'yomi reading of this word - <reading><jp>えんみ</jp></reading>. This word can also be read as <reading><jp>しおみ</jp></reading>, which has more or less the same meaning as the primary reading you learned.
Context 1-EN: Maybe I could've used more salt.
Context 1-JP: <jp>もっと塩味を利かせてもよかったかもね。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Lightly-salted potato chips aren't that popular.
Context 2-JP: <jp>うす塩味のポテトチップスは、あまり人気がありません。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey! I heard that if I make salty jello for Koichi, I’ll get a free TextFugu account." "It’s better if you don’t believe that. I think it’s a lie!"
Context 3-JP: <jp>「ねぇねぇ！コウイチに塩味のジェロを作ってあげたら、テキストフグのアカウントが無料でもらえるって聞いたんだけど。」「信じないほうがいいよ。それって嘘だと思うよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!
Context 1-EN: How many tsubo is this land?
Context 1-JP: <jp>この土地は何坪ぐらいですか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hurry</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone who is trying <vocabulary>to hurry</vocabulary> is someone who is not at <reading>ease</reading> (<jp>いそ</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Koichi left a note for Viet in a hurry and stayed in the toilet for an hour.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは急いでビエトに書きおきを残した後、トイレに一時間こもった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi heard that Viet broke down from working too much, so he hurried to the hospital.
Context 2-JP: <jp>ビエトがか労でたおれたと聞いて、コウイチは病院へ急ぎました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "Hey, hurry up! We’ll be late." "I just woke up, I’m coming."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「もう！急いでよ！遅れちゃうわ。」「今起きたから、すぐ行くわ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the kanji means <kanji>yonder</kanji>, which is like "over there." This is the verb version of "yonder." That being said, "to yonder" isn't really a thing, so you have to think of what happens when you "look yonder." This word means <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to turn toward</vocabulary>. You're looking yonder, but you have to turn towards said yonder to look that way.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You turn <vocabulary>to face</vocabulary> a new direction and look out into the distance. There is a single cow out there. It turns to face you too, and says <reading>moo</reading> (<jp>む</jp>).
Context 1-EN: Turn this way, please.
Context 1-JP: <jp>こっちを向いてください。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This room is facing South, so it gets very sunny.
Context 2-JP: <jp>このへやは、南を向いているので日当たりがいい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Now, let’s turn toward your dad and ask him why he’s wearing a baby costume.
Context 3-JP: <jp>今度は、お父さんの方を向いて、どうして赤ちゃんの格好をしているのか聞いてみましょう。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you <jp>変な猫！</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.
Context 1-EN: I thought there was a strange man behind the pole, but it was just Koichi.
Context 1-JP: <jp>はしらのかげに変な人がいると思ったらただのコウイチだった。</jp>
Context 2-EN: It's absolutely absurd that men get higher pay than women despite doing the same work!
Context 2-JP: <jp>同じ仕事をしているのに男性の方が女性よりきゅう料が高いなんてぜっ対に変だよ！</jp>
Context 3-EN: That’s strange. I can’t find the email you say you sent me anywhere in my mailbox.
Context 3-JP: <jp>変だなぁ。僕のメールボックスには、君が送ったと言っているメールがどこにも見当たらないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>person</kanji> who does <kanji>poem</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>poet</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Salmon is a poet who represents the current century.
Context 1-JP: <jp>サーモンは今世紀を代表する詩人です。</jp>
Context 2-EN: One of my friends is a poet, and poems take up space all over the walls in his house.
Context 2-JP: <jp>わたしの友人に詩人が一人いるんですが、かれの家の中はかべ中詩でおおわれているんです。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Even though you’re a poet and you like using metaphors, you have to speak clearer or people won’t understand you.
Context 3-JP: <jp>君は詩人で、暗喩を使うことが好きなのかもしれないけど、もっと分かりやすく話さないと相手はわからないよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for <jp>合</jp> is <kanji>join</kanji>, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is <vocabulary>to join together</vocabulary>, and it can also mean <vocabulary>to unify</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to match</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>合う</jp>, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.
Context 1-EN: We joined all the red and white wires together.
Context 1-JP: <jp>全ての赤と白のワイヤーを一たばに合わせました。</jp>
Context 2-EN: A man will only slow down to match a woman's pace if they like her.
Context 2-JP: <jp>男が女のペースに合わせてゆっくり歩くのは、その女のことが好きな時だけさ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hey, Steve. You’ve been living in Japan for a pretty long time now so don’t you think it’s time for you to adjust to Japanese customs? Stop being so picky and start eating fish.
Context 3-JP: <jp>おい、スティーヴ！お前はもうずいぶん長く日本に住んでいるんだから、そろそろ日本の習慣とかに合わせたほうがいいんじゃないのか？好き嫌いは止めて、魚も食べるようにしろよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>今</jp> means now. What you probably don't know is that <jp>まで</jp> means "until." So, this word means <vocabulary>until now</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the kun'yomi reading which you learned previously when you learned the vocab word <jp>今</jp>. You can tell this is a kun'yomi reading because it has hiragana attached. So if you know that, you should be able to read this word as well.
Context 1-EN: What have you been doing until now?
Context 1-JP: <jp>今まで何をしていたんですか。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Koichi had a million girlfriends up until now, but he is finally about to settle down with one woman.
Context 2-JP: <jp>コウイチが今まで付きあったかの女は百万人に上るが、ようやく一人の女の人におちつきつつある。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You are the best girlfriend I’ve had so far.
Context 3-JP: <jp>お前が今までの中では一番の彼女だよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: We've seen a few times where <jp>電</jp> refers to a train. They're big deals, after all, and use a ton of electricity. So, the <kanji>end</kanji> train for this word would refer to the <vocabulary>last train</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: What time was the last train?
Context 1-JP: <jp>終電、何時だっけ？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I've gotta go because it's almost time for the last train.
Context 2-JP: <jp>もうすぐ終電だから、そろそろかえらなきゃ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: "If you ever miss the last train, you can always call me." "Thanks, I’ll keep that in mind."
Context 3-JP: <jp>「もし終電に乗り遅れたら、いつでも電話してくれていいよ。」「有難う。覚えておくよ。」</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Plant</kanji> <kanji>things</kanji> are <vocabulary>plants</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>vegetation</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji.
Context 1-EN: Apparently Koichi can understand what plants are saying.
Context 1-JP: <jp>コウイチは植物の言っている事が分かるらしい。</jp>
Context 2-EN: This is mulch from the vegetation.
Context 2-JP: <jp>これは、植物でできたふ葉土です。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I don’t have a green thumb but I like to grow plants.
Context 3-JP: <jp>園芸の才能は無いけど植物を育てるのは好きなんですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>sleep</kanji> <kanji>bed</kanji> is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a <vocabulary>bed</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>crib</vocabulary>. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.
Reading Mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for <jp>床</jp>. You take <jp>とこ</jp> and rendaku it into <jp>どこ</jp>. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "<reading>where</reading> (<jp>どこ</jp>) is it?"
Context 1-EN: "Come now, isn’t it about time for bed?" My grandfather used to say that to me every night.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「さぁ、そろそろ寝床に着く時間じゃぞ。」子供の頃、毎晩祖父にこう言われました。</jp>

Meaning: To Flow,To Flush,To Drain,To Pour,To Float,To Wash Away,To Set Afloat
Meaning Mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>, but what in the world could "to stream" be (remember, there weren't streams of StarCraft II games back in the day when this word was made up)? Well, let's think water. If you're streaming water, it's going <vocabulary>to flow</vocabulary>. Alternatively, <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> works too.
Reading Mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you do with someone who is a <reading>nagger</reading> (one who nags)? You have <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> them down the toilet. Imagine someone nagging you to do your chores so you flush them down the toilet, somehow.
Context 1-EN: You forgot to flush the toilet, didn't you?
Context 1-JP: <jp>トイレの水、流すのわすれたでしょう？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Do you know why they are pouring oil over the swamp?
Context 2-JP: <jp>どうしてあの人たちがぬま地にあぶらを流してるか知っている？</jp>
Context 3-EN: A Tofugu custom involves cutting paper into the shape of fugu and setting them afloat down a stream on Koichi’s birthday.
Context 3-JP: <jp>トーフグの風習に、河豚の形に切りとった紙を、コウイチの誕生日に川に流すというものがあります。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... <jp>はる</jp>, I mean.
Context 1-EN: I don't like bugs, so I don't like spring.
Context 1-JP: <jp>わたしは虫が苦手だから春はきらいです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: "How did your team do in the spring tournament?" "Hehe. Epic win."
Context 2-JP: <jp>「お前のチーム、春の大会ではどうだったの？」「へへ。大勝したっての！」</jp>
Context 3-EN: I heard the reason the character for "spring" is used for spring roll is because people used to make spring rolls with vegetables that sprout in spring.
Context 3-JP: <jp>春巻きという料理に「春」の字が使われているのは、春に芽が出る野菜を使って作る食べ物だかららしいですよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>荒れる</jp> is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying <vocabulary>to lay waste</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to devastate</vocabulary> everything around you.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>荒れる</jp>.
Context 1-EN: My car was broken into last night and my mac was stolen.
Context 1-JP: <jp>昨夜車上荒らしにあって、マックを盗まれました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>ordinal number prefix</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>rank</kanji>. Basically, this means "first rank" or <vocabulary>first place</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Tofugu got first place five consecutive times in tournaments for unique Japanese learning tools.
Context 1-JP: <jp>トーフグはユニークな日本語学習教ざいとして、五年れんぞく第一位のざをかくとくしています。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Out of the whole Tofugu team, I personally want Kristen to drive around in a moped the most.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグチームの中で一番げん付乗りまわしていてほしい人第一位はわたしてきにはクリステンなんだよね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Hiro had been the top sales person in the company for five consecutive years until Akira joined the company.
Context 3-JP: <jp>あきらが入社するまで、ヒロは五年続けて、社内で売り上げ第一位だった。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>堅い</jp> is "solid" or "tough." When your <kanji>hand</kanji> is <kanji>solid</kanji> and tough, it's <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steady</vocabulary>. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the two words <jp>手</jp> and <jp>堅い</jp> combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: I’m thinking of learning how to become an undertaker because it looks like a pretty secure job.
Context 1-JP: <jp>中々手堅い仕事みたいだから、葬儀屋になるための勉強をしようかなって思ってるんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>front</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>front side</vocabulary> of it (kind of like how <jp>外面</jp> is the exterior because it's the outside face).
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: Viet always puts his good man-ness to the front.
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトはいつもいい人さを前面に出している。</jp>
Context 2-EN: Please find a box that has green on both the front and back sides.
Context 2-JP: <jp>前面も後面も両方とも緑色の箱をさがしてください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Whenever we send a letter or a package, we put the Tofugu sticker on the front of it.
Context 3-JP: <jp>手紙や小包を送る時には、いつも前面にTofuguのステッカーを貼ります。</jp>

Meaning: To Worry,To Be Concerned,To Be Anxious
Meaning Mnemonic: You know that <jp>心配</jp> is "a worry." What about the verb version of that? It would be <vocabulary>to worry</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes straight from <jp>心配</jp> so try to make sure you know that word so you can read this word! It's also all jukugo on'yomi reading, too, so you should be able to figure it out regardless.
Context 1-EN: Safety is that company's first priority, so you don't have to be concerned about that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>あの会社は安全第一だから、心配しなくても大丈夫ですよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: If you are anxious about Tofugu's performance, please buy our tenugui.
Context 2-JP: <jp>トーフグの業せきを心配してくれているのであれば、どうか手ぬぐいを買ってください。</jp>
Context 3-EN: The snow is falling heavily outside and the roads are getting pretty icy, so I’m worried about being able to drive up the hill to my boyfriend’s house.
Context 3-JP: <jp>外では雪がしんしんと降っており、地面が凍りだしているので、彼氏の家に行くときに丘を車で登りきれるのかどうか心配しています。</jp>

Meaning: To Work Well,To Be Possible,To Be Effective
Meaning Mnemonic: You know the kanji means <kanji>profit</kanji>. When you make it into a verb, though, it means <vocabulary>to work well</vocabulary>. If you think about it, when something works well it makes you a profit.
Reading Mnemonic: What works so well? Your special <reading>key</reading> (<jp>き</jp>) that can unlock anyone and anything's potential. Imagine putting it into a key slot in someone's back. Someone who's a good for nothing can't-do-anything is now an effective member of society! Go around using your key on other non-effective things and show them that anything is possible!
Context 1-EN: My bike's brakes don't work well.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自転車のブレーキが利かない。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I had a skilled cook make food for me today.
Context 2-JP: <jp>今日は、うでの利くりょうり人にりょうりを作ってもらいました。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is a pretty flexible man.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは中々融通の利く男だ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <kanji>Field</kanji> <kanji>Sphere</kanji>! The greatest sport to grace this earth since a very similar (aka the same) sport, <vocabulary>baseball</vocabulary>. Think about it, you play on a field and you use a little sphere. Awesome!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: We are just about to go to a professional baseball game.
Context 1-JP: <jp>これから、プロ野球のし合を見に行くところなんです。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I like baseball, but I heard you have to act like you're in the army if you belong to the baseball club, so I don't want to join it.
Context 2-JP: <jp>野球は好きだけど、野球部は体育会けいって聞いたから入りたくないんだよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: I fractured my knee while playing baseball.
Context 3-JP: <jp>野球をしている時に膝を骨折しちゃったんだよね。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: This is a strange word, so you'll have to bear with me. You know that <jp>知</jp> means <kanji>know</kanji>. But in the case of this word, what do you know? Look at the second half. <jp>らせ</jp> sounds a bit like "race." So, you know about a "race." How do you know about this race? You got a <vocabulary>notice</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>notification</vocabulary> about it.
Reading Mnemonic: Remember <jp>知る</jp>? This is the same reading (<jp>し</jp>). So, if you know that, you'll be able to read this one as well.
Context 1-EN: Excuse me, I have something that I’d like to tell you - do you have some time now?
Context 1-JP: <jp>あのう、お知らせしたいことがあるんですが、今、いいですか？</jp>
Context 2-EN: Did you read the notice from the school already?
Context 2-JP: <jp>学校からのお知らせはもうよみましたか？</jp>
Context 3-EN: I have some bad news. Someone broke into our home last night and stole all the ice cream we had stored in our freezer.
Context 3-JP: <jp>残念なお知らせがあります。昨夜誰かがこの家に侵入し、冷凍庫に入っていたアイスクリームを全部盗んでしまいました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Someone with <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> is someone who has <vocabulary>evil intent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>malice</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>ill will</vocabulary>. Hopefully you don't have too much <jp>悪気</jp>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading itself has a lot of <jp>悪気</jp> with all the exceptions it has. The <jp>悪</jp> part is read like <jp>悪い</jp>. Then, <jp>気</jp> is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.
Context 1-EN: I know you don't have any evil intent, but please understand that we could get hurt if you say something like that.
Context 1-JP: <jp>悪気がないのは知ってるけど、そういうことを言われるとこっちもきずつくんだよ？</jp>
Context 2-EN: I didn't do it out of malice, but I'm really sorry that I made you feel that way.
Context 2-JP: <jp>悪気があってしたわけじゃないんですが、けっかてきにそういう風に感じさせてしまう事になって本当にごめんなさい。</jp>
Context 3-EN: By the way, how did you get the job without any experience in the first place? No offense, of course.
Context 3-JP: <jp>ところで、そもそも、何の経験もなくて、どうやってその職を得たの？あ、悪気は無いよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: <jp>荒い</jp> is <kanji>rough</kanji>. Double that to <jp>荒々しい</jp> and you have the same thing: <vocabulary>wild</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rough</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>荒い</jp>. Since you already know that <jp>々</jp> means it repeats, you already know this reading!
Context 1-EN: In a wild voice he proclaimed that he was totally “pissed off” at his wife for "pissing" on his face every night while he was sleeping.
