Context 1-JP: <jp>彼は荒々しい声で、寝ている時に奥さんが毎晩顔に小便を掛けてくることに怒り心頭していることを公言しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <jp>包み</jp> is a <kanji>bundle</kanji> or <kanji>package</kanji>, and <jp>紙</jp> is <kanji>paper</kanji>. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be <vocabulary>wrapping paper</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is <jp>包み</jp> and <jp>紙</jp> combined together. Be careful of rendaku.
Context 1-EN: There is braille on this wrapping paper.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この包み紙には点字が施してあるわ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <jp>趣味</jp> is your hobby. It's the thing you do on habit. A <kanji>bad</kanji> hobby is a habit that you do all the time that's no good. This is a <vocabulary>bad habit</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: My mom forbade my dad from collecting tasteless dolls.
Context 1-JP: <jp>母は、父が悪趣味な人形を集めることを禁止しました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>tide</kanji> <kanji>time</kanji> is the <vocabulary>tidal hour</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from the individual words, <jp>潮</jp> and <jp>時</jp>. Watch out for the rendaku.
Context 1-EN: It’s high time that you quit smoking. Go get some nicotine patches right now.
Context 1-JP: <jp>今こそタバコをやめる潮時だ。今すぐニコチンパッチを買いに行くんだ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: The <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> isn't what you think, most likely. This is the <vocabulary>Japan current</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>Kuroshio Current</vocabulary>. It's a Northern flowing  current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. <jp>黒</jp> and <jp>潮</jp>.
Context 1-EN: Where exactly is the basin of the Kuroshio Current?
Context 1-JP: <jp>黒潮の流域とは正確にはどこになりますか？</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You already know that <jp>弦楽</jp> means "string music," so add some <kanji>pipe</kanji>s to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have <vocabulary>orchestral music</vocabulary>. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section!
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I want to let the children learn orchestral music.
Context 1-JP: <jp>子供に管弦楽を習わせたいと思っています。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: You've hopefully come across <jp>負ける</jp> by now, which means "to lose." So, you can figure out this word means "losing dog." Well, calling someone a dog isn't so nice, so you're probably just calling them a <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary>. As Ace Ventura would say: "Lehuzeherrrr. LOSER."
Reading Mnemonic: The readings are kun'yomi, but you should be familiar with <jp>負ける</jp> and of course <jp>犬</jp> well enough to learn the reading here.
Context 1-EN: I'm aware that I'm a loser who loves to just stay home and watch TV all day.
Context 1-JP: <jp>自分が、一日中家にいて、テレビばっかりみてる負け犬だってことは自かくしているよ。</jp>
Context 2-EN: I can't stand the fact that the loser is taking over my job tomorrow.
Context 2-JP: <jp>あの負け犬が明日からおれの仕事を引きつぐとか、本当にがまんできないよ。</jp>
Context 3-EN: You are a loser and really creepy!
Context 3-JP: <jp>この負け犬め！キモいんだよ！</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <jp>う</jp> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grate</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to rub</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to scrub</vocabulary>. It will help to think back to <jp>擦れる</jp> which means "to chafe" or "to rub," which is more similar to this verb than the kanji meaning is.
Reading Mnemonic: This kanji shares the reading from <jp>擦れる</jp> but it also has another reading, <jp>こする</jp>. Both are considered "common." Most likely, you'll use <jp>する</jp>'s reading the most because it is the same as <jp>すれる</jp>'s reading, but for now try to keep the other one in your mind as well.
Context 1-EN: I was rubbing my eyes because of my allergies and one of my contact lenses was torn.
Context 1-JP: <jp>花粉症で目を擦ってたら、片方のコンタクトレンズが破けました。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>bundle</kanji> is merely a <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>. Something big would be a big package, I guess.
Reading Mnemonic: The reading comes from <jp>小</jp> (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and <jp>包み</jp>, with the <jp>み</jp> pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see <jp>づ</jp> too often.
Context 1-EN: This package is just a symbol of our friendship.
Context 1-JP: <jp>この小包は、ほんの友情の印です。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: A <kanji>particle</kanji> (<jp>粒子</jp>) that is the <kanji>element</kanji> version of it is an <vocabulary>elementary particle</vocabulary>.
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Context 1-EN: I feel like I’ve seen the word "elementary particle" in my physics textbook.
Context 1-JP: <jp>「素粒子」って言葉は物理の教科書で見た事がある気がするよ。</jp>

Meaning Mnemonic: Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>status</kanji> is where you, yourself, are a person. This is more than skin deep, though, this is your status after all. This is your <vocabulary>character</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>personality</vocabulary>. What's the status of your character? Good? Bad? Getting there?
Reading Mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Context 1-EN: I question Viet's character!
Context 1-JP: <jp>ビエトの人格を疑います！</jp>
Context 2-EN: Fugu has a very gentle personality, doesn't he?
Context 2-JP: <jp>フグってとっても温こうな人格の持ち主だね。</jp>
Context 3-EN: Koichi is a person of integrity. Every Sunday he goes to the orphanage and donates bacon.
Context 3-JP: <jp>コウイチは人格者です。毎週日曜日に孤児院に出向いて、ベーコンを寄付しているのです。</jp>
